revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Abetalipoproteinemia | image = Abetalipoproteinemia_-_very_high_mag.jpg | caption = [[Micrograph]] showing [[enterocyte]]s with a clear [[cytoplasm]] (due to lipid accumulation) characteristic of abetalipoproteinemia. [[duodenum|Duodenal]] [[biopsy]]. [[H&E stain]]. | width = 175 | pronounce = | field = | synonyms = Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome<ref name="pmid15411425">{{cite journal |author=Bassen FA|author2=Kornzweig AL |title=Malformation of the erythrocytes in a case of atypical retinitis pigmentosa |journal=Blood |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=381–87 |year=1950 |pmid=15411425 |doi= |url=http://bloodjournal.hematologylibrary.org/cgi/reprint/5/4/381}}</ref> | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }}
'''Abetalipoproteinemia''' is a disorder that interferes with the normal absorption of fat and fat-soluble vitamins from food. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/abetalipoproteinemia|title=Abetalipoproteinemia|last=Reference|first=Genetics Home|website=Genetics Home Reference|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref> It is caused by a mutation in [[microsomal triglyceride transfer protein]] resulting in deficiencies in the apolipoproteins B-48 and B-100, which are used in the synthesis and exportation of [[chylomicrons]] and [[VLDL]] respectively. It is not to be confused with [[familial dysbetalipoproteinemia]].
It is a rare [[autosomal recessive]] disorder.<ref name="pmid17275380">{{cite journal|last1=Benayoun|first1=Liat|last2=Granot|first2=Esther|last3=Rizel|first3=Leah|last4=Allon-Shalev|first4=Stavit|last5=Behar|first5=Doron M.|last6=Ben-Yosef|first6=Tamar|title=Abetalipoproteinemia in Israel: Evidence for a founder mutation in the Ashkenazi Jewish population and a contiguous gene deletion in an Arab patient|journal=Molecular Genetics and Metabolism|date=April 2007|volume=90|issue=4|pages=453–7|doi=10.1016/j.ymgme.2006.12.010|pmid=17275380}}</ref>
== Presentation ==
===Symptoms=== Often symptoms will arise that indicate the body is not absorbing or making the lipoproteins that it needs. These symptoms usually appear ''en masse''.
These symptoms come as follows: *[[Failure to thrive]]/Failure to grow in infancy<ref name="pmid20953537">{{cite journal|year=2010|last1=Hasosah|first1=MY|last2=Shesha|first2=SJ|last3=Sukkar|first3=GA|last4=Bassuni|first4=WY|title=Rickets and dysmorphic findings in a child with abetalipoproteinemia|volume=31|issue=10|pages=1169–71|journal=Saudi medical journal|pmid=20953537}}</ref> *[[Steatorrhea]]/Fatty, pale stools<ref name="pmid20953537" /><ref name="pmid20626336">{{cite journal|last=Moutzouri|first=E|author2=Elisaf, M|author3= Liberopoulos, EN|title=Hypocholesterolemia.|journal=Current Vascular Pharmacology|date=March 2011|volume=9|issue=2|pages=200–12|pmid=20626336|doi=10.2174/157016111794519354}}</ref> *Frothy stools<ref name="pmid20953537" /> *Foul smelling stools<ref name="pmid20953537" /> *Protruding abdomen *[[Intellectual disability]]/[[developmental delay]] *[[Developmental coordination disorder]], evident by age ten *Muscle weakness *Slurred speech *[[Scoliosis]] (curvature of the spine) *Progressive decreased vision *Balance and coordination problems
===Signs=== *[[Acanthocyte|Acanthocytosis]]<ref name="pmid20953537" /><ref name="pmid874076">{{cite journal |author=Cooper RA|author2=Durocher JR|author3=Leslie MH |title=Decreased fluidity of red cell membrane lipids in abetalipoproteinemia |journal=J. Clin. Invest. |volume=60 |issue=1 |pages=115–21 |date=July 1977 |pmid=874076 |pmc=372349 |doi=10.1172/JCI108747}}</ref> *[[Retinitis pigmentosa]] *[[Hypocholesterolemia]]/low blood cholesterol<ref name="pmid20626336" /> ===Features=== Abetalipoproteinemia affects the absorption of dietary fats, [[cholesterol]], and certain [[vitamin]]s. People affected by this disorder are not able to make certain [[lipoprotein]]s, which are [[molecule]]s that consist of [[protein]]s combined with cholesterol and particular fats called [[triglyceride]]s. This leads to a multiple vitamin deficiency, affecting the fat-soluble [[Retinol|vitamin A]], [[vitamin D]], [[Tocopherol|vitamin E]], and [[vitamin K]].<ref name="titleAbetalipoproteinemia - Genetics Home Reference" /> However, many of the observed effects are due to vitamin E deficiency in particular.<ref name="titleAbetalipoproteinemia - Genetics Home Reference" />
[[Image:Acanthocytosis.jpg|thumb|[[Acanthocytosis]] in a patient with abetalipoproteinemia.]] The signs and symptoms of abetalipoproteinemia appear in the first few months of life (because pancreatic lipase is not active in this period). They can include failure to gain weight and grow at the expected rate ([[failure to thrive]]); diarrhea; abnormal spiny red blood cells ([[acanthocyte|acanthocytosis]]); and fatty, foul-smelling stools ([[steatorrhea]]).<ref name="titleAbetalipoproteinemia - Genetics Home Reference" /> The stool may contain large chunks of fat and/or blood. Other features of this disorder may develop later in childhood and often impair the function of the nervous system. They can include poor muscle coordination, difficulty with balance and movement ([[ataxia]]),<ref name="titleAbetalipoproteinemia - Genetics Home Reference" /><ref name=Hentati>{{cite journal|last=Hentati|first=F|author2=El-Euch, G|author3= Bouhlal, Y|author4= Amouri, R|title=Ataxia with vitamin E deficiency and abetalipoproteinemia|journal=Handbook of clinical neurology|year=2012|volume=103|pages=295–305|pmid=21827896|doi=10.1016/B978-0-444-51892-7.00018-8|series=Handbook of Clinical Neurology|isbn=9780444518927}}</ref> and progressive degeneration of the [[retina]] (the light-sensitive layer in the posterior eye) that can progress to near-blindness (due to deficiency of vitamin A, retinol).<ref name="titleAbetalipoproteinemia - Genetics Home Reference" /> Adults in their thirties or forties may have increasing difficulty with balance and walking. Many of the signs and symptoms of abetalipoproteinemia result from a severe vitamin deficiency, especially vitamin E deficiency, which typically results in eye problems with degeneration of the spinocerebellar and dorsal column tracts.
==Genetics==
[[Image:autorecessive.svg|thumb|right|Abetalipoproteinemia has an autosomal recessive pattern of [[inheritance]].]]
Mutations in the [[microsomal triglyceride transfer protein]] (MTTP) gene has been associated with this condition.<ref name="titleAbetalipoproteinemia - Genetics Home Reference">{{cite web |url=http://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition=abetalipoproteinemia |title=Abetalipoproteinemia - Genetics Home Reference |accessdate=2008-02-24 |format= |work=}}</ref> ([[Apolipoprotein B deficiency]], a related condition, is associated with deficiencies of [[apolipoprotein B]].)<ref name="pmid22353470">{{cite journal|title=Multiple functions of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein|year=2012|last1=Hussain|first1=M Mahmood|last2=Rava|first2=Paul|last3=Walsh|first3=Meghan|last4=Rana|first4=Muhammad|last5=Iqbal|first5=Jahangir|journal=Nutrition & Metabolism|volume=9|pages=14|doi=10.1186/1743-7075-9-14|pmid=22353470|pmc=3337244}}</ref>
The ''MTTP'' gene provides instructions for making a protein called microsomal triglyceride transfer protein, which is essential for creating beta-lipoproteins.<ref name=pmid23556456>{{cite journal|last=Mohamed|first=N|author2=Mohamed Youssef, S|author3=Mohamed Yahia, H|author4=Afef, S|author5=Awatef, J|author6=Saber, H|author7=Mohamed Fadhel, N|author8=Sassolas, A|author9= Mohamed Naceur, S|title=Molecular characterization of Tunisian families with abetalipoproteinemia and identification of a novel mutation in MTTP gene|journal=Diagnostic pathology|date=Apr 4, 2013|volume=8|issue=1|pages=54|pmid=23556456|pmc=3632489|doi=10.1186/1746-1596-8-54}}</ref> These lipoproteins are both necessary for the absorption of fats, cholesterol, and fat-soluble vitamins from the diet and necessary for the efficient transport of these substances in the bloodstream.<ref name=pmid23043934>{{cite journal|title=Novel mutations in SAR1B and MTTP genes in Tunisian children with chylomicron retention disease and abetalipoproteinemia|year=2013|last1=Magnolo|first1=Lucia|last2=Najah|first2=Mohamed|last3=Fancello|first3=Tatiana|last4=Di Leo|first4=Enza|last5=Pinotti|first5=Elisa|last6=Brini|first6=Ines|last7=Gueddiche|first7=Neji M.|last8=Calandra|first8=Sebastiano|last9=Slimene|first9=Naceur M.|last10=Tarugi|first10=Patrizia|journal=Gene|volume=512|pages=28–34|issue=1|doi=10.1016/j.gene.2012.09.117|pmid=23043934}}</ref> Most of the mutations in this gene lead to the production of an abnormally short microsomal triglyceride transfer protein, which prevents the normal creation of beta-lipoproteins in the body.<ref name=pmid21394827>{{cite journal|last1=Pons|first1=Véronique|last2=Rolland|first2=Corinne|last3=Nauze|first3=Michel|last4=Danjoux|first4=Marie|last5=Gaibelet|first5=Gérald|last6=Durandy|first6=Anne|last7=Sassolas|first7=Agnès|last8=Lévy|first8=Emile|last9=Tercé|first9=François|last10=Collet|first10=Xavier|last11=Mas|first11=Emmanuel|title=A severe form of abetalipoproteinemia caused by new splicing mutations of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP)|journal=Human Mutation|date=July 2011|volume=32|issue=7|pages=751–9|doi=10.1002/humu.21494|pmid=21394827|url=https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-00651635/document}}</ref> MTTP-associated mutations are inherited in an [[autosomal]] [[recessive]] pattern, which means both copies of the gene must be faulty to produce the disease.<ref name=pmid21394827 />
==Diagnosis== The initial workup of abetalipoproteinemia typically consists of stool sampling, a blood smear, and a fasting lipid panel though these tests are not confirmatory.<ref name="pmid15765527">{{cite journal|last=Demircioğlu|first=F|author2=Oren, H|author3= Yilmaz, S|author4= Arslan, N|author5= Gürcü, O|author6= Irken, G|title=Abetalipoproteinemia: importance of the peripheral blood smear.|journal=Pediatric blood & cancer|date=August 2005|volume=45|issue=2|pages=237|pmid=15765527|doi=10.1002/pbc.20360}}</ref> As the disease is rare, though a genetics test is necessary for diagnosis, it is generally not done initially.
[[Acanthocytes]] are seen on blood smear.<ref name="pmid21534356">{{cite journal|last=Ozsoylu|first=S|title=Red cells in abetalipoproteinemia.|journal=The Turkish journal of pediatrics|date=Jan–Feb 2011|volume=53|issue=1|pages=119|pmid=21534356}}</ref> Since there is no or little assimilation of [[chylomicron]]s, their levels in [[Blood plasma|plasma]] remains low.
The inability to absorb fat in the ileum will result in [[steatorrhea]], or fat in the stool. As a result, this can be clinically diagnosed when foul-smelling stool is encountered. Low levels of plasma [[chylomicron]] are also characteristic.
There is an absence of [[apolipoprotein B]]. On intestinal [[biopsy]], [[vacuole]]s containing lipids are seen in enterocytes. This disorder may also result in fat accumulation in the liver (hepatic steatosis). Because the epithelial cells of the bowel lack the ability to place fats into chylomicrons, lipids accumulate at the surface of the cell, crowding the functions that are necessary for proper absorption.
== Treatment ==
Treatment normally consists of rigorous dieting, involving massive amounts of [[vitamin E]].<ref name=Hentati /> Vitamin E helps the body restore and produce lipoproteins, which people with abetalipoprotenimia usually lack. Vitamin E also helps keep skin and eyes healthy; studies show that many affected males will have vision problems later on in life. Developmental coordination disorder and muscle weakness are usually treated with physiotherapy or [[occupational therapy]]. Dietary restriction of [[triglyceride]]s has also been useful.
== Prognosis == If treatment is initiated early in disease the neurologic sequelae may be reversed and further deterioration can be prevented.<ref name="pmid8340987">{{cite journal|last=Rader|first=DJ|author2=Brewer HB, Jr|title=Abetalipoproteinemia. New insights into lipoprotein assembly and vitamin E metabolism from a rare genetic disease.|journal=JAMA: the Journal of the American Medical Association|date=Aug 18, 1993|volume=270|issue=7|pages=865–9|pmid=8340987|doi=10.1001/jama.1993.03510070087042}}</ref> If left untreated the condition may lead to death. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/diseases/5/abetalipoproteinemia#ref_5103|title=Abetalipoproteinemia {{!}} Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center (GARD) – an NCATS Program|website=rarediseases.info.nih.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{Medical resources | DiseasesDB = 17 | ICD10 = {{ICD10|E|78|6|e|78}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|272.5}} | ICDO = | OMIM = 200100 | MedlinePlus = 001666 | eMedicineSubj = med | eMedicineTopic = 1117 | MeshID = D000012 }} * {{NLM|abetalipoproteinemia}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080201000748/http://health.allrefer.com/health/bassen-kornzweig-syndrome-info.html AllRefer.com Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome] * {{cite web|title=Abetalipoproteinemia:|url=https://online.epocrates.com/noFrame/showPage.do?method=diseases&MonographId=471|publisher=Epocrates Online|accessdate=13 May 2013|author=David Alexander Leaf}} {{Lipidemias}}

revision.text:
{{about|the hypothalamic structure|the structure in the medulla oblongata|Arcuate nucleus (medulla)}} {{More citations needed|date=December 2008}} {{Infobox brain | Name = Arcuate nucleus | Latin = nucleus arcuatus hypothalami | Image = HypothalamicNuclei.PNG | Caption = Arcuate nucleus is 'AR', at bottom center, in green. | Image2 = | Caption2 = | IsPartOf = [[Hypothalamus]] | Components = | Artery = | Vein = | Acronym = }}
The '''arcuate nucleus''' of the hypothalamus (also known as '''ARH''',<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Bouret|first=Sebastien G.|last2=Draper|first2=Shin J.|last3=Simerly|first3=Richard B.|date=2004-03-17|title=Formation of Projection Pathways from the Arcuate Nucleus of the Hypothalamus to Hypothalamic Regions Implicated in the Neural Control of Feeding Behavior in Mice|url=http://www.jneurosci.org/content/24/11/2797|journal=The Journal of Neuroscience|language=en|volume=24|issue=11|pages=2797–2805|doi=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.5369-03.2004|issn=0270-6474|pmid=15028773}}</ref> '''ARC''',<ref name=":06">{{Cite book|title=The Human Hypothalamus: Anatomy, Functions and Disorders|last=Dudás|first=|publisher=Nova Science Publishers|year=2013|isbn=978-1-62081-806-0|location=New York|pages=|via=Ebscohost}}</ref> or '''infundibular nucleus'''<ref name=":06"/><ref>[http://www.onderzoekinformatie.nl/en/oi/nod/onderzoek/OND1289935/ onderzoekinformatie.nl - Project: Does activation of neurons in the infundibular nucleus in menopause prevent the occurrence of Alzheimer changes?]</ref>) is an aggregation of [[neuron]]s in the mediobasal [[hypothalamus]], adjacent to the [[third ventricle]] and the [[median eminence]]. The arcuate nucleus includes several important and diverse populations of neurons that help mediate different neuroendocrine and physiological functions, including: neuroendocrine neurons, centrally projecting neurons, and [[astrocyte]]s. The populations of neurons found in the arcuate nucleus are based on the [[hormone]]s they secrete or interact with and are responsible for hypothalamic function, such as regulating hormones released from the [[pituitary gland]] or secreting their own hormones. Neurons in this region are also responsible for integrating information and providing inputs to other nuclei in the hypothalamus or inputs to areas outside this region of the brain. These neurons, generated from the ventral part of the periventricular epithelium during embryonic development, locate dorsally in the hypothalamus, becoming part of the ventromedial hypothalamic region.<ref name=":14"/><ref name=":06"/><ref name=":23">{{Cite journal|last=Sapru|first=Hreday N.|title=Role of the hypothalamic arcuate nucleus in cardiovascular regulation|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.autneu.2012.10.016|journal=Autonomic Neuroscience|volume=175|issue=1–2|pages=38–50|doi=10.1016/j.autneu.2012.10.016|pmc=3625681}}</ref> The function of the arcuate nucleus relies on its diversity of neurons, but its central role is involved in [[homeostasis]]. The arcuate nucleus provides many physiological roles involved in feeding, metabolism, fertility, and cardiovascular regulation.<ref name=":14"/><ref name=":06"/><ref name=":23"/><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Coppari|first=Roberto|last2=Ichinose|first2=Masumi|last3=Lee|first3=Charlotte E.|last4=Pullen|first4=Abigail E.|last5=Kenny|first5=Christopher D.|last6=McGovern|first6=Robert A.|last7=Tang|first7=Vinsee|last8=Liu|first8=Shun M.|last9=Ludwig|first9=Thomas|title=The hypothalamic arcuate nucleus: A key site for mediating leptin’s effects on glucose homeostasis and locomotor activity|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1550413104000105|journal=Cell Metabolism|volume=1|issue=1|pages=63–72|doi=10.1016/j.cmet.2004.12.004}}</ref>
==Cell populations==
===Neuroendocrine neurons=== Different groups of arcuate nucleus neuroendocrine neurons secrete various types or combinations of [[neurotransmitter]]s and [[neuropeptide]]s, such as [[neuropeptide Y]] (NPY), [[gonadotropin-releasing hormone]] (GnRH), [[agouti-related peptide]] (AgRP), [[cocaine- and amphetamine-regulated transcript]] (CART), [[kisspeptin]], [[dopamine]], [[substance P]], [[growth hormone–releasing hormone]] (GHRH), [[neurokinin B]] (NKB), [[β-endorphin]], [[melanocyte-stimulating hormone]] (MSH), and [[somatostatin]]. [[Proopiomelanocortin]] (POMC) is a precursor [[polypeptide]] that is cleaved into MSH, ACTH, and β-endorphin and expressed in the arcuate nucleus.<ref name=":14"/>
Groups of [[Neuroendocrinology|neuroendocrine]] neurons include: * '''TIDA neurons''', or [[Tuberoinfundibular pathway|tuberoinfundibular dopamine neurons]], are neurons that regulate the secretion of [[prolactin]] from the pituitary gland and release the neurotransmitter [[dopamine]]. TIDA neurons have nerve endings in the [[median eminence]] that release [[dopamine]] into the [[Hypophyseal portal system|hypophysial portal blood]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Voogt|first=J. L.|last2=Lee|first2=Y.|last3=Yang|first3=S.|last4=Arbogast|first4=L.|date=2001-01-01|title=Regulation of prolactin secretion during pregnancy and lactation|journal=Progress in Brain Research|volume=133|pages=173–185|issn=0079-6123|pmid=11589129|doi=10.1016/S0079-6123(01)33013-3}}</ref> In lactating females, TIDA neurons are inhibited by the stimulus of suckling. Dopamine released from their nerve endings at the median eminence is transported to the [[anterior pituitary gland]], where it regulates the secretion of [[prolactin]]. Dopamine inhibits prolactin secretion, so when the TIDA neurons are inhibited, there is increased secretion of prolactin, which stimulates [[lactogenesis]] (milk production). Prolactin acts in a short-loop negative feedback manner to decrease its levels by stimulating the release of dopamine. Dopaminergic neurons of the arcuate also inhibit the release of [[gonadotropin-releasing hormone]], explaining in part why lactating (or otherwise [[hyperprolactinemia|hyperprolactinemic]]) women experience oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea (infrequency or absence of menses).<ref name=":0" /> * '''[[KNDy neuron|Kisspeptin/NKB neurons]]''' within the arcuate nucleus form synaptic inputs with TIDA neurons. These neurons express [[estrogen receptor]]s and also coexpress neurokinin B in female rats.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sawai|first=Nobuhiko|last2=Iijima|first2=Norio|last3=Takumi|first3=Ken|last4=Matsumoto|first4=Keisuke|last5=Ozawa|first5=Hitoshi|date=2012-09-01|title=Immunofluorescent histochemical and ultrastructural studies on the innervation of kisspeptin/neurokinin B neurons to tuberoinfundibular dopaminergic neurons in the arcuate nucleus of rats|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168010212001150|journal=Neuroscience Research|volume=74|issue=1|pages=10–16|doi=10.1016/j.neures.2012.05.011}}</ref> * '''GHRH neurons''' help to control [[growth hormone]] (GH) secretion in conjunction with somatostatin and NPY.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mano-Otagiri|first=Asuka|last2=Nemoto|first2=Takahiro|last3=Sekino|first3=Azusa|last4=Yamauchi|first4=Naoko|last5=Shuto|first5=Yujin|last6=Sugihara|first6=Hitoshi|last7=Oikawa|first7=Shinichi|last8=Shibasaki|first8=Tamotsu|date=2006-09-01|title=Growth Hormone-Releasing Hormone (GHRH) Neurons in the Arcuate Nucleus (Arc) of the Hypothalamus Are Decreased in Transgenic Rats Whose Expression of Ghrelin Receptor Is Attenuated: Evidence that Ghrelin Receptor Is Involved in the Up-Regulation of GHRH Expression in the Arc|url=http://press.endocrine.org/doi/10.1210/en.2005-1619|journal=Endocrinology|volume=147|issue=9|pages=4093–4103|doi=10.1210/en.2005-1619|issn=0013-7227}}</ref> * '''NPY/AgRP neurons''' and '''POMC/CART neurons''' make up two groups of neurons in the arcuate nucleus that are centrally involved in the neuroendocrine function of feeding. Medial neurons utilize NPY peptides as neurotransmitters to stimulate appetite, and lateral neurons utilize POMC/CART to inhibit appetite.<ref name=":06" /> NPY and POMC/CART neurons are sensitive to peripheral hormones such as leptin and insulin.<ref name=":23" /> POMC/CART neurons also secrete [[melanocyte-stimulating hormone]], which suppresses appetite.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Baltatzi|first1=M|last2=Hatzitolios|first2=A|last3=Tziomalos|first3=K|last4=Iliadis|first4=F|last5=Zamboulis|first5=Ch|title=Neuropeptide Y and alpha-melanocyte-stimulating hormone: interaction in obesity and possible role in the development of hypertension.|journal=International Journal of Clinical Practice|date=September 2008|volume=62|issue=9|pages=1432–40|doi=10.1111/j.1742-1241.2008.01823.x|pmid=18793378}}</ref><ref name=Carlons2012>{{cite book|last1=Carlson|first1=Neil R.|title=Physiology of Behavior Books a La Carte Edition.|date=2012|publisher=Pearson College Div|location=Boston|isbn=978-0-205-23981-8|edition=11th}}</ref>{{rp|419}} * '''GnRH neurons''' have also been found.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":06" /> These neurons secrete GnRH and [[histamine]].<ref name=":06" /> * There are also groups of neurons expressing NKB and [[dynorphin]] that help to control reproduction.<ref name=":06"/>
===Centrally-projecting neurons=== Other types of neurons have projection pathways from the arcuate nucleus to mediate different regions of the hypothalamus or to other regions outside of the hypothalamus.<ref name=":06"/><ref name=":23"/> Projections of these neurons extend a long distance from the arcuate nucleus to the median eminence to influence the release of hormones from the pituitary gland.<ref name=":14"/><ref name=":06"/> Neurons of the arcuate nucleus have intrahypothalamic projections for neuroendrocrine circuitry.<ref name=":14" /> such as neural projections that influence feeding behavior project to the [[Paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus|paraventricular nucleus]] of the hypothalamus (PVH), the [[dorsomedial hypothalamic nucleus]] (DMH, and the [[lateral hypothalamic area]] (LHA).<ref name=":14" /> Populations of neurons connect to the intermediate lobes of the pituitary gland, from the lateral division of the ARH to the neural and intermediate parts of the pituitary gland, and the caudal division of ARH to the median eminence.<ref name=":06"/>
Groups of neurons that project elsewhere within the [[central nervous system]] include: * Centrally projecting neurons that contain [[neuropeptide Y]] (NPY), [[agouti-related protein]] (AGRP), and the inhibitory neurotransmitter [[GABA]]. These neurons, in the most ventromedial part of the nucleus, project strongly to the [[lateral hypothalamus]] and to the [[paraventricular nucleus]] of the hypothalamus, and are important in the regulation of [[appetite]]. When activated, these neurons can produce ravenous eating. These neurons are inhibited by [[leptin]], [[insulin]], and [[peptide YY]] and activated by [[ghrelin]]. * Centrally projecting neurons that contain [[peptide]] products of [[pro-opiomelanocortin]] (POMC), and [[cocaine- and amphetamine-regulated transcript]] (CART). These neurons have widespread projections to many brain areas, including to all nuclei in the hypothalamus. These cells are important in the regulation of [[appetite]], and, when activated, they inhibit feeding. These neurons are activated by circulating concentrations of [[leptin]] and [[insulin]], and they are directly innervated and inhibited by the NPY neurons.<ref>Arora and Anubhuti. Role of neuropeptides in appetite regulation and obesity--a review. Neuropeptides (2006) vol. 40 (6) pp. 375-401</ref> POMC neurons that project to the medial preoptic nucleus are also involved in the regulation of [[Human sexual activity|sexual behavior]] in both males and females. The expression of POMC is regulated by gonadal steroids. The release of a POMC product, beta-endorphin is regulated by NPY. * Centrally projecting neurons that make somatostatin; the neurosecretory somatostatin neurons that regulate growth hormone secretion are a different population, located in the periventricular nucleus. * Feeding regulatory neurons also activate oxytocin-containing neurons of the [[periventricular nucleus]] (PVN), which projects to nucleus of [[Tractus solitarius]] in the [[medulla oblongata]].<ref name=":06"/> * Others receive direct synaptic inputs from extra hypothalamic sites projecting into the [[amygdala]], the [[hippocampus]], and the [[entorhinal cortex]].<ref name=":06"/>
===Other neurons === Other cell populations include: * A small population of neurons that sensitive to [[ghrelin]]. The role of this population is not known; many neurons in the arcuate nucleus express receptors for ghrelin, but these are thought to respond mainly to blood-borne ghrelin. * The arcuate nucleus also contains a population of specialized [[ependymal cells]], called [[tanycytes]]. * Astrocytes in the arcuate nucleus hold high capacity glucose transporters that function as nutrient sensors for appetite controlling neurons<ref name=":06"/> * The diverse and specialized collections of neurons reside within a special compartment with [[glial cells]] and have their own network of [[Capillary|capillaries]] and a membrane of [[tanycyte]]s that help create a blood brain barrier.<ref name=":06"/> Circulating or molecules such as hormones travel in the blood and can directly affect these neurons and their plasticity as evidence by adult neurogenesis.<ref name=":06" />
== References == <references/>
==Footnotes== * {{cite journal |author=Kawano H, Daikoku S |title=Somatostatin-containing neuron systems in the rat hypothalamus: retrograde tracing and immunohistochemical studies |journal=J. Comp. {{Diencephalon}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Arcuate Nucleus}} [[Category:Hypothalamus]] [[Category:Neuroendocrinology]] [[Category:Human female endocrine system]]

{{Hypnosis|key}} '''Theodore Xenophon Barber''' (1927–2005)<ref name="Pearce2005-09-23">{{cite news | last = Pearce | first = Jeremy | date = September 23, 2005 | title = Theodore Barber Dies at 78; Was Major Critic of Hypnosis | work = [[The New York Times]] | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/23/national/23barber.html | accessdate = 20 January 2010 }}</ref> and '''David Smith Calverley''' (1937–2008)<ref name="CapeCodTimes2008-03-22">{{cite news|date=March 22, 2008 |title=David S. Calverley, 71 |work=[[Cape Cod Times]] |url=http://www.capecodonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080322/OBITS/803220333/-1/rss13 |accessdate=20 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617045539/http://www.capecodonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20080322%2FOBITS%2F803220333%2F-1%2Frss13 |archivedate=17 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> were American [[psychologist]]s who studied "hypnotic behaviour". They measured how susceptible patients were to [[Hypnosis|hypnotic induction]]. One result of their research was showing that the hypnotic induction was not superior to motivational instructions in producing a heightened state of suggestibility.<ref name="Pearce2005-09-23" /> The Barber Suggestibility Scale, a product of their research, measures [[hypnotic susceptibility]] with or without the use of a hypnotic induction.<ref name="Pearce2005-09-23" />
Barber was the author of ''Hypnosis: A Scientific Approach'' (1969).<ref>[http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2005-09-25/news/0509240274_1_hypnosis-hypnotism-social-psychology "Theodore Barber, 78, Hypnosis Opponent"]. SunSentinel.</ref> He argued in this work that [[hypnosis]] and related constructs are "unnecessary and misleading and that the phenomena that have been traditionally subsumed under these terms can be better understood by utilizing a different set of concepts that are an integral part of present-day psychology."<ref>Hilgard, Ernest R. (1970). ''Barber, Theodore X. Hypnosis: A Scientific Approach''. ''[[American Journal of Clinical Hypnosis]]'' 12: 272-274.</ref> It was positively reviewed by the [[scientific community]].<ref>Edwards, Griffith. (1970). ''Hypnosis: A Scientific Approach''. ''[[British Journal of Psychiatry]]'' 117: 591.</ref><ref>Bernstein, Norman R. (1971). ''Hypnosis: A Scientific Approach''. ''Anesthesia Progress'' 18: 18-19.</ref> Psychologist [[Theodore R. Sarbin]] noted that the work "demystifies and demythologizes" the subject, "the construction of hypnosis as a special mental state ha[s] no ontological footing."<ref>Sarbin, Theodore R. (1997). Barber, Theodore X. (1995/1969). ''Hypnosis: A Scientific Approach''. ''[[American Journal of Clinical Hypnosis]]'' 39: 225-227.</ref>
Barber was a fellow of the [[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry|Committee for Skeptical Inquiry (CSI)]].<ref>[http://www.csicop.org/specialarticles/show/in-memoriam_segment_from_csicon_2016 "In-Memoriam Segment from CSICON 2016"]. Skeptical Inquirer.</ref> At a meeting of the executive council of CSI in [[Denver]], [[Colorado]] in April 2011, Barber was selected for inclusion in CSI's Pantheon of Skeptics. The Pantheon of Skeptics was created by CSI to remember the legacy of deceased fellows of CSI and their contributions to the cause of scientific skepticism.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Pantheon of Skeptics|url=http://www.csicop.org/about/the_pantheon_of_skeptics|website=CSI|publisher=[[Committee for Skeptical Inquiry]]|accessdate=30 April 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131054129/http://www.csicop.org/about/the_pantheon_of_skeptics|archivedate=31 January 2017|dead-url=no}}</ref>
==Publications==
'''Theodore Xenophon Barber'''
*''Hypnosis: A Scientific Approach'' (1969) *''LSD, Marihuana, Yoga and Hypnosis'' (1970) *''Biofeedback and Self-Control'' (1971) *''Hypnosis, Imagination, and Human Potentialities'' (1974) [with [[Nicholas Spanos]] and John F. Graves] *''Advances in Altered States of Consciousness & Human Potentialities'' (1976) *''The Human Nature of Birds: A Scientific Discovery with Startling Implications'' (1994)

revision.text:
[[File:US-DeptOfHHS-Logo.svg|right|180px]] The '''Children's Health Insurance Program''' ('''CHIP''')<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.medicaid.gov/Medicaid-CHIP-Program-Information/By-Topics/Childrens-Health-Insurance-Program-CHIP/Childrens-Health-Insurance-Program-CHIP.html | title=Children's Health Insurance Program | publisher=[[United States Department of Health and Human Services]] | accessdate=July 29, 2009}}</ref> – formerly known as the '''State Children's Health Insurance Program''' ('''SCHIP''') – is a program administered by the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]] that provides [[matching funds]] to states for [[health insurance]] to families with children.<ref>Sultz, H., & Young, K. Health Care USA Understanding its Organization and Delivery pg. 257</ref> The program was designed to cover uninsured children in families with incomes that are modest but too high to qualify for [[Medicaid]].
The program came in response to the failure of [[Clinton health care plan of 1993|comprehensive health care reform proposed in 1993]] by President [[Bill Clinton]]. The legislation to create it was sponsored by Senator [[Ted Kennedy]] in a partnership with Senator [[Orrin Hatch]],<ref name="Hatch Joins Kennedy">{{cite news | first=Robert | last=Pear | title= Hatch Joins Kennedy to Back a Health Program | date=1997-03-14 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/14/us/hatch-joins-kennedy-to-back-a-health-program.html | work =The New York Times | accessdate = 2008-01-06 | language = }}</ref> with support coming from First Lady [[Hillary Clinton]] during the [[Clinton administration]].<ref name="ap100507">{{cite news | url=http://www.newsmax.com/insidecover/hillary_health_care/2007/10/05/38601.html | title=Hillary Claims Credit for Child Program | agency=[[Associated Press]] for [[NewsMax]] | author=Beth Fouhy | date=2007-10-05 | accessdate=2007-10-07 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080123174618/http://www.newsmax.com/insidecover/hillary_health_care/2007/10/05/38601.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-01-23}}</ref><ref name="time031308"/><ref name="fc031808"/> At its creation in 1997, SCHIP was the largest expansion of taxpayer-funded health insurance coverage for children in the U.S. since{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} [[Lyndon Johnson]] established Medicaid in 1965.<ref>{{cite web |work=Politico |title=President Johnson signs Medicare bill on July 30, 1965 <!-- |authorlink=Andrew Glass --> |first=Andrew |last=Glass |date=July 30, 2007 |accessdate=2013-09-08 |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0707/5129.html}}</ref> The statutory authority for CHIP is under title XXI of the [[Social Security Act]].
States are given flexibility in designing their CHIP eligibility requirements and policies within broad federal guidelines. Some states have received authority through waivers of statutory provisions to use CHIP funds to cover the parents of children receiving benefits from both CHIP and Medicaid, [[pregnant]] women, and other adults. CHIP covered 7.6 million children during federal fiscal year 2010, and every state has an approved plan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.medicaid.gov/Medicaid-CHIP-Program-Information/By-Topics/Childrens-Health-Insurance-Program-CHIP/Downloads/2010_enrollment_datapdf.pdf |title=FY 2010 Number of Children Ever Enrolled in Medicaid and CHIP |accessdate=2013-04-03 |format=PDF }}</ref> Despite CHIP, the number of uninsured children continued to rise, particularly among families that cannot qualify for CHIP. An October 2007 study by the Vimo Research Group found that 68.7 percent of newly uninsured children were in families whose incomes were 200 percent of the [[Poverty in the United States|federal poverty level]] or higher as more employers dropped dependents or dropped coverage altogether due to annual premiums nearly doubling between 2000 and 2006. Vimo cites the Kaiser Commission on Medicaid and the Uninsured when it says 48 percent of the newly uninsured were not eligible for any kind of public coverage, and that only those in the lowest income bracket might offset the loss of employer-sponsored coverage with increases in Medicaid and SCHIP.<ref name="Uninsured In America">{{cite web |url=http://www.vimo.com/reports/uninsured.pdf |title=The Uninsured In America |accessdate=2008-01-06 |last=Espe |first=Erik |date=October 2007 |format=PDF |publisher=Vimo Research Group |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627024709/http://www.vimo.com/reports/uninsured.pdf |archivedate=2013-06-27 |df= }} Obtain a .</ref> In FY 2008, the program faced funding shortfalls in several states.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kff.org/medicaid/upload/7635.pdf |title=President's FY 2008 Budget and the State Children's Health Insurance Program (SCHIP) |accessdate=2007-07-03 |format=PDF |work=Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation }}</ref>
Two attempts to expand funding for the program were vetoed by President [[George W. Bush]], who argued that such efforts were steps toward federalization of health care, and would "steer the program away from its core purpose of providing insurance for poor children and toward covering children from middle-class families."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/03/washington/03cnd-veto.html|author1=David Stout |title=Bush Vetoes Children's Health Bill |work=The New York Times| accessdate=2009-01-08 | date=2007-10-03}}</ref> On February 4, 2009, President [[Barack Obama]] signed the Children's Health Insurance Reauthorization Act of 2009, expanding the healthcare program to an additional 4 million children and pregnant women, including “lawfully residing” immigrants without a waiting period.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nilc.org/ICHIA-facts-2010-08-06.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-12-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120618171105/http://www.nilc.org/ICHIA-facts-2010-08-06.html |archivedate=2012-06-18 |df= }}</ref>
A 2018 survey of the existing research noted that the availability of "CHIP coverage for children has led to improvements in access to health care and to improvements in health over both the short-run and the long-run."<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://econofact.org/filling-in-the-gap-of-childrens-health-insurance-coverage-medicaid-and-chip|title=CHIP and Medicaid: Filling in the Gap in Children's Health Insurance Coverage. {{!}} Econofact|date=2018-01-22|work=Econofact|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
As of February 2018, the CHIP program has been authorized to continue through the year 2027.
==History== {{hus}} The Children's Health Insurance Program grew out of years of work in the [[U.S. Congress]] to improve Americans' health coverage. Almost a decade prior, the [[U.S. Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care]] was formed in 1989 and charged with recommending “legislative action to ensure coverage for all Americans.” The Commission, renamed the Pepper Commission in honor of its creator and first chair Representative Claude Pepper (D-Fla.), laid out a blueprint to achieve universal coverage. Given the challenges of comprehensive health reform, Governor [[Jay Rockefeller]], who was elected chair following Rep. Pepper's death, emphasized his commitment to pursue legislative action not only on the commission's full set of recommendations but also on a "down payment" — to expand public health coverage immediately for children and pregnant women, consistent with the principles the commission put forward. The legislation would guarantee public insurance coverage through Medicaid for every American child living in poverty and offset the cost of the improvements by doubling the federal excise tax on cigarettes.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rockefeller|first1=John|title=The Pepper Commission Report on Comprehensive Health Care|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=October 4, 1990|doi=10.1056/NEJM199010043231429|url=http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199010043231429#t=article|accessdate=6 September 2017}} {{PD-notice}}</ref>
Quickly after his election in 1992, President [[Bill Clinton]] assembled a task force to write a comprehensive health reform bill, and he worked with Congress to introduce the Health Security Act (HSA) in November 1993. It included provisions such as universal coverage and a basic benefit package, health insurance reform, and consumer choice of health plans.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Plaut|first1=TF|last2=Arons|first2=BS|title=President Clinton's proposal for health care reform: key provisions and issues|journal=Hosp Community Psychiatry|date=September 1994|volume=45|issue=9|pages=871–876|accessdate=}}</ref>
After the HSA failed in the fall of 1994, congressional leaders and the administration recognized the need for an incremental, bipartisan approach to health care reform.<ref>{{cite news|title=THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: IN THEIR OWN WORDS; Why Health Care Fizzled: Too Little Time and Too Much Politics|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/27/us/health-care-debate-their-own-words-why-health-care-fizzled-too-little-time-too.html|accessdate=6 September 2017|agency=The New York Times|date=September 27, 1994}}</ref> Senator [[Jay Rockefeller]] continued to argue for expanded coverage for children. He referenced an amendment for accelerated coverage children and pregnant women offered during the Senate Finance Committee’s health care reform markup that was adopted by a bipartisan majority of 12 to 8 as evidence that there was bipartisan support to provide assistance to children. He also went on to say expanding coverage for children was essential to reforming the welfare system to “prevent families from having to go and off welfare to qualify for Medicaid.”<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rockefeller|first1=John D.|title=Moving Ahead With Health Care System Reform|journal=JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association|date=18 January 1995|volume=273|issue=3|pages=250|doi=10.1001/jama.1995.03520270086044}}</ref>
The 1996 Bipartisan Budget Agreement made net reductions in federal Medicaid spending over a five-year period but anticipated an additional $16 billion in spending on children's health care over the same period. However, it did not provide details on how that money would be spent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Medicaid and Child Health Provisions of the Bipartisan Budget Agreement|url=https://www.cbpp.org/archives/mcaidbud.htm|website=Center on Budget and Policy Priorities|accessdate=6 September 2017}}</ref> In 1997, several members of Congress introduced bills to cover uninsured children using that $16 billion, and the two most popular proposals were the Chafee-Rockefeller proposal and the Kennedy-Hatch proposal.
Senator [[Ted Kennedy]], Chairman of the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions (HELP) was intrigued by a children's health insurance plan in Massachusetts that had passed in 1996, and met with a [[Boston Medical Center]] pediatrics director and a [[Massachusetts state legislator]] to discuss the feasibility of a national initiative.<ref name="bg031408">{{cite news | url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2008/03/14/clinton_role_in_health_program_disputed/?page=full | title=Clinton role in health program disputed | author=Susan Milligan | work=[[The Boston Globe]] | date=2008-03-14 | accessdate=2008-03-15}}</ref> Kennedy also saw using an increase in [[sin tax|tobacco taxes]] as a way to pay for the expanded coverage.<ref name="bg031408"/> Thus, in October 1996, Kennedy introduced a bill to provide health care coverage for children of the working poor, to be financed via a 75 cents a pack cigarette tax increase.<ref name="time031308">{{cite magazine | url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1721966,00.html | title=Assessing Clinton's "Experience": Children's Health Care |author1=Karen Tumulty |author2=Michael Duffy |author3=Massimo Calabresi |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date=2008-03-13 | accessdate=2008-03-17}}</ref>
Kennedy brought Republican Senator [[Orrin Hatch]] onto the legislation as a co-sponsor. Kennedy and Hatch had worked together as an "odd couple" in the Senate before, and here Hatch said that "Children are being terribly hurt and perhaps scarred for the rest of their lives" and that "as a nation, as a society, we have a moral responsibility" to provide coverage. Hatch's role would infuriate some Republican colleagues and conservative commentators.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pear|first1=Robert|title=Hatch Joins Kennedy to Back a Health Program|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/14/us/hatch-joins-kennedy-to-back-a-health-program.html?mcubz=0|website=The New York Times}}</ref>
On April 8, 1997, Senators Kennedy and Hatch introduced S. 525, the “Child Health Insurance and Lower Deficit Act (CHILD).<ref>{{cite web|title=S.525 - Child Health Insurance and Lower Deficit Act|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/105th-congress/senate-bill/525?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22S.+525%5C%22Child+Health+Insurance+and+Lower+Deficit+Act%5C%22%22%5D%7D&r=1|website=Congress.gov}}</ref> This legislation amended the Public Health Service Act to create a new grant program for states to purchase private health insurance for children. It proposed to raise $30 billion over 5 years by raising the tobacco tax with $20 billion going to expanded coverage for children under a block grant approach and $10 billion for deficit reduction. S. 525 was referred to the Senate Health Education Labor and Pensions (HELP) Committee. Hearings were held on the bill in the HELP Committee but legislation to expand coverage for children was never acted on in the HELP Committee.
On April 30, 1997, Senators [[John Chafee]] (R-RI) and [[Jay Rockefeller]] (D-WVa.) introduced S. 674, a bill to amend title XIX of the Social Security Act “to expand health coverage of low income children and pregnant women and to provide funds to promote outreach efforts to enroll eligible children.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Children's Health Insurance Provides Security (CHIPS) Act|url=https://www.congress.gov/congressional-record/1997/5/1/senate-section/article/s3926-2?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22children%27s+health+rockefeller%22%5D%7D&r=1|website=The Congressional Record}}</ref> On the same day, Representative [[John Dingell]] (D-MI) introduced an identical bipartisan companion bill in the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] with Republican cosponsor, Representative Margaret Scafati Roukema (R-NJ).<ref>{{cite journal|title=Children’s Health Insurance Provides Security (CHIPS) Act (H.R 1491)|journal=The Congressional Record|date=April 30, 1997|volume=143|issue=54|page=H2089|url=https://www.congress.gov/congressional-record/1997/04/30/house-section/article/H2089-4}}</ref>
{{Bill Clinton series}} {{Hillary Clinton series}} Meanwhile, in December 1996 First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton examined several possible initiatives and decided expanding health care insurance to children who had none was the one to advance,<ref name="ap100507"/> especially as its focus on children would be politically popular.<ref name="time031308"/> This had precedents from earlier in the Clinton administration: a different variant of this approach, dubbed "Kids First", had been envisioned as a backup plan during the original 1993 Task Force on National Health Care Reform meetings.<ref name="fc031808">{{cite news | url=http://www.factcheck.org/elections-2008/giving_hillary_credit_for_schip.html | title=Giving Hillary Credit for SCHIP | author=Brooks Jackson | publisher=[[FactCheck.org]] | date=2008-03-18 | accessdate=2008-03-19 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080322032750/http://www.factcheck.org/elections-2008/giving_hillary_credit_for_schip.html | archivedate=2008-03-22 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.aapsonline.org/newsletters/jan96.htm | title=Clinton Care Through the Kitchen Door | publisher=[[Association of American Physicians and Surgeons]] | date=January 1996 | accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref> Additionally, Hillary Clinton had discussed an SCHIP-like program with a White House health policy coordinator during the time her full-blown health care plan had suffered political failure.<ref name="wapo032408">{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/03/23/AR2008032301706.html?sid=ST2008032401106 | title=Both Obama And Clinton Embellish Their Roles | author=Shailagh Murray | author2= Jonathan Weisman | newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] | date=2008-03-24 | accessdate=2008-03-24}}</ref>
The new initiative was proposed at Bill Clinton's January 1997 [[State of the Union address]], with the stated goal of coverage up to five million children.<ref name="ap100507"/><ref name="time031308"/> Kennedy continued to write much of the bill, using the increase in tobacco taxes to pay the $20 billion price tag.<ref name="Hatch Joins Kennedy"/> In March 1997, Kennedy brought Republican Senator Orrin Hatch onto the legislation as co-sponsor; Kennedy and Hatch had worked together as an "odd couple" in the Senate before, and here Hatch said that "Children are being terribly hurt and perhaps scarred for the rest of their lives" and that "as a nation, as a society, we have a moral responsibility" to provide coverage.<ref name="Hatch Joins Kennedy"/> Hatch's role would infuriate some Republican colleagues<ref name="time042197"/><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.slate.com/id/2095803/ | title=Sen. Orrin Hatch | author=[[Michael Crowley (journalist)|Michael Crowley]] | publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] | date=2004-02-20 | accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref> and [[American conservatism|conservative commentators]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.eagleforum.org/column/1997/mar97/97-03-25.html | title=Orrin Hatch Turns Out To Be A Latter Day Liberal | author=[[Phyllis Schlafly]] | publisher=[[Eagle Forum]] | date=1997-03-25 | accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref> The First Lady did not hold news conferences or testify before Congress on behalf of the bill.<ref name="wapo032408"/>
An initial objection of Republicans in the Senate was that proposing to pay for the services by raising the federal tax on cigarettes, from 24 cents a pack to 67 cents a pack, ignored the likely consequence that sale of tobacco products would decrease and tax revenues would increasingly fall short of those needed to pay for the expansion of benefits.<ref name="nyt052197">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/21/us/child-insurance-bill-opposed-as-threat-to-cigarette-revenue.html | title= Child Insurance Bill Opposed As Threat to Cigarette Revenue | author=[[Adam Clymer]] | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=1997-05-21 | accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref> Kennedy and Hatch scoffed at the objection, with the former saying, "If we can keep people healthy and stop them from dying, I think most Americans would say 'Amen; isn't that a great result?' If fewer people smoke, states will save far more in lower health costs than they will lose in revenues from the cigarette tax."<ref name="nyt052197"/> Republicans also criticized the bill as an open-ended [[entitlement program]], although it was structured as a [[block grant]] rather than an entitlement;<ref name="nyt052197"/> Senate Majority Leader [[Trent Lott]] was an early opponent of the measure, calling it a "big-government program" that would not pass.<ref name="time042197">{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,986210,00.html | title=Hatching Mischief | author=James Carney | publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date=1997-04-21 | accessdate=2008-01-22}}</ref>
Then the bill had to comply with the existing balanced budget agreement between Congress and the White House, something that Lott said it did not.<ref name="ap100507"/> Pressure was on to reduce the amount of grants involved, with $16 billion a possible compromise; Hillary Clinton instead argued for $24 billion.<ref name="ap100507"/><ref name="fc031808"/> The Clinton administration had a deal with the Republican leadership in Congress that forbade the administration from backing any amendments to the budget resolution.<ref name="bg031408"/> Thus, Bill Clinton phoned members of Congress and asked that they kill the children's health insurance provision when it came to the floor.<ref name="ap100507"/> On May 22, it was so done, with the necessary cigarette tax amendment defeated by a 55–45 margin.<ref name="nyt052297">{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/us/clinton-helps-kill-proposal-to-raise-tax-on-cigarettes.html | title=Clinton Helps Kill Proposal to Raise Tax on Cigarettes | author=[[Adam Clymer]] | date=1997-05-22 | accessdate=2008-03-17 | work=The New York Times}}</ref> Hillary Clinton defended her husband's action at the time, saying "He had to safeguard the overall budget proposal,"<ref name="ap100507"/> but Kennedy was surprised and angered by it,<ref name="bg031408"/> considering it a betrayal,<ref name="time031308"/> and saying that his calls to Bill Clinton and Vice President [[Al Gore]] had not been returned.<ref name="nyt052297"/> Hatch was also upset, saying that Lott may have been bluffing and that, "I think the President and the people in the White House caved here."<ref name="nyt052297"/>
Kennedy did not give up on the measure, saying: "We shall offer it again and again until we prevail. It's more important to protect children than to protect the tobacco industry."<ref name="nyt052297"/> Both Bill and Hillary Clinton argued for including the children's health insurance in subsequent legislation.<ref name="bg031408"/> The bill was indeed revived by Kennedy and Hatch a month after its initial defeat.<ref name="time031308"/> Organizations from the [[Children's Defense Fund]] to the [[Girl Scouts of the USA]] lobbied for its passage, putting public pressure on Congress;<ref name="time031308"/> Hillary Clinton was pushing for it as well,<ref name="ap100507"/> with Kennedy urging her to use her influence within the White House.<ref name="time031308"/> SCHIP was then passed and signed into law by Bill Clinton on August 5, 1997<ref name="ap100507"/> as part of the [[Balanced Budget Act of 1997]], to take effect the following month.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/21/us/states-to-give-more-children-health-coverage.html | title= States to Give More Children Health Coverage | author=Peter T. Kilborn | work=The New York Times | date=1997-09-21 | accessdate=2008-01-21}}</ref> At a press conference following the signing, Kennedy thanked Hatch, Senate Minority Leader [[Tom Daschle]], Children's Defense Fund head [[Marian Wright Edelman]], Bill Clinton, and Hillary Clinton.<ref name="fc031808"/> About the last, Kennedy said, "Mrs. Clinton ... was of invaluable help, both in the fashioning and the shaping of the program and also as a clear advocate."<ref name="time031308"/>
SCHIP is located at Title IV, subtitle J of H.R. 2015 [105th] [[Balanced Budget Act of 1997]]. H.R. 2015 was introduced and sponsored by Rep John Kasich [R-OH] with no cosponsors.<ref>[http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h105-2015 H.R. 2015 [105th]: Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (GovTrack.us)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> On 25 June 1997, H.R. 2015 passed House Vote Roll #241 mainly among partisan lines, 270 ayes and 162 nays, with most Democrats in the House of Representatives in opposition. On the same day, the bill passed in the Senate, with a substitute amendment, by unanimous consent. After a conference between the House and Senate, passage in both House (Roll #345: 346-85) and Senate (Roll #209: 85-15) on the conference substitute became more bipartisan.
== {{Visible anchor|State administration}} ==<!-- Other articles link here. --> Like Medicaid, SCHIP is a partnership between federal and state governments. The programs are run by the individual states according to requirements set by the federal [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]]. States may design their SCHIP programs as an independent program separate from Medicaid (separate child health programs), use SCHIP funds to expand their Medicaid program (SCHIP Medicaid expansion programs), or combine these approaches (SCHIP combination programs). States receive enhanced federal funds for their SCHIP programs at a rate above the regular Medicaid match.
By February 1999, 47 states had set up SCHIP programs, but it took effort to get children enrolled.<ref name="fc031808"/> That month, the Clinton administration launched the "Insure Kids Now" campaign, designed to get more children enrolled;<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.clintonfoundation.org/legacy/022399-fact-sheet-on-insure-kids-now-campaign.htm | title=President Clinton and First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton Launch the [Insure Kids Now Campaign]http://www.insurekidsnow.gov Promoting Children's Health Insurance Outreach | date=1999-02-23 | accessdate=2008-03-19}}</ref> the campaign would fall under the aegis of the [[Health Resources and Services Administration]]. By April 1999, some 1 million children had been enrolled, and the Clinton administration set a goal of raising the figure to 2.5 million by 2000.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.clintonpresidentialcenter.org/legacy/042099-hrc-announces-child-health-insurance-enrollment.htm | title=First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton Announces That Almost One Million Children Are Enrolled in the Children's Health Insurance Program | date=1999-04-20 | accessdate=2008-03-19}}</ref>
States with separate child health programs follow the regulations described in Section 42 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Section 457. Separate child health programs have much more flexibility than Medicaid programs. Separate programs can impose cost sharing, tailor their benefit packages, and employ a great deal of flexibility in eligibility and enrollment matters. The limits to this flexibility are described in the regulations, and states must describe their program characteristics in their SCHIP state plans. Out of 50 state governors, 43 support SCHIP renewal.<ref>[http://www.americanprogress.org/issues/2007/10/schip_numbers.html Overriding the SCHIP Veto by the Numbers] Center for American Progress.</ref> Some states have incorporated the use of private companies to administer portions of their SCHIP benefits. These programs, typically referred to as [[Medicaid managed care]], allow private insurance companies or health maintenance organizations to contract directly with a state Medicaid department at a fixed price per enrollee. The health plans then enroll eligible individuals into their programs and become responsible for assuring SCHIP benefits are delivered to eligible beneficiaries.
In [[Ohio]], SCHIP funds are used to expand eligibility for the state's Medicaid program. Thus all Medicaid rules and regulations (including cost sharing and benefits) apply. Children from birth through age 18 who live in families with incomes above the Medicaid thresholds in 1996 and up to 200% of the federal poverty level are eligible for the SCHIP Medicaid expansion program. In 2008, the maximum annual income needed for a family of four to fall within 100% of the federal poverty guidelines was $21,200, while 200% of the poverty guidelines was $42,400.<ref>Federal Register, Vol. 73, No. 15, January 23, 2008, pp. 3971-3972. Also see [http://aspe.hhs.gov/poverty/index.shtml "US Department of Health and Human Services Poverty Guidelines"]</ref>
Other states have similar SCHIP guidelines, with some states being more generous or restrictive in the number of children they allow into the program.<ref>[http://ccf.georgetown.edu/index/medicaid-and-schip-programs "Medicaid and SCHIP Program Eligibility Rules by State"]</ref> With the exception of Alaska, Idaho, North Dakota and Oklahoma, all states have a minimum threshold for coverage at 200% of the federal poverty guidelines. North Dakota currently has the lowest at 175%. New York currently has the highest at 405% of the federal poverty guidelines.<ref>[https://singlemotherguide.com/medicaid-chip-eligibility/ State Medicaid and CHIP Eligibility Guidelines]</ref> SCHIP Medicaid expansion programs typically use the same names for the expansion and Medicaid programs. Separate child health programs typically have different names for their programs. A few states also call the SCHIP program by the term "Children's Health Insurance Program" (CHIP).
States are allowed to use Medicaid and SCHIP funds for premium assistance programs that help eligible individuals purchase private health insurance. As of 2008 relatively few states had premium assistance programs, and enrollment was relatively low. Interest in this approach remained high, however.<ref>Joan Alker, [http://www.kff.org/medicaid/upload/7782.pdf "Choosing Premium Assistance: What Does State Experience Tell Us?"], The [[Kaiser Family Foundation]], May 2008</ref>
In August 2007, the Bush Administration announced a rule requiring states (as of August 2008) to sign up 95% of families with children earning 200% of the federal poverty level, before using the funds to serve families earning more than 250% of the federal poverty level. The federal government said that 9 out the 17 states that offer benefits to higher-earning families were already compliant. Opponents of this rule argued that signing up higher-income families makes lower-income families more likely to sign up, and that the rule was incompassionate toward children who would otherwise go without medical insurance.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=89521878 Proposal Favoring SCHIP's Poorest Kids Criticized]</ref>
===Implementations=== * California: [[California Healthy Families Program]] * Utah: [[State Children's Health Insurance Program in Utah]]
==Impact== A 2018 survey of the existing research noted that the availability of "CHIP coverage for children has led to improvements in access to health care and to improvements in health over both the short-run and the long-run."<ref name=":1" />
In 2007, researchers from [[Brigham Young University]] and [[Arizona State University|Arizona State]] found that children who drop out of SCHIP cost states more money because they shift away from routine care to more frequent [[emergency room|emergency care]] situations.<ref name="Impacts Medicaid disenrollment">{{cite journal |vauthors=Rimsza ME, Butler RJ, Johnson WG | title = Impact of Medicaid disenrollment on health care use and cost | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 119 | issue = 5 | pages = e1026–32 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17473075 | doi = 10.1542/peds.2006-2747 | url = http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17473075 | issn = | accessdate = 2008-01-05}} </ref> The conclusion of the study is that an attempt to cut the costs of a state healthcare program could create a false savings because other government organizations pick up the tab for the children who lose insurance coverage and later need care.
In a 2007 analysis by the [[Congressional Budget Office]], researchers determined that "for every 100 children who gain coverage as a result of SCHIP, there is a corresponding reduction in private coverage of between 25 and 50 children." The CBO speculates this is because the state programs offer better benefits at lower cost to enrollees than the private alternatives.<ref name="CBO">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbo.gov/ftpdocs/80xx/doc8092/05-10-SCHIP.pdf|title=The State Children's Health Insurance Program|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|date=2007-05-10|accessdate=2007-10-16|format=PDF}}</ref> A briefing paper by libertarian think-tank [[Cato Institute]] estimated the "crowding out" of private insurers by the public program could be as much as 60%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cato.org/pubs/bp/html/bp99/bp9900006.html|title=Sinking SCHIP: A first step toward stopping the growth of government health programs|author=Michael F. Cannon|accessdate=2007-10-04}}</ref>
== Reauthorization == SCHIP was created in 1997 as a ten-year program; to continue past federal fiscal year 2007, passage of a reauthorization bill was required. The first two reauthorization bills to pass through Congress would also expand the program's scope; President [[George W. Bush]] vetoed them as improper expansions. A two-year reauthorization bill was signed into law by the President in December 2007 that would merely extend current SCHIP services without expanding any portion of the program. With the 2008 Presidential and Congressional elections giving Democrats control of the Oval Office as well as expanded majorities in both houses of Congress, SCHIP was reauthorized and expanded in the same bill through fiscal year 2013.
===2007 reauthorization===
====HR 976==== In 2007, both houses of Congress passed a bipartisan measure to expand the SCHIP program, {{USBill|110|H.R.|976}}. The measure would have expanded coverage to over 4 million more participants by 2012, while phasing out most state expansions in the program that include any adults other than pregnant women. The bill called for a budget increase for five years totaling $35 billion, increasing total SCHIP spending to $60 billion for the five-year period. Opposition to HR 976 focused on the $35 billion increase in government health insurance as well as $6.5 billion in Medicaid benefits to illegal immigrants. Originally intended to provide health care coverage to low-income children, HR 976 was criticized as a giveaway that would have benefited adults as well as non-U.S. citizens.<ref>[http://aderholt.house.gov/?sectionid=20&sectiontree=6,20&itemid=649 Congressman Robert B. Aderholt : News Releases : Aderholt Opposes $35 Billion Expansion of Government Health Insurance: SCHIP Bill Includes $6.5 Billion Giveaway For Illegal Immigrants<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.virginiafoxx.com/political_posturing_obscures_the.htm Political posturing obscures the issue Insuring health care for poor children should be highest priority as Congress votes By Rep<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080708192026/http://www.virginiafoxx.com/political_posturing_obscures_the.htm |date=2008-07-08 }}</ref><ref name="More SCHIP: Revived">{{cite news | first= J| last= Galloway|author2=Kemper B | title=More SCHIP: Revived but already dead | date=2007-09-21 | url =http://www.ajc.com/metro/content/shared-blogs/ajc/politicalinsider/entries/2007/09/21/more_schip_revived_but_already.html | work =The Atlanta Journal-Constitution | accessdate = 2008-01-06 | language = }}</ref><ref name="White House: Health Care">{{cite web |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/infocus/healthcare/ |title=''Health Care'' |accessdate=2007-10-04 |format=webpage |publisher=''whitehouse.gov'' }}</ref><ref name="FactCheck.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.factcheck.org/bushs_false_claims_about_childrens_health_insurance.html |title=''Bush's False Claims About Children's Health Insurance'' |accessdate=2007-10-10 |format=webpage |publisher=''FactCheck.org''}}</ref> The program expansion was to have been funded by sharply increasing federal excise taxes on tobacco products.<ref name="GovTrack">{{cite web |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/billtext.xpd?bill=h110-976 |title=''GovTrack: H.R. 976: Text of Legislation'' |accessdate=2007-12-24 |format=webpage |publisher=''GovTrack'' }}</ref> On the other hand, opponents said this proposed expansion was for families with annual incomes up to $82,600 (400 percent of the federal poverty level)<ref name="Citizen Feb 2009 Game Plan">{{cite journal |first=John |last=Paulton |date=February 2009 |title=Game Plan |journal=Citizen |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=36–37 |issn=1084-6832}}</ref>
On October 3, 2007, President Bush vetoed the bill,<ref name="Bush Veto">{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21111931/ |title=''Bush vetoes child health insurance plan'' |accessdate=2007-10-03 |format=webpage |publisher=''MSNBC''}}</ref> stating that he believed it would "federalize health care", expanding the scope of SCHIP much farther than its original intent.<ref name="Washington Post Veto page">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/03/AR2007100300116.html?hpid=topnews |title=''Bush Vetoes Children's Health Insurance Plan'' |last=Abramowitz |first=Michael |date=2007-10-03 |publisher=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/09/20070928-9.html |title=Excerpt of President's Radio Address on SCHIP Legislation |date=September 28, 2007 |publisher=White House}}</ref> The veto was the fourth of his administration.<ref name="Washington Post Veto page" /> After his veto, Bush said he was open to a compromise that would entail more than the $5 billion originally budgeted, but would not agree to any proposal drastically expanding the number of children eligible for coverage.<ref>{{cite news | last =Stolberg | first =Sheryl Gay |author2=Carl Hulse | title =Bush Vetoes Child Health Bill Privately | work=The New York Times | date =2007-10-04 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/04/washington/04bush.html?_r=1&th=&adxnnl=1&oref=slogin&emc=th&adxnnlx=1191499205-V0SMbWtwnr6woUuLB3vhZA | accessdate =2007-12-08}}</ref>
On October 18, 2007, the House of Representatives fell 13 votes short (273–156) of the two-thirds majority required to override the president's veto, although 44 Republicans joined 229 Democrats in supporting the measure.<ref name="House override attempt">{{cite web |url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2007/roll982.xml |title=Final Vote Results for Roll Call 982 |publisher=U.S. House of Representatives |accessdate=2007-10-18 |format=webpage}}</ref>
====HR 3963==== Within a week of the failed veto override vote, the House passed a second bill attempting a similar expansion of SCHIP. According to Democrats, the second bill, {{USBill|110|H.R.|3963}}, created firmer caps on income eligibility, prevented adults from joining, and banned children of illegal immigrants from receiving benefits. According to its opponents, however, this second proposed expansion was for families with annual incomes up to $62,000 (300 percent of the federal poverty level).<ref name="Citizen Feb 2009 Game Plan" /> The Senate passed the measure on November 1, 2007, but on December 12, 2007, Bush vetoed this bill as well, saying it was "essentially identical" to the earlier legislation,<ref>{{cite news |title=President Bush vetoes child health bill again|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/POLITICS/12/12/bush.schip/?iref=mpstoryview|work= |publisher=CNN |date=2007-12-13 |accessdate=2007-12-14 }}</ref> and a House vote in January 2008 failed to override the veto.
{{USPL|110|173}}, which extended SCHIP funding through March 31, 2009, and the President signed it into law on December 21, 2007.
=== 2009 reauthorization === [[File:Dingell joins Obama in signing of the re-issuing of CHIP.jpg|thumb|right|Signing ceremony for the reauthorization]] In the wake of President [[Barack Obama]]'s inauguration and the Democrats' increased majorities in both houses of Congress, legislative leaders moved quickly to break the political stalemate over SCHIP expansion. On January 14, 2009, the House passed {{USBill|111|H.R.|2}} on a vote of 290-138. The bill authorized spending and added $32.8 billion to expand the health coverage program to include about 4 million more children, including coverage of legal immigrants<ref name="NYTimes.com"/> with no waiting period for the first time. A cigarette tax increase of 62 cents—bringing the total tax on a pack of cigarettes to $1.01—an increase of tax on chewing tobacco from $0.195/lb. to $0.50/lb.—as well as tax increases on other tobacco products<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cancer.gov/ncicancerbulletin/021009/page2 |title=Health Groups Hail Increase in Federal Tobacco Taxes |accessdate=2009-02-10 |work=NCI Cancer Bulletin |publisher=National Cancer Institute |date=February 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217235457/http://www.cancer.gov/ncicancerbulletin/021009/page2 |archivedate=February 17, 2009 |df= }}</ref> was proposed as a funding source for the program's expansion. On January 29, the Senate passed the House bill by a 66-32 margin, with two amendments.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ceci |last=Connolly |title=Senate Passes Health Insurance Bill for Children |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/29/AR2009012900325.html |work=Washington Post |publisher= |date=January 30, 2009 |accessdate=January 31, 2009 }}</ref> The House accepted the amended version on a vote of 290 to 135,<ref name="NYTimes.com">{{cite news |first=Robert |last=Pear |title=Obama Signs Children's Health Insurance Bill |work=NYTimes.com |date=February 4, 2009 |accessdate=February 6, 2009 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/05/us/politics/05health.html?ref=health}}</ref> and President Obama signed the bill into law as {{USPL|111|3}} on February 4, 2009.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29011620/ | title=Obama signs kids' health insurance bill | publisher=MSNBC | agency=Associated Press | accessdate=2009-02-04 | date=February 4, 2009}}</ref>
===2010 funding via Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act=== The 2010 passage and signing of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] included funding for CHIP through 2015.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.americanactionforum.org/research/primer-childrens-health-insurance-program-chip/ | title = Primer: The Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) | last = O'Neill Hayes | first = Tara | date = 2017-07-17 | website = American Action Forum | access-date = 2017-09-28 }}</ref>
===2015 reauthorization=== In 2015, Congress passed the [[Medicare Access and CHIP Reauthorization Act of 2015]] (MACRA), and it was signed by President Obama.<ref>{{cite news | last = Hagland | first = Mark | title = BREAKING: President Obama Signs SGR Repeal Legislation, Shifting Medicare Physician Payment Incentives | newspaper = Healthcare Informatics | date = 2015-04-17 | url = https://www.healthcare-informatics.com/article/breaking-president-obama-signs-sgr-repeal-legislation-shifting-medicare-physician-payment-in | access-date = }}</ref>
===2017 expiration and 2018 reauthorization for 10 additional years=== CHIP expired on September 30, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/answer-sheet/wp/2017/10/01/9-million-kids-get-health-insurance-under-chip-congress-just-let-it-expire/|title=9 million kids get health insurance under CHIP. Congress just let it expire.|last=Strauss|first=Valerie|work=Washington Post|date=2017-10-01|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref> At the time, most states had sufficient funds to keep the program running for a period of months.<ref>{{cite news | last = Chang | first = Clio | title = The GOP’s Struggles to Re-Authorize CHIP Is a Devastating Indictment | newspaper = The New Republic | date = 2017-09-28 | url = https://newrepublic.com/article/145084/gops-struggles-re-authorize-chip-devastating-indictment | access-date = 2017-09-28}}</ref>
On September 18, 2017, Senators [[Orrin Hatch]] and [[Ron Wyden]] introduced the Keeping Kids’ Insurance Dependable and Secure (KIDS) Act (Bill S.1827),<ref>{{USBill|115|S.|1827}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |date= 2017-09-18 |title= Hatch, Wyden Introduce Bill to Extend and Improve Critical Children’s Healthcare Program |url= https://www.hatch.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/9/hatch-wyden-introduce-bill-to-extend-and-improve-critical-children-s-healthcare-program |location=Washington, D.C. |publisher= Sen. Orin Hatch |agency= [[U.S. Senate]] |access-date=2017-09-28}}</ref> which would fund CHIP until 2022.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21730912-congressional-inaction-threatens-health-insurance-poor-children-chipped-away|title=Chipped away|work=The Economist|access-date=2017-11-19|language=en}}</ref> On November 3, 2017, the House of Representatives passed the CHAMPION Act, which also would fund CHIP until 2022.<ref>{{USBill|115|H.|3922}}</ref>
On January 22, 2018, President Trump signed legislation that reauthorized CHIP for six years. Bill H.195 (known as the Federal Register Printing Savings Act of 2017, including Extension of Continuing Appropriations Act, 2018) passed the House by a vote of 266-150 and passed the Senate a vote of 81-18.<ref>{{USBill|115|H.|195}}</ref> Fifteen Senate Democrats and 144 House Democrats voted against the bill because they objected to ending a three-day government shutdown without legally enshrining the DACA program for certain undocumented immigrants.<ref>http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/congress-agrees-fund-government-weeks-immigration-debate-continues/story?id=52522136</ref>
On February 9, 2018, Congress passed the [[Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018]], which reauthorized CHIP for an additional four years.<ref name="appropriations.senate.gov">https://www.appropriations.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/Bipartisan%20Budget%20Act%20of%202018.pdf#page=265</ref> The bill was passed by vote of 71-28 in the Senate<ref>http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/373092-senate-passes-bill-to-end-shutdown</ref> and by a vote of 240-186 in the House of Representatives.<ref>http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2018/roll069.xml</ref> President Trump signed the bill into law that same day,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/373107-trump-signs-budget-deal-ending-shutdown |title=Trump signs budget deal ending shutdown |author=BEN KAMISAR, MELANIE ZANONA AND CRISTINA MARCOS |date=February 9, 2018 |website=[[TheHill.com]] |access-date=22 May 2018}}</ref> allowing for CHIP's extension through 2027.<ref name="appropriations.senate.gov"/>
