Rozenblad | leader_title2 = Managing director | leader_name2 = E.D. van Eer | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|medischezending.sr}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} '''Medische Zending Primary Health Care Suriname''', commonly known as '''Medische Zending''' ([[Dutch language|Dutch]] for "medical mission") or '''MZ''' is a [[Suriname]]se [[charitable organization]] offering primary healthcare to remote villages in the interior of Suriname.
Medische Zending and the [[Amazon Conservation Team]] cooperate through a [[memorandum of understanding]] signed in July 1999.
== Healthcare centres == Medische Zending operates 52 primary healthcare centres in the Surinamese interior:<ref name="map">[https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=zcwOKyg5WuI0.kip5FTfZu7JM Map of MZ healthcare centres]</ref>
*[[Afobaka]] *[[Agaigoni]] *[[Apoema]] *[[Apoera]] *[[Balingsoela]] *[[Brokopondo]] *[[Brownsweg]] *[[Corneliskondre]] *[[Cottica]] *[[Debike]] *[[Djoemoe]] *[[Donderskamp]] *[[Drietabiki]] *[[Gakaba]] *[[Godoro]] *[[Goejaba]] *[[Hekoenoenoe]] *[[Jaw Jaw]] *[[Kajana, Suriname|Kajana]] *[[Kalebaskreek]] *[[Nason, Suirname|Nason]] *[[Stoelmanseiland]] *[[Karmel, Suriname|Karmel]] *[[Kawemhakan]] *[[Puleowime]] *[[Paloemeu]] *[[Peleloe Tepoe]] *[[Semoisie]] *[[Kambaloa]] *[[Ladoani]] *[[Soekoenale]] *[[Pokigron]] *[[Lebidotie]] *[[Poesoegroenoe]] *[[Nieuw Koffiekamp]] *[[Kwakoegron]] *[[NJ. Jacob Kondre]] *[[Victoria, Suriname|Victoria]] *[[Klaaskreek]] *[[Phedra]] *[[Tapoeripa]] *[[Washabo]] *[[Witagron]] *[[Kwamalasamutu]] *[[Langatabiki]] *[[Sipaliwini]] *[[Nieuw Lombe]] *[[Marchallkreek]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Mr. Yoga | image = MrYoga Brand Founder Daniel Lacerda.jpg | caption = Mr. Yoga Daniel Lacerda | birth_name = Daniel Lacerda | birth_date = February 11, {{birth year and age|1985}} | birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Canada]] | occupation = author, yoga teacher | years_active = 2005-present | website = http://mryoga.com/ }}
'''Daniel Lacerda''', also known as '''Mr. Yoga''', is a ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' best selling author. He is the founder of Mr. Yoga, Inc. The Mr. Yoga, Inc. office is located in [[Beverly Hills, California|Beverly Hills]], [[California]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/feeling-flexible-heres-2100-yoga-poses/2015/12/09/3c5fcd20-992d-11e5-94f0-9eeaff906ef3_story.html|title=Feeling flexible? Here are 2,100 yoga poses.|website=Washington Post|access-date=2016-05-11}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://yogajournal.de/das-mega-projekt-2100-asanas-von-mr-yoga/|title=Das Mega-Projekt: 2100 Asanas von Mr. Yoga - Yoga Journal|date=2016-04-16|website=Yoga Journal|language=de-DE|access-date=2016-05-11}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2016-01-03/sports/list.html|title=Best Sellers - The New York Times|website=www.nytimes.com|access-date=2016-05-11}}</ref>
Lacerda was born on February 11, 1985 in [[Toronto]], [[Canada]].<ref name=":2" />
In 2015, [[Hachette Book Group]] published a book by Lacerda, called [[Mr. Yoga's 2,100 Asanas]]. It features 2,100 yoga poses ([[Asana]]s) photographed in colour by the author. All the poses in the book are demonstrated by Lacerda's yoga students.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> [[Mr. Yoga's 2,100 Asanas]] became a [[Toronto Star]] bestseller, Indie Healthy Living bestseller, was mentioned on [[Vanity Fair (magazine)]] Hot Type list, as well as making [[The New York Times]] bestsellers list.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/books/2015/12/20/bestsellers.html|title=Bestsellers {{!}} Toronto Star|website=thestar.com|access-date=2016-05-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bookweb.org/news/indie-healthy-living-bestseller-list-5#22 |title=The Indie Healthy Living Bestseller List {{!}} American Booksellers Association |website=www.bookweb.org |access-date=2016-05-11}}</ref><ref name=":3">Vanity Fair Hot Type List, http://sigliopress.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Vanity-Fair-Hot-Type.pdf</ref>
Lacerda began his yoga studies in India under the [[Hindu]] Monk Dada Hari Krishnamacharya. He states that has catalogued many yoga poses mentioned in the [[Hatha Yoga Pradipika]]. Lacerda states further that the [[Mr. Yoga's 2,100 Asanas|2,100 Asanas]] of the first edition will be increased to "50,000 Asanas" in the second edition.<ref name=":2" />
== References == <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Yoga, Mr.}} [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian health and wellness writers]]
{{Canada-writer-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=February 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Natasha Gajewski | image = | caption = | birth_name = {{nowrap|Natasha Rana}} | birth_date = | birth_place = | residence = [[Princeton, New Jersey]] | education = [[Rutgers University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}} | occupation = {{Hlist|CEO|Director|Business Owner}} | organization = Symple Health | spouse = | children = 2 | relatives = [[Christopher Emery]] {{small|(stepbrother)}}
[[Richard Kind]] {{small|(stepbrother)}} | honors = [[TEDMED|TedMED Frontline Scholar]], Stanford MedX ePatient Scholar }}'''Natasha Gajewski''' ({{nee|'''Rana'''}}) is the CEO and Founder of Symple Health.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/858362028|title=Startup leadership : how savvy entrepreneurs turn their ideas into successful enterprises|last=1953-|first=Lidow, Derek,|isbn=9781118845653|edition=First|location=San Francisco|oclc=858362028}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.rwjf.org/en/culture-of-health/2014/03/if_patients_are_flip.html|title=If Patients Are Flipped Out by Today's Physician Encounters, Why Not "Flip" The Clinic?|last=Dentzer|first=Susan|date=2014-03-03|work=[[Robert Wood Johnson Foundation]]|access-date=2017-10-26|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} ==Early life and education== Gajewski was born to Dana Roy and Riaz Hussein Rana. Her father, Rana, was a [[Aircraft pilot|commercial pilot]] and later [[statistician]]. Rana immigrated to the United States from Zafar Chowk, [[Pakistan]] in 1960.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/riaz-h-rana-company-founder/2012/11/15/9c7ad770-2ea2-11e2-9ac2-1c61452669c3_story.html|title=Riaz H. Rana, company founder|last=Schudel|first=Matt|date=2012-11-15|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-10-18|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} Gajewski has one sister, Holly Bossard. Gajewski has a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in Economics and Statistics from [[Rutgers University]]. == Career == After being diagnosed, in 2010, with the rare condition, [[Mixed connective tissue disease|Mixed connective tissue disease (MTCD)]], Gajewski told by her physician to keep track of her symptoms between medical appointments.{{Cite news|url=https://www.medpagetoday.com/publichealthpolicy/generalprofessionalissues/50553|title=Transparency Summit: Patients vs. Doctors|last=Firth|first=Shannon|date=2015-03-18|work=MedPage Today|access-date=2017-12-29|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} This motivated her to improve health prospects for patients.{{Cite web|url=https://medicinex.stanford.edu/conf/conference/user/1045|title=Natasha Gajewski|last=|first=|date=|website=Medicinex - Stanford University|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-26}}{{Cite web|url=http://prescribedesign.com/hacking-my-patient-experience/|title=D-Patient Series: Hacking My Patient Experience – Prescribe Design|last=|first=|date=|website=Prescribe Design|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-26}}{{Cite web|url=http://homecaretechreport.com/article.asp?id=1643|title=New Tools Help Patients Self-Manage Health, Chronic Conditions|last=Kinsella|first=Audrey|date=|website=Home Care Tech Report|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-03}} This led to the idea to create a mobile symptom journal. Gajewski was initially faced with the prohibitive costs of developing a [[Mobile app]] after approaching developers from the [[United States]] and [[India]].{{Cite web|url=http://njtechweekly.com/art/1372-growing-princeton-tech-meetup-features-networking-speakers/|title=Growing Princeton Tech Meetup Features Networking, Speakers|last=Surden|first=Esther|date=2012-05-30|website=New Jersey Tech Weekly|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-26}} To evaluate the feasibility and validity of the app, she attend [[Eric Ries]]'s 2011 [[Lean startup]] - [[San Francisco]] where her idea was the 2nd-place winner and was voted "most fundable" and "most likely to succeed."{{Cite web|url=https://gust.com/companies/symple_health|title=Symple Health|website=Gust|access-date=2017-10-26}} In a February 2017 [https://myheartsisters.org/ Heart Sisters] interview, Gajewksi said of her experience designing a mobile app:{{Cite news|url=https://myheartsisters.org/2017/02/12/clueless/|title=If you’re clueless and you know it . . .|last=Thomas|first=Carolyn|date=2017-02-12|work=Heart Sisters|access-date=2017-10-26|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}{{cquote|But there wasn’t [already a mobile app], so I went about making my own. Because I was actively sick at the time, I knew certain things that a healthy person might completely miss – something as simple as not using sliders on a screen because they’re harder to activate (and require more thought) than a button. }} She has been described as a "revolutionary" in the engaged patient movement along with [[Dave deBronkart]] and [[Jamie Heywood]].{{Cite news|url=https://clearhealthcosts.com/blog/2013/02/a-few-thoughts-about-the-health-care-marketplace/|title=A few thoughts about the health-care marketplace|last=Pinder|first=Jeanne|date=2013-02-27|work=Clear Health Costs|access-date=2017-12-29|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}} In 2014, the Symple App had 60,000 users.{{Cite web|url=http://pixelhealth.net/2014/07/18/friday-interview-natasha-gajewski-founder-symple-app/|title=The Friday Interview: Natasha Gajewski, Founder of Symple App {{!}} Pixel Health|last=Clare|first=David|date=2014-07-18|website=Pixel Health|language=en-GB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-26}} It is distributed through the [[App Store (iOS)]]. In an interview with [[Break Media|MedCity News]], Gajewski stated that she used simplistic design for the Symple App which operates as an online health journal.{{Cite web|url=https://medcitynews.com/2015/07/engage-keep-health-apps-simple-outcomes-focused/?rf=1|title=ENGAGE: Keep health apps simple, outcomes-focused|last=Versel|first=Neil|date=2015-07-14|website=MedCity News|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-26}} In 2016, Symple was recommended by a [[National Health Service]] [[general practitioner]], Dr. Golda Parker, for patients to use to create lists of symptoms so they come prepared to appointments.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health-fitness/body/dont-come-on-mondays-and-google-your-symptoms-first---gps-tips-o/|title=Forget Mondays and Google your symptoms first - GPs' tips on getting more from your appointment|last=Magee|first=Anna|date=2017-06-01|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2017-10-28|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} Gajewski's Symple app has been the subject of research in academic journals.{{Cite journal|last=Masterson Creber|first=Ruth M|last2=Maurer|first2=Mathew S|last3=Reading|first3=Meghan|last4=Hiraldo|first4=Grenny|last5=Hickey|first5=Kathleen T|last6=Iribarren|first6=Sarah|date=2016-06-14|title=Review and Analysis of Existing Mobile Phone Apps to Support Heart Failure Symptom Monitoring and Self-Care Management Using the Mobile Application Rating Scale (MARS)|journal=JMIR mHealth and uHealth|volume=4|issue=2|doi=10.2196/mhealth.5882|issn=2291-5222|pmc=4925936|pmid=27302310}} A 2017 academic study rated her mobile app as one of the "highest performing apps" for heart failure monitoring.{{Cite journal|last=Athilingam|first=Ponrathi|last2=Jenkins|first2=Bradlee|last3=Johansson|first3=Marcia|last4=Labrador|first4=Miguel|date=2017|title=A Mobile Health Intervention to Improve Self-Care in Patients With Heart Failure: Pilot Randomized Control Trial|url=https://cardio.jmir.org/2017/2/e3/|journal=JMIR Cardio|language=en|volume=1|issue=2|doi=10.2196/cardio.7848}} Gajewski provided input on [[point of care]] patient decisions in a 2016 study.{{Cite journal|last=O’Malley|first=Ann S.|last2=Collins|first2=Anna|last3=Contreary|first3=Kara|last4=Rich|first4=Eugene C.|date=2016-07-01|title=Barriers to and Facilitators of Evidence-Based Decision Making at the Point of Care: Implications for Delivery Systems, Payers, and Policy Makers|url=https://doi.org/10.1177/2381468316660375|journal=MDM Policy & Practice|language=en|volume=1|issue=1|pages=2381468316660375|doi=10.1177/2381468316660375|issn=2381-4683}} Danny Gorog of [[Macworld]] had positive remarks on the App, stating that it " is a powerful iPhone app that lets users track up to 20 different symptoms at once. It also functions as a health diary, to let you note the things you eat, daily exercise and medications you take."{{Cite news|url=http://www.macworld.com.au/app-guide/3-of-a-kind-ios-health-apps-113650/#.WkWhe1Q-fsk|title=3 of a kind: iOS health apps - Macworld Australia|work=Macworld Australia|access-date=2017-12-29|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171229112739/http://www.macworld.com.au/app-guide/3-of-a-kind-ios-health-apps-113650/#.WkWhe1Q-fsk#.WkWhe1Q-fsk|archive-date=December 29, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} == Advisory boards == Gajewski serves as an Advisor for [[Princeton University]]'s Keller Center eLab Summer Accelerator.{{Cite news|url=https://kellercenter.princeton.edu/create/elab-summer-accelerator/people/advisors|title=Advisors|last=|first=|date=2016-03-31|work=Keller Center|access-date=2017-10-26|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=Board of Trustees Princeton University|language=en-US}} She is also a member of [[University of California, San Diego]] and [[University of California, Irvine|Irvine]]'s Health Data Exploration Project.{{Cite web|url=http://hdexplore.calit2.net/hdedirectory/name/natasha-gajewki-_/|title=Natasha Gajewki _ » Network Directory – Health Data Exploration|website=hdexplore.calit2.net|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-29}} In December 2011, Gajewski was one of the [[Princeton University|Princeton alumni]] and women [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneurs]] and business leaders who served as a panelist for the event entitled "Women in Entrepreneurship" hosted by the Keller Center.{{Cite news|url=https://www.princeton.edu/news/2011/12/09/princeton-alumni-examine-barriers-women-entrepreneurship|title=Princeton alumni examine barriers for women in entrepreneurship|last=Sullivan|first=John|date=2011-12-09|work=Princeton University|access-date=2017-10-29|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} The panel explored the underrepresentation of women in [[venture capital]] and [[Startup company|startup]] ventures to which, Gajewski reported "I just never imagined limitations based on my sex.” Later remarking, “It just never occurred to me." Gajewski is a faculty member for the [[Robert Wood Johnson Foundation]] sponsored National Health Care Transparency Summit.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hctransparencysummit.com/|title=The National Healthcare Healthcare Transparency Summit|last=Robert Wood Johnson Foundation|first=|date=|website=Healthcare Healthcare Transparency Summit|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-29}} Gajewski serves on the Advisory Board of Flip the Clinic, a project of the [[Robert Wood Johnson Foundation]].{{Cite news|url=http://fliptheclinic.org/about/|title=About - Flip the Clinic|work=Flip the Clinic|access-date=2017-12-29|language=en-US}} == Personal life == Gajewksi resides in [[Princeton, New Jersey]]. To combat her [[Autoimmune disease]], Gajewski practices [[Zumba]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.healthmgttech.com/taking-patient-advocacy-to-a-whole-new-level.php|title=Taking Patient Advocacy to a Whole New Level|last=|first=|date=2011-09-01|website=Health Management Technology Magazine|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-26}} Gajewski's parents later divorced and her father remarried to Jacqueline Nicole Marchal of Paris, through which, Gajewski gained three stepsiblings including [[Christopher Emery]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/usa/the-washington-post/20100219/283583806543506|title=Jacqueline Rana|last=|first=|date=2010-02-19|website=Washington Post|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-10-19}} Gajewski's mother remarried to [[Jewellery|jeweler]] Samuel Kind, through which, she gained two stepsiblings, actor and voice actor [[Richard Kind]] and Joanne Hinton.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/23/classified/paid-notice-deaths-kind-samuel-m.html|title=Paid Notice: Deaths KIND, SAMUEL M.|date=1997-07-23|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} == Awards and recognition == * [[TEDMED|TedMED]] Frontline scholar * "1 of 10 Innovators to Follow" - [[Partners HealthCare|Partners HealthCare Center for Connected Health]] * 2013 [[Stanford University|Stanford]] MedX [[E-patient|ePatient]] scholar * Member - Startup Health Showcase, mHealth Summit, [[Washington, D.C.]] * Competition winners - [[Lean startup]], [[Eric Ries]], [[IMVU]], and [[Thomas Eisenmann]] of the [[Harvard Business School]] {{Portal|Biography|Technology|Health and fitness|Medicine|New Jersey|}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://www.sympleapp.com/blog/aboutme Official Website] {{Portal bar|Biography|Technology|Health and fitness|Medicine|Biotechnology|Science|New Jersey}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gajewski, Natasha}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Princeton, New Jersey]] [[Category:American people of Pakistani descent]] [[Category:Rutgers University alumni]] [[Category:Businesspeople in the healthcare industry]] [[Category:Women in medicine]] [[Category:American women chief executives]] [[Category:American women business executives]] [[Category:American businesspeople of Pakistani descent]]

{{Infobox building | name = Nun's Well | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_names = | alternate_names = | status = Restored | image = [[File:Nun's Well, Europa Point, Gibraltar.jpg|240px]] | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = Nun's Well at [[Europa Point]] | map_type = Gibraltar | map_alt = | map_caption = Location of Nun's Well in [[Gibraltar]] | altitude = | building_type = | architectural_style = | structural_system = | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = [[Government of Gibraltar]] | current_tenants = | landlord = | location = [[Europa Point]], [[Gibraltar]] | address = | location_town = | location_country = | coordinates = {{coord|36.111556|-5.345739|display=inline,title}} | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = [[Moors|Moorish]] Period (Before 1462) | completion_date = | opened_date = | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = 1988 | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | height = | architectural = | awards = | designations = | ren_architect = | ren_firm = | ren_str_engineer = [[Royal Engineers]] | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_awards = | parking = | url = }} '''Nun's Well''' is an ancient underground water [[reservoir]] in the [[British Overseas Territory]] of [[Gibraltar]]. It is located at [[Europa Point]], and is thought to be of the [[Moors|Moorish]] period. It represents some of the earliest evidence of an artificial [[Water supply and sanitation in Gibraltar|water supply in Gibraltar]]. The name of the [[cistern]] is thought to be derived from the [[nuns]] associated with the [[Shrine of Our Lady of Europe]]. In the eighteenth century, Nun's Well supplied the military with water. In the early nineteenth century, it provided water for the [[brewery]] that was built next door. In 1988, the [[Royal Engineers]] constructed what is now the main building, which has a castle-like appearance. Nun's Well became the focus of controversy during the 2010-2011 restoration of the site.
==Early history==
[[File:Captain John Drinkwater.jpg|thumb|180px|left|[[John Drinkwater Bethune]]]] Nun's Well is an ancient [[Subterranea (geography)|subterranean]] water reservoir in Gibraltar, the British Overseas Territory at the southern end of the [[Iberian Peninsula]].<ref name=aquagib/><ref>{{cite web|title=List of Crown Dependencies & Overseas Territories|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/publications-and-documents/treaties/uk-overseas-territories/list-crown-dependencies-overseas|work=fco.gov.uk|publisher=[[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]]|accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Neandertals' Last Stand Was in Gibraltar, Study Suggests|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2006/09/060913-neanderthals.html|accessdate=7 October 2012|newspaper=National Geographic News|date=13 September 2006|author=Roach, John|agency=[[National Geographic Society]]}}</ref> It is located at Europa Point, the southernmost portion of Gibraltar.<ref name=about/><ref>{{cite web|title=The Essential Gibraltar|url=http://www.liftedmagazine.com/travel-1.asp?ID=6|work=liftedmagazine.com|publisher=Lifted Magazine|accessdate=7 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713204847/http://www.liftedmagazine.com/travel-1.asp?ID=6|archivedate=13 July 2011|df=}}</ref> The cistern is on Europa New Road at Europa Flats, across from the south entrance to [[Keightley Way Tunnel]], just south of the [[Ibrahim-al-Ibrahim Mosque]]. On the east side of the structure, the reservoir is accessed by stairs which lead to a door constructed at the underground level.<ref>{{cite book|title=The shores and islands of the Mediterranean|year=1840|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yy8BAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA26&lpg=PA26&dq=Moorish+cistern,+Gibraltar&source=bl&ots=qGyI_XowvX&sig=_MqdjpxYMwy5GbzhaxZIKM9wqs4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=tS1zUPjAO6byyAGQiYGYCw&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBzgU#v=onepage&q=Moorish%20cistern%2C%20Gibraltar&f=false|author=[[George Newenham Wright|Wright, George Newenham]]|accessdate=8 October 2012|page=26}}</ref><ref name=costa>{{cite web|title=Nun's Well Gibraltar|url=http://gibraltar.costasur.com/en/nunswell.html|work=gibraltar.costasur.com|publisher=CostaSur.com|accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Map - Nun's Well|url=https://maps.google.com/?q=36.111556,-5.345739&num=1&t=h&z=20 |work=maps.google.com|publisher=[[Google Maps]]|accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref> The water reservoir includes a pair of large underground arched chambers into which ground water was permitted to drain. Nun's Well is thought to be of the Moorish period, and represents some of the earliest evidence of the attempts to provide a water supply in Gibraltar.<ref name=aquagib>{{cite web|title=Gibraltar Water Supply|url=http://aquagib.gi/doc_bin/040319-Gib%20Water%20Supply%20History.pdf|work=aquagib.gi|publisher=AquaGib|accessdate=7 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120831191612/http://aquagib.gi/doc_bin/040319-Gib%20Water%20Supply%20History.pdf|archivedate=31 August 2012|df=}}</ref><ref name=about>{{cite web|title=Nunswell|url=http://www.aboutourrock.com/sites/nunswell.htm|work=aboutourrock.com|publisher=About Our Rock|accessdate=6 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120831102550/http://www.aboutourrock.com/sites/nunswell.htm|archivedate=31 August 2012|df=}}</ref><ref name=costa/>
It is thought that the name of the cistern originated with the nuns who previously cared for the Shrine of Our Lady of Europe, another historic site at Europa Point.<ref name=about/> Nun's Well is also in proximity to the [[Europa Point Lighthouse]].<ref>{{cite book|title=A popular history of Gibraltar, its institutions, and its neighbourhood on both sides of the Straits, and a guide book to their principal places and objects of interest|year=1881|publisher=[[Garrison Library]] Printing Establishment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2J5CAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&dq=Moorish+cistern,+Gibraltar&source=bl&ots=qC03jbUQ6D&sig=PQ3hNrOyVUlmRJPngGbH26KDXes&hl=en&sa=X&ei=tS1zUPjAO6byyAGQiYGYCw&ved=0CDYQ6AEwBTgU#v=onepage&q=Moorish%20cistern%2C%20Gibraltar&f=false|author=Gilbard, Lieutenant Colonel George James|accessdate=8 October 2012|page=35}}</ref>
In 1753, [[Governor of Gibraltar]] [[Humphrey Bland]] ordered that the chambers be cleaned. Afterwards, the reservoir supplied the military with water.<ref name=costa/> Nun's Well was described in the second edition of the journal of [[England|British]] officer and military historian [[John Drinkwater Bethune]], ''A history of the late siege of Gibraltar'', published in 1786.<ref>{{cite book|title=A history of the late siege of Gibraltar|year=1786|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yT4OAAAAQAAJ&q=Moorish+bath#v=snippet&q=Moorish%20bath&f=false|author=[[John Drinkwater Bethune|Bethune, John Drinkwater]]|edition=2|accessdate=7 October 2012|page=34}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=History of the Late Siege of Gibraltar|year=1786|url=http://www.dotcom.gi/siege/chapter02.htm|author=Bethune, John Drinkwater|accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> {{quote|"Towards Europa advance is a Moorish bath, called by the [[garrison]], the Nuns well. It is sunk eight feet deep in the rock, is 72 feet long, and 42 feet broad, and, to preserve the water, has an arched roof, supported by pillars."}}
==Nineteenth century==
[[File:Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn by Sir William Beechey.jpg|thumb|180px|left|[[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn|Prince Edward, Duke of Kent]]]] [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn|Prince Edward, the Duke of Kent]] (2 November 1767 – 23 January 1820), later the father of [[Queen Victoria]], arrived in Gibraltar for the second time in May 1802. His first arrival had been in 1790 as an officer; his second stay at Gibraltar was as Governor, following the death of Governor General [[Charles O'Hara]]. Prince Edward was ordered by his brother [[Prince Frederick, Duke of York and Albany|Prince Frederick, Duke of York]] to restore discipline at the garrison, as the soldiers spent much of their time inebriated. Before the prince's arrival, Gibraltar had ninety-two taverns which served its approximately 7,000 civilians and soldiers.<ref>{{cite book|title=Nelson's Refuge: Gibraltar in the Age of Napoleon|publisher=[[Naval Institute Press]]|isbn= 9781612510842|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HThZ_inxa14C&pg=PT68&lpg=PT68&dq=Prince+Edward's+Gate,+Gibraltar&source=bl&ots=pAIlKj0tv1&sig=_01B066EBz8gq66WYXurfTODTi0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=h5BmUKOqB-a_ygG824CIBw&ved=0CCEQ6AEwATge#v=onepage&q=Prince%20Edward's%20Gate%2C%20Gibraltar&f=false|author=Musteen, Jason R.|accessdate=8 October 2012|date=15 October 2011}}</ref><ref name=canadian>{{cite DCB |url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/edward_augustus_5E.html |title=Edward Augustus, Duke of Kent and Strathearn |volume=5 |last=MacNutt |first=W.S. |accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref> After his arrival, he closed down the majority of the wine houses that had been frequented by the soldiers. In addition, the Governor ordered that all the remaining taverns be off-limits for the soldiers except for three: [[The Three Light Infantrymen, Gibraltar|The Three Light Infantrymen]], [[The Halfway House, Gibraltar|The Halfway House]], and the [[Three Guns, Gibraltar|Three Guns]].<ref>{{cite web|title=1802 - The Duke of Kent – Abominable Licentiousness|url=http://gibraltar-intro.blogspot.com/2012/01/chapter-3.html|publisher=Neville Chipulina|accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> He established a brewery at Europa Point, next to Nun's Well. His brewery was known as Brewery Yard or Brewers Yard, and utilised water from Nun's Well. It was the source of “a wholesome supply of [[Beer]] for the Troops.”<ref name=about/><ref name=costa/><ref name=seven/> The [[Duke of Kent]] was recalled to [[England]] in the spring of 1803.<ref name=canadian/> Later, in 1805, the brewery was converted into military [[barracks]].<ref name=about/><ref name=costa/><ref name=seven>{{cite news|title=Europa Point gets a Makeover|url=http://www.7daysgibraltar.com/article.php?id=1302|accessdate=6 October 2007|newspaper=7 Days}}</ref> The [[Italy|Italian]] architect [[Giovanni Maria Boschetti]] has been credited with demolishing the brewery and constructing a barracks in its place.<ref>{{cite web|title=The People of Gibraltar - 1784 - Giovanni Maria Boschetti|url=http://gibraltar-intro.blogspot.com/2012/03/chapter-3-1784-giovanni-maria-boschetti.html|publisher=Neville Chipulina|accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=House Hunting in ... Gibraltar|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/16/greathomesanddestinations/real-estate-in-gibraltar.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=8 October 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 August 2012|author=Gregor, Alison}}</ref>
In the mid nineteenth century, Nun's Well was described by [[Spain|Spanish]] historian [[Ignacio López de Ayala]] in his ''History of Gibraltar'', published in 1845.<ref>{{cite book|title=The History of Gibraltar: From the Earliest Period of Its Occupation by the Saracens : Comprising Details of the Numerous Conflicts for Its Possession Between the Moors and the Christians, Until Its Final Surrender in 1642 : and of Subsequent Events : with an Appendix Containing Interesting Documents|year=1845|publisher=[[William Pickering (publisher)|William Pickering]]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8e4rAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA20&lpg=PA20&dq=Moorish+cistern,+Gibraltar&source=bl&ots=aR2iLRU-Rm&sig=3c-WZF6AfP2tbvYGtRDLjaYtMqk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-xhzUOmRCYizyAG_yYGgDw&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAjgU#v=onepage&q=Moorish%20cistern%2C%20Gibraltar&f=false|author=[[Ignacio López de Ayala|López de Ayala, Ignacio]]|accessdate=8 October 2012<!--|nopp=234-->|pages=19–20}}</ref>{{quote|"To the Eastward, and near the Virgen de Europa, was an admirably constructed Cistern or tank for receiving water; so magnificent and of such noble architecture, that it is difficult to divine whether it was the work of the Moors, or of more ancient times. Its shape is that of a [[Trapezoid|Trapezium]], seventy-eight feet long, forty-two and forty-eight in width, and eight feet high. Twenty-two solid pillars support the roof, and the descent is by steps, built of bricks. The whole exhibits the result of great perseverance and industry, for it is excavated in a solid rock, and no other place near to it seems fit for such an undertaking. The water collected there is good, and remains sweet throughout the year; but the Cistern has suffered much from the effects of time. (It is still used as a tank, and now bears the name of the Nun's Well.)"}}
==Recent history== [[File:Dr john cortes.jpg|thumb|180px|left|[[John Cortes]]]] [[File:Peter Caruana portrait.jpg|thumb|right|180px|[[Peter Caruana]]]] In the early twentieth century, the military barracks next to the Nun's Well site, referred to as Brewery Barracks, was reported to be in an "insanitary" condition. Discussions at [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] further indicated that large amounts of money had already been spent on the barracks, and that they were scheduled to be replaced.<ref name=about/><ref name=costa/><ref>{{cite book|title=The parliamentary debates|year=1904|publisher=[[Reuters|Reuter's Telegram Co]]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vr7ARemKpjkC&pg=PR936&lpg=PR936&dq=Brewery+barracks,+Gibraltar&source=bl&ots=8B7wrYH7gJ&sig=t7Axqu81v0jz-ie-NiWBJzsIAsk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-khzUIK9N4bkyQHKs4DoBQ&ved=0CDcQ6AEwBTgU#v=onepage&q=Brewery%20barracks%2C%20Gibraltar&f=false|author=[[Parliament of the United Kingdom]]|accessdate=8 October 2012|pages=1487–1488}}</ref>
In May 1987, the Royal Engineers conducted an investigation of the Nun's Well site. The following year, the Royal Engineers constructed what is now the main building. It has a castle-like appearance; its addition was part of a general restoration of the site. The site of the previous brewery and later barracks is now open ground which is utilised by the military for target practice.<ref name=about/><ref name=costa/> While the reservoir had been thought to fill with water that drains along the fractures of the nearby Beefsteak Fault, recent investigation has led researchers to believe that it fills with a combination of rain, street flushing, and sea spray, particularly during [[Levant (wind)|levanter]] winds.<ref>{{cite news|title=Geology - Ground and Surface Water Supply|url=http://vox.gi/science/geology/3305-Ground_Surface_Water_Supply20012008.html|accessdate=7 October 2012|newspaper=Vox - The Truly Independent Gibraltar Newspaper|date=20 January 2008|author=Gomez, Freddie|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130808030107/http://vox.gi/science/geology/3305-Ground_Surface_Water_Supply20012008.html|archivedate=8 August 2013|df=}}</ref>
In 2010, the [[Government of Gibraltar]] requested that the [[Gibraltar Ornithological and Natural History Society]] (GONHS) make suggestions for the landscaping of Europa Point, as the government was intent on restoring the site. A report was completed and contractors transplanted vegetation to the area by Nun's Well to be tended while awaiting replanting. However, irrigation was not provided for the landscaping plants, with the result that most of the plants at Nun's Well died. Another thousand plants that replaced them were also neglected and largely died. Concurrently, an adjacent area which was covered with the strictly protected [[Gibraltar Sea Lavender]] ''(Limonium emarginatum)'' had [[rubble]] dumped upon it.<ref name=gonhs/><ref>{{cite web|title=Plant Life - Sea cliffs and shoreline|url=http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi/flora-and-fauna/plant-life|work=gibraltar.gov.gi|publisher=[[Government of Gibraltar]]|accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref> The errors were compounded when replacement planting took place in the heat of summer, and dumping of rubble on the lavender continued. The society contended that the events which transpired were against both the government's own Environment Charter and Environmental Action and Management Plan.<ref name=gonhs>{{cite news|title=GONHS Concerns About Europa Point Landscaping|url=http://vox.gi/local/4121-gonhs-concerns-about-europa-point-landscaping.html|accessdate=7 October 2012|newspaper=Vox - The Truly Independent Gibraltar Newspaper|date=20 September 2011}}</ref>
In October 2011, the council of the Gibraltar Ornithological and Natural History Society declined an invitation for its [[General Secretary]] [[John Cortes]] to attend the inauguration of the recently restored Europa Point. The reasons cited included the [[Habitat destruction|destruction]] of the [[habitat]], the flouting of laws relating to the removal of Gibraltar's [[protected species]], and the ignoring of solicited advice on landscaping with salt-resistant [[native plants]]. The decision was criticised by [[Chief Minister of Gibraltar|Chief Minister]] [[Peter Caruana]] as a "political stunt."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Gibraltar Ornithological & Natural History Society|url=http://www.gonhs.org/press.htm|work=gonhs.org|publisher=The [[Gibraltar Ornithological & Natural History Society]]|accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Cortes Boycott of Europa Inauguration 'a Political Stunt', says Caruana|url=http://www.chronicle.gi/headlines_details.php?id=23057|accessdate=7 October 2012|newspaper=[[Gibraltar Chronicle]]|date=24 October 2011}}</ref> Caruana's statements were denounced by the GONHS as a "vitriolic attack" and a spokesman indicated that their society was an "apolitical ... independent NGO" ([[non-governmental organization]]).<ref>{{cite news|title=Decision to Boycott Europa Opening Was Taken Unanimously|url=http://www.chronicle.gi/headlines_details.php?id=23067|accessdate=7 October 2012|newspaper=Gibraltar Chronicle|date=25 October 2011}}</ref>

#REDIRECT [[Osteopathy]]
[[Category:Osteopaths| ]] [[Category:Healthcare occupations]]

[[File:Cebocap.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Prescription placebos used in research and practice.]] '''Placebo-controlled studies''' are a way of testing a medical therapy in which, in addition to a group of subjects that receives the treatment to be evaluated, a separate [[Scientific control|control]] group receives a sham "[[placebo]]" treatment which is specifically designed to have no real effect. Placebos are most commonly used in [[Blind experiment|blinded]] trials, where subjects do not know whether they are receiving real or placebo treatment. Often, there is also a further "natural history" group that does not receive any treatment at all.
The purpose of the placebo group is to account for the [[placebo effect]], that is, effects from treatment that do not depend on the treatment itself. Such factors include knowing one is receiving a treatment, attention from health care professionals, and the expectations of a treatment's effectiveness by those running the research study. Without a placebo group to compare against, it is not possible to know whether the treatment itself had any effect.
Patients frequently show improvement even when given a sham or "fake" treatment. Such intentionally inert [[placebo]] treatments can take many forms, such as a pill containing only sugar, a surgery where nothing efficacious is actually done (just an incision and sometimes some minor touching or handling of the underlying structures), or a medical device (such as an [[medical ultrasonography|ultrasound machine]]) that is not actually turned on. Also, due to the body's natural healing ability and statistical effects such as [[regression to the mean]], many patients will get better even when given no treatment at all. Thus, the relevant question when assessing a treatment is not "does the treatment work?" but "does the treatment work better than a placebo treatment, or no treatment at all?" As one early [[clinical trial]] researcher wrote, "the first object of a therapeutic trial is to discover whether the patients who receive the treatment under investigation are cured more rapidly, more completely or more frequently, than they would have been without it."<ref>{{cite journal |author=Gaddum JH |title=Clinical pharmacology |journal=Proc. R. Soc. Med. |volume=47 |issue=3 |pages=195–204 |date=March 1954 |pmid=13155508 |pmc=1918604 }}</ref>{{sup|p.195}} More broadly, the aim of a [[clinical trial]] is to determine what treatments, delivered in what circumstances, to which patients, in what conditions, are the most effective.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Chambless DL, Hollon SD |title=Defining empirically supported therapies |journal=J Consult Clin Psychol |volume=66 |issue=1 |pages=7–18 |date=February 1998 |pmid=9489259 |url=http://content.apa.org/journals/ccp/66/1/7 |doi=10.1037/0022-006X.66.1.7}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lohr JM, Olatunji BO, Parker L, DeMaio C |title=Experimental analysis of specific treatment factors: efficacy and practice implications |journal=J Clin Psychol |volume=61 |issue=7 |pages=819–34 |date=July 2005 |pmid=15827994 |doi=10.1002/jclp.20128}}</ref>
Therefore, the use of placebos is a standard [[Scientific control|control]] component of most [[clinical trial]]s, which attempt to make some sort of [[quantitative property|quantitative]] assessment of the efficacy of medicinal drugs or treatments. Such a test or clinical trial is called a ''placebo-controlled'' study, and its control is of the [[scientific control#Negative|negative]] type. A study whose control is a previously tested treatment, rather than no treatment, is called a ''positive-control'' study, because its control is of the [[scientific control#Positive|positive]] type. Government regulatory agencies approve new drugs only after tests establish not only that patients respond to them, but also that their effect is greater than that of a placebo (by way of affecting more patients, by affecting responders more strongly, or both).
== Methodology ==
===Single Blind trials=== Things like sugar pills, that look like real treatments but in fact have no physical effect are used to create "blind" trials in which the participants do not know whether they are getting the active treatment or not, so that physical effects can be measured independently of the participants' expectations. Single Blind trials control all of these by making whatever expectations there are equal for all cases.
Placebos are not the only possible technique for creating "blindness" (= unawareness of the treatment): to test the effectiveness of [[prayer]] by others, the participants are not told who has and has not had prayers said for them. To test the effect of changing the frequency of [[fluorescent light]]s on [[headache]]s, the light fittings are changed at night in the absence of the office workers (this is a real case). It has been shown that "mock" surgery can have similar effects,{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} and so some surgical techniques must be studied with placebo controls (rarely double blind, due to the difficulty involved).
=== Double-blind trials=== Because a doctor's belief in the value of a treatment can affect his or her behavior, and thus what his or her patient believes, clinical trials are usually conducted in "[[double-blind]]" manner: that is, not only are the patients made unaware when they are receiving a placebo, the doctors are made unaware too.
Nearly all studies conducted find benefit in the placebo group. For example, Khan published a [[meta-analysis]] of studies of investigational [[antidepressant]]s and found a 30% reduction in suicide and attempted suicide in the placebo groups and a 40% reduction in the treated groups.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Khan A, Warner HA, Brown WA |title=Symptom reduction and suicide risk in patients treated with placebo in antidepressant clinical trials: an analysis of the Food and Drug Administration database |journal=Arch. Gen. Psychiatry |volume=57 |issue=4 |pages=311–7 |date=April 2000 |pmid=10768687 |url=http://archpsyc.ama-assn.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=10768687 |doi=10.1001/archpsyc.57.4.311 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> However, studies generally do not include an untreated group, so determining the actual size of the placebo effect, compared to totally untreated patients, is difficult.
=== Natural history groups=== The practice of using an additional [[natural history group]] as the trial's so-called "''third arm''" has emerged; and trials are conducted using three [[randomized clinical trial|randomly selected]], equally matched trial groups, David<ref>{{cite journal| title=Creative consulting: what modifies a healing response| journal=Student BMJ| year=2002| first=David| last=Reilly| volume=10| pages=1–44| url=http://student.bmj.com/issues/02/02/education/12.php }} p.28</ref> wrote: "''... it is necessary to remember the adjective ‘random’ [in the term ‘random sample’] should apply to the method of drawing the sample and not to the sample itself.''".
* The '''Active drug''' group ('''A'''): who receive the active test drug. * The '''Placebo drug''' group ('''P'''): who receive a placebo drug that simulates the active drug. * The '''Natural history''' group ('''NH'''): who receive no treatment of any kind (and whose condition, therefore, is allowed to run its ''natural'' course).
The outcomes within each group are observed, and compared with each other, allowing us to measure: * The efficacy of the active drug's '''treatment''': the difference between '''A''' and '''NH''' (i.e., '''A-NH'''). * The efficacy of the active drug's '''active ingredient''': the difference between '''A''' and '''P''' (i.e., '''A-P'''). * The magnitude of the '''placebo response''': the difference between '''P''' and '''NH''' (i.e., '''P-NH'''). It is a matter of interpretation whether the value of '''P-NH''' indicates the ''efficacy of the entire treatment process'' or the ''magnitude of the "placebo response"''. The results of these comparisons then determine whether or not a particular drug is considered efficacious.
===Indexing=== In certain clinical trials of particular drugs, it may happen that the level of the "placebo responses" manifested by the trial's subjects are either considerably higher or lower (in relation to the "active" drug's effects) than one would expect from other trials of similar drugs. In these cases, [[Ceteris paribus|with all other things being equal]], it is reasonable to conclude that: * the degree to which there is a '''considerably higher''' level of "placebo response" than one would expect is an index of the degree to which the drug's ''active ingredient'' is '''not efficacious'''. * the degree to which there is a '''considerably lower''' level of "placebo response" than one would expect is an index of the degree to which, in some particular way, the ''placebo'' is '''not simulating''' the active drug in an appropriate way.
However, in particular cases such as the use of Cimetidine to treat ulcers, a significant level of placebo response can also prove to be an index of how much the treatment has been directed at a wrong target.
==Implementation issues==
===Adherence === The Coronary Drug Project<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1056/NEJM198010303031804 |title=Influence of adherence to treatment and response of cholesterol on mortality in the coronary drug project |journal=N. Engl. J. Med. |volume=303 |issue=18 |pages=1038–41 |date=October 1980 |pmid=6999345 }}</ref> was intended to study the safety and effectiveness of drugs for long-term treatment of coronary heart disease in men. Those in the placebo group who adhered to the placebo treatment (took the placebo regularly as instructed) showed nearly half the [[mortality rate]] as those who were not adherent. A similar study of women similarly found survival was nearly 2.5 times greater for those who adhered to their placebo.<ref>{{cite journal| title= The relationship of treatment adherence to the risk of death after myocardial infarction in women| journal=Journal of the American Medical Association| year=1993| first=E. J.| last=Gallagher|author2=Viscoli, C. M. |author3=Horwitz, R. I. | volume=270| pages=742–4| doi= 10.1001/jama.270.6.742| pmid=8336377| issue= 6}}</ref> This apparent placebo effect may have occurred because: * Adhering to the protocol had a psychological effect, i.e. genuine placebo effect. * People who were already healthier were more able or more inclined to follow the protocol. * Compliant people were more diligent and health-conscious in all aspects of their lives.
===Recognition=== Appropriate use of a placebo in a [[clinical trial]] often requires or at least benefits from a [[double-blind]] study design, which means that neither the experimenters nor the subjects know which subjects are in the "test group" and which are in the "control group". This creates a problem in creating placebos that can be mistaken for active treatments. It therefore can be necessary to use a '''psychoactive placebo''', a drug that produces physiological effects that encourage the belief in the control groups that they have received an active drug.
A psychoactive placebo was used in the [[Marsh Chapel Experiment]], a [[double-blind]] study in which the experimental group received the [[Psychedelic drug|psychedelic]] substance [[psilocybin]] while the control group received a large dose of [[niacin]], a substance that produces noticeable physical effects intended to lead the control subjects to believe they had received the '''psychoactive drug'''. The term "psychoactive placebo" is rare in the literature; but, when it is used, it always denotes a placebo of this type. For example, "''Neither the experienced investigator nor the naive [subject] is easily fooled on the matter of whether he has received a [[Psychedelic drug|psychedelic]] substance or merely a [[psychoactive]] placebo such as [[amphetamine]].''"<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Harman WW, McKim RH, Mogar RE, Fadiman J, Stolaroff MJ |title=Psychedelic agents in creative problem-solving: a pilot study |journal=Psychol Rep |volume=19 |issue=1 |pages=211–27 |date=August 1966 |pmid=5942087 |doi=10.2466/pr0.1966.19.1.211}}</ref>
==History== {{broader|Placebo in history}}
=== James Lind and scurvy=== [[File:James lind.jpg|thumb|left|200px|James Lind|A portrait of Scottish doctor James Lind (1716-1794)]]In 1747, [[James Lind (physician)|James Lind]] (1716–1794), the [[ship's doctor]] on [[HMS Salisbury]], conducted the first [[clinical trial]] when he investigated the efficacy of [[citrus fruit]] in cases of [[scurvy]]. He randomly divided twelve scurvy patients, whose "cases were as similar as I could have them", into six pairs. Each pair was given a different remedy. According to Lind’s 1753 ''Treatise on the Scurvy in Three Parts Containing an Inquiry into the Nature, Causes, and Cure of the Disease, Together with a Critical and Chronological View of what has been Published of the Subject'', the remedies were: one quart of [[cider]] per day, twenty-five drops of elixir [[vitriol]] ([[sulfuric acid]]) three times a day, two spoonfuls of [[vinegar]] three times a day, a course of sea-water (half a [[pint]] every day), two [[orange (fruit)|orange]]s and one [[lemon]] each day, and [[electuary]], (a mixture containing [[garlic]], [[mustard (condiment)|mustard]], [[balsam of Peru]], and [[myrrh]]).<ref name="Lind">{{cite journal| title= James Lind (1716-94) of Edinburgh and the treatment of scurvy| journal=Archives of Disease in Childhood: Fetal and Neonatal Edition| date= January 1, 1997 | first=Peter M.| last=Dunn| volume=76| pages=F64–5 | pmid= 9059193| issue= 1| doi= 10.1136/fn.76.1.F64| pmc= 1720613}}</ref>
He noted that the pair who had been given the oranges and lemons were so restored to health within six days of treatment that one of them returned to duty, and the other was well enough to attend the rest of the sick.<ref name="Lind"/>{{clear}}
===Animal magnetism=== In 1784, the French [[Royal Commission]] looked into the existence of [[animal magnetism]], comparing the effects of allegedly "magnetized" water with that of plain water.<ref>{{cite book |author=Gauld, Alan |title=A history of hypnotism |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge, UK |year=1992 |isbn=0-521-48329-8 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Donaldson IM |title=Mesmer's 1780 proposal for a controlled trial to test his method of treatment using "animal magnetism" |journal=J R Soc Med |volume=98 |issue=12 |pages=572–5 |date=December 2005 |pmid=16319443 |pmc=1299353 |doi=10.1258/jrsm.98.12.572 |url=http://www.jrsm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=16319443}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Best M, Neuhauser D, Slavin L |title=Evaluating Mesmerism, Paris, 1784: the controversy over the blinded placebo controlled trials has not stopped |journal=Qual Saf Health Care |volume=12 |issue=3 |pages=232–3 |date=June 2003 |pmid=12792017 |pmc=1743715 |url=http://qhc.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=12792017 |doi=10.1136/qhc.12.3.232}}</ref> It did not examine the practices of [[Franz Mesmer]], but examined the significantly different practices of his associate Charles d'Eslon (1739–1786).
=== Perkins tractors=== In 1799, [[John Haygarth]]<ref>{{cite journal |author=Booth C |title=The rod of Aesculapios: John Haygarth (1740–1827) and Perkins' metallic tractors |journal=J Med Biogr |volume=13 |issue=3 |pages=155–61 |date=August 2005 |pmid=16059528 |url=http://jmb.rsmjournals.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=16059528 |doi=10.1258/j.jmb.2005.04-01}}</ref> investigated the efficacy of medical instruments called "[[Perkins tractors]]", by comparing the results from ''dummy'' wooden tractors with a set of allegedly "active" metal tractors, and published his findings in a book ''On the Imagination as a Cause & as a Cure of Disorders of the Body''.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Green SA |title=The origins of modern clinical research |journal=Clin. Orthop. Relat. Res. |volume= |issue=405 |pages=311–9 |date=December 2002 |pmid=12461388 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=Haygarth, J. |title=Of the Imagination, as a Cause and as a Cure of Disorders of the Body; Exemplified by Fictitious Tractors, and Epidemical Convulsions (New Edition, with Additional Remarks) |publisher=Crutwell |location=Bath |year=1801 |url=http://www.jameslindlibrary.org/trial_records/19th_Century/haygarth/pamphlet/haygarth_pamphlet.pdf}}</ref>
=== Flint and placebo active treatment comparison=== In 1863 [[Austin Flint murmur|Austin Flint]] (1812–1886) conducted the first-ever trial that directly compared the efficacy of a dummy simulator with that of an active treatment; although Flint's examination did not compare the two against each other in the same trial. Even so, this was a significant departure from the (then) customary practice of contrasting the consequences of an active treatment with what Flint described as "''the natural history of [an untreated] disease''".<ref name="Finkt">Flint, A., "A Contribution Toward the Natural History of Articular Rheumatism, Consisting of a Report of Thirteen Cases Treated Solely with Palliative Measures", ''American Journal of the Medical Sciences'', Vol.46, (July 1863), pp.17–36. [http://www.jameslindlibrary.org/trial_records/19th_Century/flint/flint_tp.html]</ref>{{Rp|18}}
Flint’s paper is the first time that he terms "placebo" or "placeboic remedy" were used to refer to a dummy simulator in a clinical trial.{{quote|… to secure the moral effect of a remedy given specially for the disease, the patients were placed on the use of a placebo which consisted, in nearly all of the cases, of the tincture of [[quassia]], very largely diluted. This was given regularly, and became well known in my wards as the placeboic remedy for [[rheumatism]].}}
Flint<ref name="Finkt"/>{{Rp|21}} treated 13 hospital inmates who had [[rheumatic fever]]; 11 were "[[Acute (medical)|acute]]", and 2 were "sub-acute". He then compared the results of his dummy "placeboic remedy" with that of the active treatment’s already well-understood results. (Flint had previously tested, and reported on, the active treatment’s efficacy.) There was no significant difference between the results of the active treatment and his "placeboic remedy" in 12 of the cases in terms of disease duration, duration of convalescence, number of joints affected, and emergence of [[Complication (medicine)|complication]]s.<ref name="Finkt"/>{{Rp|32–34}} In the thirteenth case, Flint expressed some doubt whether the particular complications that had emerged (namely, [[pericarditis]], [[endocarditis]], and [[pneumonia]]) would have been prevented if that subject had been immediately given the "active treatment".<ref name="Finkt"/>{{Rp|36}}
=== Jellinek and headache remedy ingredients===
Jellinek in 1946<ref name="Jellinke">Jellinek, E. M. [https://www.jstor.org/pss/3001983 JSTORE "Clinical Tests on Comparative Effectiveness of Analgesic Drugs"], ''Biometrics Bulletin'', Vol.2, No.5, (October 1946), pp.87–91.</ref> was asked to test whether or not the headache drug's overall efficacy would be reduced if certain ingredients were removed. In post-[[World War II]] 1946, pharmaceutical chemicals were restricted, and one U.S. headache remedy manufacturer sold a drug composed of three ingredients: '''a''', '''b''', and '''c''', and chemical '''b''' was in particular short supply.
Jellinek set up a complex trial involving 199 subjects, all of whom suffered from "''frequent headaches''". The subjects were randomly divided into four test groups. He prepared four test drugs, involving various [[permutation]]s of the three drug constituents, with a placebo as a [[scientific control]]. The structure of this trial is significant because, in those days, the only time placebos were ever used "''was to express the efficacy or non-efficacy of a drug in terms of "how much better" the drug was than the "placebo''".<ref name="Jellinke"/>{{Rp|88}} (Note that the trial conducted by Austin Flint is an example of such a drug efficacy vs. placebo efficacy trial.) The four test drugs were identical in shape, size, colour and taste: * Drug '''A''': contained '''a''', '''b''', and '''c'''. * Drug '''B''': contained '''a''' and '''c'''. * Drug '''C''': contained '''a''' and '''b'''. * Drug '''D''': a 'simulator', contained "ordinary [[lactic acid|lactate]]".
Each time a subject had a headache, they took their group’s designated test drug, and recorded whether their headache had been relieved (or not). Although "some subjects had only three headaches in the course of a two-week period while others had up to ten attacks in the same period", the data showed a "great consistency" across all subjects<ref name="Jellinke"/>{{Rp|88}} Every two weeks the groups’ drugs were changed; so that by the end of eight weeks, all groups had tested all the drugs. The stipulated drug (i.e., '''A''', '''B''', '''C''', or '''D''') was taken as often as necessary over each two-week period, and the two-week sequences for each of the four groups were: #'''A''', '''B''', '''C''', '''D''' #'''B''', '''A''', '''D''', '''C''' #'''C''', '''D''', '''A''', '''B''' #'''D''', '''C''', '''B''', '''A'''.
Over the entire population of 199 subjects, there were 120 "''subjects reacting to placebo''" and 79 "''subjects not reacting to placebo''".<ref name="Jellinke"/>{{Rp|89}}
On initial analysis, there was no difference between the self-reported "success rates" of Drugs '''A''', '''B''', and '''C''' (84%, 80%, and 80% respectively) (the "success rate" of the simulating placebo Drug '''D''' was 52%); and, from this, it appeared that ingredient '''b''' was completely unnecessary.
However, further analysis on the trial demonstrated that ingredient '''b''' made a significant contribution to the remedy’s efficacy. Examining his data, Jellinek discovered that there was a very significant difference in responses between the 120 placebo-responders and the 79 non-responders. The 79 non-responders' reports showed that if they were considered as an entirely separate group, there was a significant difference the "success rates" of Drugs '''A''', '''B''', and '''C''': viz., 88%, 67%, and 77%, respectively. And because this significant difference in relief from the test drugs could only be attributed to the presence or absence of ingredient '''b''', he concluded that ingredient '''b''' was essential.
Two conclusions came from this trial: * Jellinek,<ref name="Jellinke"/>{{Rp|90}} having identified 120 "placebo reactors", went on to suppose that all of them may have been suffering from either "''psychological headaches''" (with or without attendant "''[[hypochondria]]sis''") or "''true physiological headaches [which were] accessible to suggestion''". Thus, according to this view, the degree to which a "placebo response" is present tends to be an index of the [[Psychosomatic illness|psychogenic]] origins of the condition in question.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Lasagna L, Mosteller F, von Felsinger JM, Beecher HK |title=A study of the placebo response |journal=Am. J. Med. |volume=16 |issue=6 |pages=770–9 |date=June 1954 |pmid=13158365 |doi=10.1016/0002-9343(54)90441-6 }}</ref>{{Rp|777}} * It indicated that, whilst any given placebo was inert, a ''responder'' to that particular placebo may be responding for a wide number of reasons unconnected with the drug's active ingredients; and, from this, it could be important to pre-[[Screening (medicine)|screen]] potential test populations, and treat those manifesting a placebo-response as a special group, or remove them altogether from the test population!
=== MRC and randomized trials=== It used to be thought<ref>{{cite journal |author=Yoshioka A |title=Use of randomisation in the Medical Research Council's clinical trial of streptomycin in pulmonary tuberculosis in the 1940s |journal=BMJ |volume=317 |issue=7167 |pages=1220–3 |date=October 1998 |pmid=9794865 |pmc=1114162 |url=http://bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=9794865 |doi=10.1136/bmj.317.7167.1220}}</ref> that the first-ever randomized clinical trial was the trial<ref>{{cite journal |title=Streptomycin treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis |journal=Br Med J |volume=2 |issue=4582 |pages=769–82 |date=October 1948 |pmid=18890300 |pmc=2091872 |doi=10.1136/bmj.2.4582.769 }} [http://www.jameslindlibrary.org/trial_records/20th_Century/1940s/MRC_bmj/MRC_bmj_kp.html see also]</ref> conducted by the [[Medical Research Council (UK)|Medical Research Council]] (MRC) in 1948 into the efficacy of [[streptomycin]] in the treatment of [[pulmonary tuberculosis]]. In this trial, there were two test groups: #those "''treated by [[streptomycin]] and [[bed-rest]]''", and #those "''[treated] by bed-rest alone''" (the control group). What made this trial novel was that the subjects were randomly allocated to their test groups. The up-to-that-time practice was to allocate subjects alternately to each group, based on the order in which they presented for treatment. This practice could be [[Bias of an estimator|biased]], because those admitting each patient knew to which group that patient would be allocated (and so the decision to admit or not admit a specific patient might be influenced by the experimenter's knowledge of the nature of their illness, and their knowledge of the group to which they would occupy).
Recently, an earlier MRC trial on the antibiotic patulin on the course of common colds<ref>{{cite journal |title=Clinical trial of patulin in the common cold. 1944 |journal=Int J Epidemiol |volume=33 |issue=2 |pages=243–6 |date=April 2004 |pmid=15082620 |doi=10.1093/ije/dyh028 |url=http://ije.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/33/2/243 |author1=Patulin Clinical Trials Committee, Medical Research Council}}</ref> has been suggested to have been the first randomized trial.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Chalmers I, Clarke M |title=Commentary: the 1944 patulin trial: the first properly controlled multicentre trial conducted under the aegis of the British Medical Research Council |journal=Int J Epidemiol |volume=33 |issue=2 |pages=253–60 |date=April 2004 |pmid=15082623 |doi=10.1093/ije/dyh162 |url=http://ije.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=15082623}}</ref> Another early and until recently overlooked randomized trial was published on strophanthin in a local Finnish journal in 1946.<ref>{{cite web |author=Hemminki E |title=Commentary on an early placebo controlled trial in Finland |year=2005 |publisher=The James Lind Library |url=http://www.jameslindlibrary.org/trial_records/20th_Century/1940s/elvainio_et_al/elvainio_commentary.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828040111/http://www.jameslindlibrary.org/trial_records/20th_Century/1940s/elvainio_et_al/elvainio_commentary.html |archivedate=2008-08-28 |df= }}</ref>
== Declaration of Helsinki== From the time of the [[Hippocratic Oath]] questions of the ethics of medical practice have been widely discussed, and codes of practice have been gradually developed as a response to advances in scientific medicine. The '''[[Nuremberg Code]]''', which was issued in August 1947, as a consequence of the so-called [[Doctors' Trial]] which examined the [[Nazi human experimentation|human experimentation]] conducted by [[Nazism|Nazi]] doctors during [[World War II]], offers ten principles for legitimate medical research, including [[informed consent]], absence of [[coercion]], and [[Beneficence (ethics)|beneficence]] towards experiment participants.
In 1964, the [[World Medical Association]] issued the '''[[Declaration of Helsinki]]''',[https://web.archive.org/web/20090220183350/http://www.wma.net/e/policy/b3.htm] which specifically limited its directives to health research by physicians, and emphasized a number of additional conditions in circumstances where "''medical research is combined with medical care''". The significant difference between the 1947 '''Nuremberg Code''' and the 1964 '''Declaration of Helsinki''' is that the first was a set of principles that was ''suggested'' '''to''' the medical profession by the "Doctors’ Trial" judges, whilst the second was ''imposed'' '''by''' the medical profession upon itself. Paragraph 29 of the Declaration makes specific mention of placebos:
{{quotation|29. The benefits, risks, burdens and effectiveness of a new method should be tested against those of the best current prophylactic, diagnostic, and therapeutic methods. This does not exclude the use of placebo, or no treatment, in studies where no proven prophylactic, diagnostic or therapeutic method exists.}}
In 2002, World Medical Association issued the following elaborative announcement:
{{quotation|Note of clarification on paragraph 29 of the WMA Declaration of Helsinki<br/><br/>The WMA hereby reaffirms its position that extreme care must be taken in making use of a placebo-controlled trial and that in general this methodology should only be used in the absence of existing proven therapy. However, a placebo-controlled trial may be ethically acceptable, even if proven therapy is available, under the following circumstances: :— Where for compelling and scientifically sound methodological reasons its use is necessary to determine the efficacy or safety of a prophylactic, diagnostic or therapeutic method; or :— Where a prophylactic, diagnostic or therapeutic method is being investigated for a minor condition and the patients who receive placebo will not be subject to any additional risk of serious or irreversible harm. All other provisions of the Declaration of Helsinki must be adhered to, especially the need for appropriate ethical and scientific review.}}
In addition to the requirement for informed consent from all drug-trial participants, it is also standard practice to inform all test subjects that they may receive the drug being tested or that they may receive the placebo.
==Non-drug treatments== "Talking therapies" (such as [[hypnotherapy]], [[psychotherapy]], counseling, and non-drug [[psychiatry]]) are now required to have scientific [[Verification and validation|validation]] by clinical trial. However, there is controversy over what might or might not be an appropriate placebo for such therapeutic treatments. In 2005, the ''Journal of Clinical Psychology'', devoted an issue <ref>[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jclp.v61:7/issuetoc]</ref> to the issue of "''The Placebo Concept in Psychotherapy''" that contained a range of contributions to this question. As the abstract of one paper <ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1002/jclp.20133 | volume=61 | title=Moving from empirically supported treatment lists to practice guidelines in psychotherapy: The role of the placebo concept | year=2005 | journal=Journal of Clinical Psychology | pages=893–908 | author=Herbert James D}}</ref> noted: <blockquote>Unlike within the domain of medicine, in which the logic of placebos is relatively straightforward, the concept of placebo as applied to psychotherapy is fraught with both conceptual and practical problems.</blockquote>
== See also == * [[Academic clinical trials]] * [[Bioethics]] * [[Clinical data acquisition]] * [[Clinical trial management]] * [[Confounding factor]] * [[Experimental design]] * [[Medical ethics]] * [[Philosophy of medicine]] * [[Randomized controlled trial]] * [[Scientific control]] * [[Scientific method]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{wiktionary|placebo}} * [http://www.jameslindlibrary.org/index.html James Lind Library] A source of historical texts on fair tests of treatments in health care.

{{Multiple issues| {{Advert|date=October 2014}} {{more citations needed|date=October 2014}} }}
{{Infobox company | name = Planmeca Oy | logo = Planmeca_logo.jpg | logo_size = 220px | type = [[Osakeyhtiö]] | foundation = [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] (1971) | founder = {{flatlist| * [[Heikki Kyöstilä]] }} | location_city = Helsinki, Finland | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{plainlist| * Heikki Kyöstilä (Chairman & CEO)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planmeca.com/fi/Yritys/management/ |title=Tervehdys toimitusjohtajaltamme |website=Planmeca |accessdate=July 1, 2015}}</ref> }} | industry = {{unbulleted list|Dental Equipment & Supplies}} |revenue = USD $ 850 million (2015)<ref name="finance">{{cite web|url=http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/revenue-financial.Planmeca_Oy.931a52eb361f03a7.html |title=Planmeca Oy Revenue and Financial Data |accessdate=February 16, 2016}}</ref> |net_income = USD $122.3 million (2015)<ref name="finance">{{cite web|url=http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/revenue-financial.Planmeca_Oy.931a52eb361f03a7.html |title=Planmeca Oy Revenue and Financial Data |accessdate=February 16, 2016}}</ref> | num_employees = 2,700 (2014)<ref name="employee_num">{{cite web|url=http://www.planmeca.com/fi/Yritys/ |title=Planmeca − Better care through innovation |website=planmeca.com |accessdate=July 1, 2015}}</ref> | subsid = {{flatlist| * [[Plandent]] * [[Planmed]] * [[LM-Instruments]] * [[Opus Systemer]] * [[Triangle furniture Systems]] }} | homepage = {{URL|https://www.planmeca.com}} }} '''Planmeca''', established in 1971, is a Finnish manufacturer of high-tech dental team, 3D digital imaging devices and software.
Planmeca’s product lines are organised in
* dental care units * dental X-ray units * digital imaging and software applications.
Planmeca offers integrated product concepts consisting of a dental unit, digital imaging equipment and software. Planmeca works in close co-operation with dental universities and institutions.
Planmeca’s products are designed and manufactured in Helsinki, Finland, and distributed worldwide via a network of dealers operating around the world. More than 98% of Planmeca’s production is exported to over 100 countries.
== History ==
Planmeca was founded by [[Heikki Kyöstilä]] in 1971. Kyöstilä is the president and owner of Planmeca.
In the 1970s, Planmeca manufactured dental stools and instrument cabinets, and created its first patient chair and dental unit.
The 1980s was a decade of international expansion and subsidiaries were established abroad. Planmeca introduced a microprocessor-controlled dental chair, panoramic X-ray device and dental unit.
In the 1990s, Planmeca introduced a dental unit with an integrated patient chair. The decade was also an era of digital progress – Planmeca introduced an integrated information technology system for a digital dental practice, the all in one -concept. The concept allowed instant access to all digital clinical patient information at chair side via one software.
In the 2000s, Planmeca introduced a dental unit that could be converted from right- to left-handed use with motorised movements as well as the Planmeca Romexis software for processing patient information, dental unit’s user activities and images. Planmeca also introduced a new SCARA technology in its X-ray units, which enabled free formation of imaging geometry.
In the 2010s, the concept of ''Digital perfection'' was launched. The combination of a digital intraoral scan, a 3D X-ray (CBVT) and a 3D facial photo provides comprehensive information on the patient’s anatomy.
== Co-operation with universities ==
Cooperative work between Planmeca and universities in product and software development is widespread. Planmeca offers solutions designed especially for teaching environments. Planmeca has supplied dental units and X-ray units to universities and hospitals around the world.
== Planmeca Group ==
Planmeca Oy is the parent company of Planmeca Group. The Group operates in the field of health care and consists of six companies. The Group employs approximately 2,650 people worldwide and the estimated turnover for 2014 amounts to MEUR 800. The headquarters is located in Helsinki, Finland.
In addition to '''Planmeca Oy''', the companies belonging to Planmeca Group are: [[Planmed]] Oy, a manufacturer of mammography and orthopaedic imaging equipment, '''Plandent Oy''', a full-service dental supply company, '''LM-Instruments Oy''', a manufacturer of dental hand instruments, '''Opus Systemer AS''', a developer of dental software solutions and '''Triangle Furniture Systems Inc'''., a manufacturer of dental practice cabinetry solutions.{{clarify|date=August 2012}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * http://www.planmeca.com/

revision.text:
[[Image:Päijännetunneli.svg|thumb|250px|Map of the Päijänne Water Tunnel.
'''1.''' Asikkalanselkä
'''2.''' Kalliomäki water distribution station
'''3.''' Korpimäki water pump station
'''4.''' Artificial lake of Silvola ]] The '''Päijänne Water Tunnel''' ({{Lang-fi|'''Päijännetunneli'''}}, {{Lang-sv|'''Päijännetunneln'''}}), located in [[Southern Finland]], is the world's second longest [[tunnel]] (after the [[Delaware Aqueduct]] in the USA). It is {{convert|120|km|mi|sp=us}} long and runs 30–100 meters under the surface in [[bedrock]].{{cite web|title=The water comes from Päijänne|url=https://www.hsy.fi/en/experts/water-services/water-treatment-plants/Pages/the-water-comes-from-paijanne.aspx|website=Helsinki Region Environmental Services Authority HSY|accessdate=24 February 2017}}{{cite journal|last1=Hukka|first1=J. J.|last2=Juuti|first2=P. S.|last3=Katko|first3=T. S.|last4=Seppala|first4=O. T.|title=Many Ps Needed for Sustainable Water Services: Expansion of the Scope of Public-Private Partnerships|journal=Public Works Management & Policy|date=1 October 2006|volume=11|issue=2|pages=104–109|doi=10.1177/1087724X06294063}} The purpose of the tunnel is to provide [[fresh water]] for the million plus people in Southern Finland in the cities of [[Helsinki]], [[Espoo]], [[Vantaa]], [[Hyvinkää]], [[Järvenpää]], [[Kerava]], [[Kauniainen]], [[Kirkkonummi]], [[Sipoo]], and [[Tuusula]]. The former [[Porvoon maalaiskunta|Porvoo Rural Municipality]], now merged with the municipality of [[Porvoo]], also took part in the building of the scheme but has never drawn water from it for domestic use. The tunnel starts at [[Asikkalanselkä]] in [[Lake Päijänne]], which is the second largest lake in Finland, with an area of 1,080 square kilometres. The tunnel slopes slightly downhill so that water flows naturally. Water from the southern portion of Lake Päijänne is of rather good quality at the [[Water tunnel (physical infrastructure)|water tunnel]] intake and is usually drinkable without processing. The tunnel ends at the Silvola [[reservoir]] in Vantaa in the [[Greater Helsinki]] area. From the reservoir covering 0.5 square kilometres, water is pumped to water treatment plants in [[Pitkäkoski]] and [[Vanhakaupunki]]. Since the constant low temperature in the deep tunnel ensures high quality during transport, only minimal processing is required before use. Tunnel construction started in 1972 and was completed in 1982 at a cost of approximately €200 million (adjusted for inflation).{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinginvesi.fi/paijanne/alltypes.asp?menu_id=70|title=Yleistä Päijänne-tunnelista|publisher=Helsingin vesi|language=Finnish|accessdate=2008-10-12}} In 1999 and 2001, portions of the tunnel required repair due to rock falls.{{cite journal|last1=Mikkola|first1=Jannis|last2=Viitala|first2=Raimo|title=Cave-ins in the Päijänne Tunnel and their repair|journal=Tunnelling and Underground Space Technology|date=April 2000|volume=15|issue=2|pages=129–138|doi=10.1016/S0886-7798(00)00040-7}}{{cite book|last1=Lipponen|first1=Annukka|title=Topographical, structural and geophysical characterization of fracture zones: implications for groundwater flow and vulnerability|date=2006|publisher=Finnish Environment Institute|location=Helsinki|isbn=952-11-2346-X|url=https://helda.helsinki.fi/handle/10138/39349}} In 2008, the tunnel underwent an extensive renovation. The southern part of the tunnel was reinforced in order to prevent [[cave-in]]s. During the renovation, from April 15 to December 31, 2008, the raw water for the [[Greater Helsinki]] metropolitan area was drawn from the [[Vantaanjoki|Vantaa River]]. The tunnel has a cross section of 16 square metres (wide enough for a truck) and enables a water flow of 10 cubic metres per second. At current water usage rates, treatment plants take water at a rate of about 3.1 cubic metres per second for drinking water processing. The tunnel can be used as an emergency water reserve during water supply disruption. __NOTOC__ ==Gallery== Image:Päijänne.png|Location of [[Lake Päijänne]] in [[Finland]]. Image:Silvolan tekojärvi 1.jpg|The artificial lake of [[Silvola]], where the Päijänne Water Tunnel ends. ==See also== *[[List of further tunnels by length]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060214235435/http://www.mtry.org/eng_html/eng_tekniset_tilat.htm Finnish Tunnelling Association, Päijänne Water Tunnel] *[http://www.psv-hrv.fi Pääkaupunkiseudun Vesi Oy] {{coord missing|Finland}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Paijanne Water Tunnel}} [[Category:Water tunnels]] [[Category:Water supply and sanitation in Finland]] [[Category:Tunnels in Finland]] [[Category:Tunnels completed in 1982]] [[Category:Päijänne]] [[Category:1982 establishments in Finland]]
