[[Denny Lawrence]] | creative_director = | starring = (see detailed cast and character list below) | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = Australia | language = English | num_seasons = 8 | num_episodes = 1,396 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | editor = | location = [[TCN-9]] [[Willoughby, New South Wales]] | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 25 minutes | company = [[Reg Grundy Organisation]] | distributor = [[FremantleMedia]] | channel = [[Nine Network]] | picture_format = 4.3 PAL | audio_format = Stereo | first_run = | first_aired = {{start date|1976|11|8|df=yes}} | last_aired = {{end date|1983|3|30|df=yes}} | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = }} '''''The Young Doctors''''' is an Australian early-evening [[soap opera]]. The series was set in the fictional Albert Memorial hospital and primarily concerned with romances between younger members of the hospital staff, rather than typical medical issues and procedures. It screened on the [[Nine Network]] from Monday, 8 November 1976 until Wednesday, 30 March 1983. The program was shown in numerous international locations, particularly throughout the United Kingdom and North America, and also in France and Spain. ==History== The series was created and produced by the [[Reg Grundy Organisation]] and started a week earlier than the Nine Network's other soap opera, ''[[The Sullivans]]'', which was produced by [[Crawford Productions]]. [[Nine Network]] made it clear only one of the series would be kept after 13 weeks. After the 13-week trial period ''The Sullivans'' (which had a budget which was three times bigger than ''The Young Doctors'') emerged as the critical success, so ''The Young Doctors'' was cancelled. Fans of ''The Young Doctors'' lobbied Channel 9, who reversed their decision. ''The Young Doctors'' continued in its 6.00 pm slot and had a successful run. After several years, many long running characters left the series and in the final season during 1982 several new cast members were added. Producer and creator [[Alan Coleman]] also left, and was replaced by Sue Masters shortly before the series finished production in late 1982. Masters went on to produce Grundy's stablemate ''[[Prisoner (TV series)|Prisoner]]'' from 1983; several ''The Young Doctors'' cast members, including [[Judy McBurney]], [[Genevieve Lemon]], [[Babs McMillan]] and [[Peter Bensley]] also went into leading roles in ''Prisoner'' after ''The Young Doctors'' finished. The advent of one-day cricket led to Channel 9 moving the show around the schedules. These factors contributed to a decline in ratings which saw the series cancelled in late 1982. The final episode was aired in March 1983.{{cite web |url=http://www.theyoungdoctors.com/show/history.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807123809/http://www.theyoungdoctors.com/show/history.htm |archivedate=7 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }} When the series ended after 1396 episodes, it held the record of Australia's longest-running commercial television drama serial, which was previously held by ''[[Number 96 (TV series)|Number 96]]''. This was later surpassed by ''[[A Country Practice]]'' and then ''[[Neighbours]]'', which is currently the longest-running Australian drama serial. ''The Young Doctors'' also holds the distinction, rare among long-running Australian dramas, of having never won any sort of television award. Popular Actress [[Peta Toppano]] who appeared in the first season of ''Prisoner'' had also previously appeared in ''The Young Doctors'' for just over a year. One of the more popular cast members was [[Gwen Plumb]], a recipient of the [[British Empire Medal]] and [[Member of the Order of Australia|AM]] recipient for her service to the arts and communities service, who portrayed gossippy kiosk lady Ada Simmonds for the length of the series. The original cast members [[Lyn James]] who portrayed the doctors secretary Helen Gordon and [[Tim Page (actor)|Tim Page]] who portrays Dr. Grahame Steele, appeared to the end of the series, as did [[Judy McBurney]] as Nurse Tania Livingstone who first appeared in episode 40. The relatively long-running serial also achieved modest international [[cult]] success, particularly in the United Kingdom, where it aired in a daytime slot on the commercial [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] network. The programme was shown regionally, meaning each region was free to show the series as and when they liked. [[Central Independent Television]] were the first ITV region to start the serial from January 1982. Most other regions gradually followed over the next few years and [[Yorkshire Television]] were the last to start in 1988. Central were the first to finish in August 1992, and [[Westcountry Television]] was the last ITV region to air ''Young Doctors'' in December 1995. ==Story and setting== Despite the medical setting, medical procedures rarely figured in storylines, with most of the stories and plots focusing more on the personal life and romances of the staff. The local Club ''Bunnys'' was another venue for the staff to mingle. ==Cast== {{Main article|List of The Young Doctors cast members}} {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ==Doctors== * Dr. Raymond Shaw – [[Alfred Sandor]] * Dr. Graham Steele – [[Tim Page (actor)|Tim Page]] * Dr. Brian Denham – [[Michael Beecher (actor)|Michael Beecher]] * Dr. John Forrest – [[Alan Dale]] * Dr. Jim Howard – [[John Dommett]] * Dr. Greg Mason – [[Mark Holden]] * Dr. Craig Rothwell – [[John Walton (actor)|John Walton]] * Dr. Gail Henderson – [[Peta Toppano]] * Dr. Chris Piper – [[Bartholomew John]] * Dr. Mike Newman – [[Peter Bensley]] * Dr. Ben Fielding – [[Eric Oldfield]] * Dr. Peter Holland – [[Peter Lochran]] * Dr. Tony Garcia – [[Tony Alvarez (actor)|Tony Alvarez]] * Dr. Rod Langley – [[Chris Orchard]] * Dr. Liz Kennedy – [[Rebecca Gilling]] * Dr. Ian Parrish – [[Serge Lazareff]] * Dr. Susan Richards – [[Judy Lynne]] * Dr. Robyn Porter – [[Joy Chambers]] * Dr. Andrew Baxter – [[Andrew Sharp (actor)|Andrew Sharp]] * Dr. Dan Wheatley – [[John Hamblin]] * Dr. Richard Quinlan – [[Vince Martin (actor)|Vince Martin]] * Dr. Judith-Anne Napier – [[Carole Skinner]] * Dr. Nick Barrett – [[Adrian Van Den Bok]] * Dr. Russell Edwards – [[Peter Cousens]] * Dr. Lance Wilkinson – [[Michael Gow]] * Dr. Andrew Baxter – [[Andrew Sharp (actor)|Andrew Sharp]] * Dr. Matt Blake – [[Nick Holland]] * Dr. Vincent Snape – [[Brian Moll]] * Dr. David Henderson – [[Graham Harvey (actor)|Graham Harvey]] * Dr. Vicki Daniels – [[Sally Tayler]] ==Sisters== * Sister Grace Scott – [[Cornelia Frances]] * Sister Tania Livingston – [[Judy McBurney]] * Sister Eve Turner – [[Anne Lucas]] * Sister Vivienne Jeffries – [[Diana McLean]] * Sister Suzanne Gibbs – [[Susanne Stuart]] * Sister Erin Cosgrove – [[Babs McMillan]] {{col-2}} ==Nurses== * Nurse Jo Jo Adams – [[Delvene Delaney]] * Nurse Jill Gordon – [[Joanne Samuel]] * Nurse Kate Rhodes – [[Ros Wood]] * Nurse Kim Barrington – [[Lynda Stoner]] * Nurse Lisa Brooks – [[Paula Duncan]] * Nurse Julie Holland – [[Lisa Aldenhoven]] * Nurse Julie Warner – [[Margaret Nelson]] * Nurse Virginia Mason – [[Rosie Bailey]] * Nurse Angela Parry – [[Robyn Gibbes]] * Nurse Sherry Andrews – [[Karen Pini]] * Nurse Jody Carter – [[Julie Wilson]] * Nurse Yvonne Davies – [[Margaret Laurence (actress)|Margaret Laurence]] * Nurse Viki Rayner – [[Debbie Baile]] * Nurse Martin Price – [[Gregory Apps]] * Nurse Maggie Gordon – [[Jackie Woodburne]] * Nurse Dolly Davis – [[Christine Harris (actress)|Christine Harris]] * Nurse Linda Wilson – [[Julie Nihill]] * Nurse Genevieve Ridgway – [[Susan Stenmark]] * Nurse Zelda Baker – [[Genevieve Lemon]] * Nurse Diana Trent – [[Julianne White]] ==Hospital staff== * Ada Simmonds – [[Gwen Plumb]] * Helen Gordon – [[Lyn James]] * Dennis Jamieson – [[Chris King (actor)|Chris King]] * Mark Holland – [[Robert Leys]] * Caroline Jamieson – [[Kim Wran]] * 'Flint' Stone – [[Robert Korosy]] * Toni Sheffield – [[Tottie Goldsmith]] * Trixie Rogers – [[Bunney Brooke]] * Gael Hogan – [[Tracy Mann]] * Frances Taylor – [[Briony Behets]] * Judy Sutton – [[Kathleen Brinson]] ==Other miscellaneous characters== * 'Bunny' Howard – [[Ugly Dave Gray]] * Laura Denham – [[Joanna Moore-Smith]] * Anne-Marie Austin – [[Judi Connelli]] * Hilary Templeton – [[Abigail (actress)|Abigail]] * Philip Winter – [[Noel Trevarthen]] * Edna Curtis – [[Vivienne Benson-Young]] * Georgie Saint – [[Mark Hembrow]] * Ken Hansen – [[Joe Hasham]] * Tom Garrett – [[Chard Hayward]] * Erika Hoffman – [[Karen Petersen]] * Barry Cox - [[Peter DeSalis]] {{col-end}} ==Broadcast== {{unreferenced section|date=August 2018}} In the United Kingdom the programme was acquired by 13 of the 14 weekday members of the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] Network, [[Scottish Television]] never purchased the series. Most of the ITV regions initially screened ''The Young Doctors'' at their own regional pace in their 15:30 slot on Mondays and Tuesdays with ''[[Sons and Daughters (Australian TV series)|Sons and Daughters]]'' on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays. * [[ITV Central|Central Television]] pioneered the programme in their Tuesday and Thursday 12:30 slot from January 1982 (but it was quickly moved to the afternoon Monday and Tuesday 15:45 slot) while all the other ITV contractors were screening ''[[The Sullivans]]''. This was then increased to a daily 15:30 slot until ''[[Sons and Daughters (Australian TV series)|Sons and Daughters]] ''began in February 1983 and ''The Young Doctors'' shared the slot airing on Mondays and Tuesdays. This continued until 1987 when Central returned the programme to 12:00 and then 12.35 to allow ''The Young Doctors'' and ''Sons and Daughters'' to be stripped Monday to Friday in their respective slots. Following the end of ''[[Sons and Daughters (Australian TV series)|Sons and Daughters]]'' in early December 1988, ''The Young Doctors'' returned to 15.30 at the end of 1988, usually airing Tuesday to Friday until ''Families'' began in April 1990, which took the Monday and Tuesday 15:30 slot. ''The Young Doctors'' was finally moved to 14:50, Monday to Thursday in 1990, and finished 15 August 1992. Central was the first region to complete the series and it was replaced by ''G.P,'' an Australian series set in a busy inner-city clinic. After 6 months, ''G.P.'' was replaced by the New Zealand Medical drama ''Shortland Street'' in March 1993; a new series made by the Grundy Organization, just like ''The Young Doctors'' was. * [[ITV Wales & West|HTV]] started the series on Tuesday, 4 January 1983 and screened the series regularly on Mondays and Tuesdays, finishing on 18 April 1994. * [[Granada Television]] and [[Border Television]] switched the broadcast pattern around, and screened ''The Young Doctors'' on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays instead, finishing at Easter 1993 at 3.20pm. * [[Anglia Television]] started on 3 September 1984, going out Mondays and Tuesdays at 15:30 until 17 April 1990, then changed to Wednesdays and Thursdays from 25 April 1990. It was then moved to Thursdays and Fridays from Friday 6 July 1990 and an additional Wednesday episode returns in January 1991. Then Mondays to Fridays from January 1992 and finally, Thursdays and Fridays at 13.55 until Friday, 2 June 1995. * [[Thames Television]] and [[LWT]] in London started screening the series initially at 17:15 on Thursdays and Fridays from 23 June 1983 until 1 September 1984, before switching the series to 15:30 slot, to allow ''[[Blockbusters (UK game show)|Blockbusters]]'' the slot. From this point onwards, only Thames broadcast the series. When [[Carlton Television]] took over in January 1993, the series was dropped for 6 months to allow backlog of ''Blockbusters'' episodes to be aired, ''The Young Doctors'' returned daily on 7 June 1993 concluding the programme as an 80minute special from 13:55 on Friday 30 December 1994. * [[Television South West|TSW]] Started the series on 1 April 1985, Monday and Fridays at 17:15 until 8 July, when it was moved to 15.30 slot. On 17 October 1988, the series moves to 12:30 on Mondays and Wednesdays but due to network programming resulted in the series becoming weekly during 1989/1990, but returned to twice a week by the end 1990. [[Westcountry Television]] took over in 1993, and continued twice a week until early 1994 when it was increased to three times a week until 20 December 1995 when episode 1101 was broadcast. The series was never completed, even though Westcountry were the last region to still be showing it. * Years after most of the other regions [[Yorkshire Television]] started the series in October 1988, going out five times a week. In January 1993, they had to skip 215 episodes to enable them to catch up to [[Tyne Tees Television]], as from January 1993, both regions screened exactly the same material. It aired daily at 15:20, until January 1994 when the Friday episode was dropped until the series ended on Thursday 15 December 1994. * Grampian Television started on Monday, 14 November 1983, increased to 4 episode per week by 1991, and finished Friday, 30 September 1994. * ''The Young Doctors'' was also aired on [[Sky1|Sky Channel]] from Monday, 6 February 1989. It originally transmitted at 17:00, and from July 1989 when the channel relaunced as [[Sky One]], ''The Young Doctors'' aired regularly at 15.15–15.45 before it moved to the mid-morning 10.30 slot in February 1990. When Sky purchased the newer Australian soap ''[[E Street]]'' in April 1992, they eventually cancelled ''The Young Doctors'' after around 900 episodes in July to accommodate an afternoon repeat of the American medical series ''[[St Elsewhere]].'' ==Remake== In November 2007, the [[Nine Network]] announced plans to remake the series in conjunction with [[FremantleMedia]]. Originally, it was set to be broadcast in 2008 but due to script delays, the premiere date had been pushed back to 2009. The remake was set to be named ''Young Doctors'' (minus "The"). However, at the end of 2008, the [[Nine Network]] officially passed on the idea. The network decided against the remake, instead, confirming a second series of the popular Australian drama [[Underbelly (TV series)|Underbelly]]. [[FremantleMedia]] is currently searching for another television station to contract the programme.[http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,22775803-5006009,00.html New life for Young Doctors | The Daily Telegraph] ==DVD== Selected episodes of the serial were released on DVD in October 2006, under the title of ''The Best Romances''. A second set of selected episodes, under the title of ''Classic Cliffhangers'', was released in February 2008. In 1994, prior to the DVDs, a VHS was edited in the UK by "NTV entertainment" collecting episodes A, B (pilots) & 1. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0074077|title=The Young Doctors}} *{{tv.com show|the-young-doctors|The Young Doctors}} *[http://members.ozemail.com.au/~fangora/doctors.html Aussie Soap Archive: The Young Doctors] — Overview and Review *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061029091922/http://www.thesoapshow.com/specialshows/main.htm Documentary celebrating 30 year anniversary, with cast interviews] *[http://colsearch.nfsa.afc.gov.au/nfsa/search/display/display.w3p;adv=yes;group=;groupequals=;holdingType=;page=0;parentid=;query=138344;querytype=;rec=0;resCount=10 The Young Doctors at the National Film and Sound Archive] {{Mark Holden}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Young Doctors, The}} [[Category:Australian television soap operas]] [[Category:Australian medical television series]] [[Category:Nine Network shows]] [[Category:Television series produced by The Reg Grundy Organisation]] [[Category:1976 Australian television series debuts]] [[Category:1983 Australian television series endings]] [[Category:1970s Australian television series]] [[Category:1980s Australian television series]] [[Category:Television shows set in Sydney]] [[Category:English-language television programs]]

page.title: Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Use Irish English|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox referendum |name = Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland |title = To permit the Oireachtas to legislate for the regulation of termination of pregnancy |location = {{flag|Ireland}} |date = Referendum: {{Start date|2018|05|25|df=y}}
In force: {{Start date|2018|09|18|df=y}} |yes = 1,429,981 |yespct = 66.40 |no = 723,632 |nopct = 33.60 |valid = 2,153,613 |validpct = 99.72 |invalid = 6,042 |invalidpct = 0.28 |total = 2,159,655 |turnoutpct = 64.13 |electorate = 3,367,556 |map = File:Abortion referendum 2018.svg |mapdivision= [[Dáil constituencies|Dáil constituency]] |notes = Source: [http://www.referendum.ie/detailed-results/?ref_id=12 referendum.ie] }} The '''Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland''' (previously [[bill (law)|bill]] no. 29 of 2018) is an [[Amendments to the Constitution of Ireland|amendment to the constitution of Ireland]] which permits the [[Oireachtas]] (parliament of Ireland) to legislate for [[abortion]]. The [[Constitution of Ireland|constitution]] had previously prohibited [[abortion]] unless there was a serious risk to the life of the mother. The proposal is often described as the '''Repeal of the Eighth Amendment''', referring to the [[Eighth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|1983 constitutional amendment]] which guarantees the unborn the [[right to life]], making abortion illegal unless the pregnancy is life-threatening. The 2018 bill replaces Article 40.3.3° of the Constitution, which was added in 1983 and [[Irish constitutional referendums, November 1992|amended in 1992]]. The bill was introduced to the Oireachtas on 9 March 2018 by the [[Government of the 32nd Dáil#31st Government of Ireland|Fine Gael minority coalition government]], and completed its passage through both houses on 27 March 2018. It was put to a [[referendum]] on 25 May 2018{{cite news |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/abortion-referendum/government-can-meet-timeline-to-hold-abortion-referendum-donohoe-1.3420911 |title=Government can meet timeline to hold abortion referendum - Donohoe |first1=Vivienne |last1=Clarke |date=9 March 2018 |access-date=9 March 2018 |work=[[The Irish Times]]}} and approved by 66.4% of voters. It took effect once signed into law by the [[Michael D. Higgins|President]] on 18 September 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/ireland/2018/0918/994438-cabinet/|title=Eighth Amendment repealed after bill is signed into law|last=Fitzgerald|first=Martina|date=18 September 2018|work=RTÉ News|access-date=18 September 2018}} ==Background== {{main|Abortion in the Republic of Ireland}} The British [[Offences Against the Person Act 1861#Abortion|Offences Against the Person Act 1861]], which made "unlawful procurement of a miscarriage" a crime, remained in force after Irish independence in 1922. The 1983 [[Eighth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|Eighth Amendment of the Constitution]], which declares "the right to life of the unborn ... equal [to the] right to life of the mother", was instigated by the [[Pro-Life Amendment Campaign]] for fear that the 1861 prohibition might be weakened by liberal legislators or [[Judicial activism|activist judges]].{{cite journal|last1=Quinlan|first1=John A.|title=The Right to Life of the Unborn--An Assessment of the Eighth Amendment to the Irish Constitution|journal=BYU L. Rev.|date=September 1984|issue=3|page=371|url=https://digitalcommons.law.byu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2735&context=lawreview|accessdate=22 May 2018}} The 1992 "X case" ([[Attorney General v. X]]) ruled that abortion is permitted where pregnancy threatens a woman's life, including by risk of suicide. No regulatory framework within the limited scope of the X case judgment was passed until the [[Protection of Life During Pregnancy Act 2013]], impelled by the 2010 [[A, B and C v Ireland]] case in the [[European Court of Human Rights]] and the 2012 [[death of Savita Halappanavar]] after miscarriage.{{cite journal|last1=O'Sullivan|first1=Catherine|first2=Jennifer |last2=Schweppe |first3=Eimear A. |last3=Spain |title=Article 40.3.3° and the Protection of Life During Pregnancy Bill 2013: the impetus for, and process of, legislative change |journal=Irish Journal of Legal Studies|date=20 July 2013|pages=1–17|url=https://ssrn.com/abstract=2304258}} The 2013 act repealed the 1861 act and makes "destruction of unborn human life" a crime. In the three years 2014–2016 a total of 77 legal abortions were performed under the 2013 act.{{cite web|title=Third Annual Report of notifications in accordance with the Protection of Life During Pregnancy Act 2013 laid before the Houses of the Oireachtas |url=https://health.gov.ie/blog/press-release/third-annual-report-of-notifications-in-accordance-with-the-protection-of-life-during-pregnancy-act-2013-laid-before-the-houses-of-the-oireachtas/ |publisher=Department of Health|date=29 June 2017|language=en}} Illegal [[surgical abortion]]s in Ireland have been practically unknown since the UK's [[Abortion Act 1967]] allowed Irish women to travel to Great Britain for a legal abortion. The [[Thirteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|13th]] and [[Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|14th]] amendments to the constitution, passed in 1992 after the X case, guarantee the right to information about foreign abortions and to travel abroad for an abortion. The number of women at UK abortion clinics giving Irish addresses peaked at 6,673 in 2001 and was 3,265 in 2016.{{cite web|title=Abortion in Ireland: Statistics|url=https://www.ifpa.ie/Hot-Topics/Abortion/Statistics|publisher=Irish Family Planning Association|accessdate=22 May 2018|language=en}} The decline is partly due to unregulated use of [[abortion pill]]s illegally delivered from [[online pharmacies]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/abortion-pill-questions-4002257-May2018/|title=How many women in Ireland request abortion pills? How safe are they? Are they illegal?|work=thejournal.ie|date=23 May 2018}} While left-wing parties and feminists opposed the 1983 amendment and have advocated its repeal, this was not supported by the two largest parties for most of the interim, [[Fianna Fáil]] and [[Fine Gael]]. In the 2010s while both parties' leadership opposed broad liberalisation, some accepted the argument for abortion in cases like fatal foetal abnormalities and pregnancy resulting from rape or incest, which are not permitted by the 1983 amendment. These became the focus of campaigning after the 2013 act. The [[Abortion Rights Campaign]], a pro-choice alliance formed in 2012, holds an annual "March for Choice" in Dublin.{{cite news|last1=Ní Aodha|first1=Gráinne|title=How Dublin's March for Choice was reported around the world|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/march-for-choice-international-media-3624566-Oct2017/|accessdate=22 May 2018|work=TheJournal.ie|date=1 October 2017|language=en}} Pro-life groups have countered with a "Rally for Life".{{cite news|title=Tens of thousands march in support of Eighth Amendment|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2017/0701/887020-march-for-life/|accessdate=22 May 2018|work=RTE.ie|date=1 July 2017|language=en}} In the run up to the [[Irish general election, 2016|2016 general election]], a number of parties committed to a referendum to repeal the Eighth Amendment ([[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour]],{{cite web|url=https://www.labour.ie/manifesto/reproductive-healthcare/|publisher=[[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour Party]]|access-date=5 August 2016|title=Reproductive Healthcare|quote=Our plan for the next five years: Hold a referendum to remove Article 40.3.3 (the 8th Amendment) from the Constitution}} [[Green Party (Ireland)|Green Party]],{{cite web|publisher=[[Green Party (Ireland)|Green Party]]|url=https://greenparty.ie/policies/green-party-reproductive-rights-policy/|title=Reproductive Rights|access-date=5 August 2016|quote=The Green Party supports the holding of a referendum to allow the people of Ireland determine whether or not the 8th Amendment should be repealed.}} [[Social Democrats (Ireland)|Social Democrats]],http://astaines.eu/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Social-Democrats-2016-Building-a-Better-Future-2016-2026-Social-Democr.pdf [[Sinn Féin]],{{cite web|url=http://www.sinnfein.ie/contents/39220|quote=Sinn Féin MEP Lynn Boylan joined Amnesty Ireland campaigners and her Sinn Féin colleagues outside Leinster House today calling for a referendum to repeal the 8th amendment.|publisher=[[Sinn Féin]]|title=Sinn Féin support the Amnesty Ireland Repeal the 8th Campaign- Lynn Boylan MEP|access-date=5 August 2016}} and [[Workers' Party of Ireland|Workers' Party]]{{cite web|url=http://workersparty.ie/wpmanifesto/|title=Workers' Party Manifesto|publisher=[[Workers' Party of Ireland|Workers' Party]]}}) and a group of feminist law academics published model legislation to show what a post-Eighth Amendment abortion law could look like.{{Cite journal|last=Enright|first=Mairead|last2=Conway|first2=Vicky|last3=Londras|first3=Fiona de|last4=Donnelly|first4=Mary|last5=Fletcher|first5=Ruth|last6=McDonnell|first6=Natalie|last7=McGuinness|first7=Sheelagh|last8=Murray|first8=Claire|last9=Ring|first9=Sinead|date=2015-06-28|title=General Scheme of Access to Abortion Bill 2015|url=http://journals.kent.ac.uk/index.php/feministsatlaw/article/view/174|journal=Feminists@law|language=en|volume=5|issue=1|issn=2046-9551}} A [[Government of the 32nd Dáil|Fine Gael-led government]] under Taoiseach [[Enda Kenny]] took office after the 2016 election with a programme which promised a randomly selected [[Citizens' Assembly (Ireland)|Citizens' Assembly]] to report on possible changes to the Eighth Amendment, which would be considered by an Oireachtas committee, to whose report the government would respond officially in debates in both houses of the Oireachtas. [[Leo Varadkar]] replaced Enda Kenny as Taoiseach on 14 June 2017 and promised to hold a referendum on abortion in 2018.{{cite web|url=https://inews.co.uk/essentials/news/world/irelands-new-leader-announces-abortion-referendum-despite-popes-visit/|title=Ireland's new leader announces abortion referendum despite Pope visit|date=15 June 2017|publisher=|access-date=4 July 2017}} The Citizens' Assembly, chaired by [[Supreme Court of Ireland|Supreme Court]] judge [[Mary Laffoy]],{{cite web|url=http://www.merrionstreet.ie/en/News-Room/Releases/Government_appoints_Chairperson_to_Citizens_Assembly.html|title=Government appoints Chairperson to Citizens' Assembly|work=MerrionStreet.ie|date=27 July 2016|access-date=5 August 2016}} discussed the issue from November 2016 to April 2017 with invited experts and stakeholders, and voted to recommend repealing the existing text and replacing it with an explicit mandate for the Oireachtas to legislate on abortion.{{cite web|url=https://www.citizensassembly.ie/en/The-Eighth-Amendment-of-the-Constitution/Final-Report-on-the-Eighth-Amendment-of-the-Constitution/Final-Report-on-the-Eighth-Amendment-of-the-Constitution.html|title=Final Report on the Eighth Amendment of the Constitution|work=Citizens' Assembly|date=29 June 2017|access-date=21 January 2018}} It also made recommendations for the consequent legislation, which were more liberal than media commentators had expected.{{cite news|last1=McGreevy|first1=Ronan|title=Why did Citizens’ Assembly take liberal view on abortion?|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/why-did-citizens-assembly-take-liberal-view-on-abortion-1.3138280|accessdate=22 May 2018|work=The Irish Times|date=30 June 2017}} The assembly's report was considered from September to December 2017 by a special Oireachtas committee of 21 members, which also discussed the issue with invited experts; its recommendations by majority vote were broadly similar to those of the assembly.{{cite web|title=Committee on the Eighth Amendment of the Constitution|url=https://www.oireachtas.ie/en/committees/32/eighth-amendment-constitution/|publisher=Oireachtas|accessdate=22 May 2018|language=en-ie|date=8 May 2018}} However, it said that because of difficulties legislating for rape and incest, abortion should be legal up to 12 weeks' gestation without restriction; on the other hand, it did not favour socio-economic grounds for abortion after 12 weeks.{{cite web|author1=Joint Committee on the Eighth Amendment of the Constitution|title=Report|url=https://data.oireachtas.ie/ie/oireachtas/committee/dail/32/joint_committee_on_the_eighth_amendment_of_the_constitution/reports/2017/2017-12-20_report-of-the-joint-committee-on-the-eighth-amendment-of-the-constitution_en.pdf|publisher=Oireachtas|accessdate=22 May 2018|nopp=Y |pages=§§2.19–2.24, 2.37–2.40|format=PDF|date=December 2017}} In January 2018, [[Minister for Health (Ireland)|Minister for Health]] [[Simon Harris (politician)|Simon Harris]] opened the Dáil debate on the committee's report by listing the numbers from each county who travelled to Great Britain for an abortion in 2016.{{cite web |first=Simon |last=Harris |url=http://health.gov.ie/blog/speeches/speech-by-mr-simon-harris-td-minister-for-health-report-of-the-joint-committee-on-the-eighth-amendment-of-the-constitution-dail-eireann/ |publisher=Department of Health |title=Speech by Mr Simon Harris TD, Minister for Health – Report of the Joint Committee on the Eighth Amendment of the Constitution – Dáil Éireann |date=17 January 2018 |access-date=20 January 2018 |quote=In 2016, 3,265 Irish women travelled to the UK alone and we know that Irish women travel to other countries like the Netherlands too.}} [[Fianna Fáil]] leader [[Micheál Martin]] declared that he had changed his view on the issue and gave his support for Repeal of the Eighth Amendment and for the Committee's recommendations.{{cite web |first=Shona |last=Murray |url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/politics/fianna-fil-leader-michel-martin-backs-repeal-of-the-eighth-amendment-36504489.html |publisher=[[Irish Independent]] |title=Fianna Fáil leader Micheál Martin backs repeal of the Eighth Amendment |date=18 January 2018 |access-date=20 January 2018 |quote=Following a long period of reflection and assessment of evidence before the Oireachtas Committee, I believe that we should remove the Eighth Amendment from Bunreacht na hÉireann and I will vote accordingly}} Further action was called into question by a July 2016 [[High Court (Ireland)|High Court]] ruling that a foetus was a child within the meaning of [[Thirty-first Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|Article 42A of the Constitution]], which guarantees [[children's rights]]. The [[Supreme Court of Ireland|Supreme Court]] agreed to expedite the government's [[appeal]] of the decision, and on 7 March 2018 overturned the High Court judgment, ruling that a foetus was not a child and had no rights other than the right to life mentioned in Article 40.3.3.{{cite web|title=M (Immigration - Rights of Unborn) -v- Minister for Justice and Equality & ors : Judgments & Determinations : Courts Service of Ireland|url=http://www.courts.ie/Judgments.nsf/0/2CA87FAB5FD004FF8025824A00329063|website=Courts Service of Ireland|accessdate=22 May 2018}}; {{cite web|title=Statement re. M & ors -v- Minister for Justice and Equality & ors [2018] IESC 14 : Judgments & Determinations : Courts Service of Ireland|url=http://www.courts.ie/Judgments.nsf/0/90885E9539F501F780258250005A2922|website=Courts Service of Ireland|accessdate=22 May 2018}}; {{cite news|last1=O'Donnell|first1=Orla|title=Unborn 'does not have' inherent constitutional rights|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2018/0307/945560-supreme-court-rights-of-unborn/|accessdate=22 May 2018|work=RTE.ie|date=7 March 2018|language=en}} ==Proposed change to the text== The Amendment proposes to replace the text of Article 40.3.3º,{{cite news|url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/viewdoc.asp?DocID=37936|title=Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018|access-date=9 March 2018|publisher=[[Oireachtas|Houses of the Oireachtas]]}} which reads: {{quote frame|The State acknowledges the right to life of the unborn and, with due regard to the equal right to life of the mother, guarantees in its laws to respect, and, as far as practicable, by its laws to defend and vindicate that right. This subsection shall not limit freedom to travel between the State and another state. This subsection shall not limit freedom to obtain or make available, in the State, subject to such conditions as may be laid down by law, information relating to services lawfully available in another state.}} '''Note:''' The first clause was added by the [[Eighth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|Eighth Amendment]] approved by referendum in 1983. The second and third clauses were added by the [[Thirteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|Thirteenth Amendment]] and the [[Fourteenth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|Fourteenth Amendment]] respectively approved by referendum in 1992. As the amendment passed, the subsection will be replaced with the following text: {{quote frame|Provision may be made by law for the regulation of termination of pregnancy.}} ==Proposed subsequent legislation== {{see also |Health (Regulation of Termination of Pregnancy) Bill 2018}} The [[Department of Health (Ireland)|Department of Health]] published a [[policy paper]] on "Regulation of Termination of Pregnancy" on 9 March 2018.{{cite web|url=http://health.gov.ie/blog/publications/policy-paper-on-regulation-of-termination-of-pregnancy/|title=Policy Paper on Regulation of Termination of Pregnancy|publisher=|date=9 March 2018|access-date=9 March 2018}} This provided an outline of the policies for legislation which would repeal and replace the [[Protection of Life During Pregnancy Act 2013]] if the Amendment of Constitution Bill was passed in a referendum. Under this scheme, abortion would be permissible in circumstances where: * there is a risk to the health of a woman, on assessment by two doctors, without a distinction between physical and mental health; * there is a medical emergency, on assessment by one doctor; * there is a foetal condition which is likely to lead to death before or shortly after birth, on the assessment of two doctors; * up to 12 weeks of pregnancy without specific indication, with a time period after an initial assessment by a medical practitioner and the termination procedure. The Policy Paper also proposed that: * medical practitioners would have a right of conscientious objection; * the termination of pregnancy in circumstances other than those under the proposal would be a criminal offence, but that a woman who procures or seeks to procure a termination of pregnancy for herself would not be guilty of an offence. On 26 March 2018, [[Tánaiste]] [[Simon Coveney]] announced he would support legislation on the lines of the policy paper, but suggested that this should be [[Entrenched clause|entrenched]] by requiring a two-thirds [[supermajority]] in the Dáil for any later amendment.{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/varadkar-rules-out-coveney-s-two-third-majority-plan-on-abortion-1.3441754|title=Varadkar rules out Coveney’s two-third majority plan on abortion|last=Bardon|first=Sarah|first2=Vivienne |last2=Clarke |first3=Marie |last3=O'Halloran|date=26 March 2018|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=28 March 2018}} This was aimed at voters prepared to accept the policy-paper regulations but wary of subsequent liberalisation. Coveney's proposal was dismissed as unconstitutional.{{cite news|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/simon-coveneys-plan-for-legal-lock-on-abortion-law-in-tatters-468838.html|title=Simon Coveney's plan for 'legal lock' on abortion law in tatters|last=Ó Cionnaith|first=Fiachra|first2=Daniel |last2=McConnell |first3=Juno |last3=McEnroe|date=28 March 2018|work=[[Irish Examiner]]|accessdate=28 March 2018}} On 27 March 2018, the cabinet agreed the general scheme of the proposed "Regulation of Termination of Pregnancy Bill 2018", which health minister [[Simon Harris (politician)|Simon Harris]] summarised that evening in the Seanad.{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/oireachtas/six-things-to-know-about-the-abortion-bill-1.3442528|title=Six things to know about the abortion Bill|date=27 March 2018|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=28 March 2018}} The scheme was published online the following day.{{cite web|url=http://health.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/General-Scheme-for-Publication.pdf |format=PDF|title=General Scheme of a Bill to Regulate Termination of Pregnancy|date=27 March 2018|publisher=[[Department of Health (Ireland)|Department of Health]]|accessdate=28 March 2018|location=Dublin}} Even after the referendum had passed, "Abortion [would] remain illegal in almost all circumstances until the Oireachtas passes legislation providing otherwise". Health Minister Simon Harris, speaking a few days before the referendum, said the Government hoped to introduce the bill in the Dail in the autumn and to have passed it by the end of 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/harris-aims-for-bill-on-abortion-to-pass-before-end-of-year-1.3506253|title=Harris aims for Bill on abortion to pass before end of year|date=24 May 2018|work=The Irish Times}} ==Oireachtas debate== The Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill was introduced by [[Minister for Health (Ireland)|Minister for Health]] [[Simon Harris (politician)|Simon Harris]]. The debate on the Second Stage began on 9 March 2018.{{cite hansard|jurisdiction=Ireland|hansard=Dáil Debates|title=Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018: Second Stage|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail2018030900003|house=Dáil Éireann|date=9 March 2018}} The Bill passed all stages in the Dáil on 21 March.{{cite hansard|jurisdiction=Ireland|hansard=Dáil Debates|title=Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018: Committee and Remaining Stages (Continued)|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail2018032100056|house=Dáil Éireann|date=21 March 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/oireachtas/abortion-referendum-to-go-ahead-following-d%C3%A1il-vote-1.3435008|title=Abortion referendum to go ahead following Dáil vote|date=21 March 2018|access-date=22 March 2018|first1=Sarah|last1=Bardon|first2=Marie|last2=O'Halloran|first3=Michael|last3=O'Regan|publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]''}} The main vote on the bill was at [[Second reading|second stage]], with 110 in favour and 32 against. Of the 16 who did not vote at second stage, five voted in favour in subsequent votes. At [[committee stage]], there were votes on Section 2 of the bill (98–18) and the [[short title]] (96–20); there was also a vote on the [[Fifth stage|final stage]] (97–25). [[Fianna Fáil]] [[Teachta Dála|TDs]] had a [[conscience vote|free vote]] although [[Micheál Martin]] was reported to be upset at how many voted against the bill.{{cite news|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/micheal-martin-furious-after-five-or-six-tds-lead-fianna-fail-rejection-of-8th-amendment-vote-468632.html|title=Micheál Martin 'furious' after 'five or six' TDs lead Fianna Fáil rejection of 8th Amendment vote|last=Loughlin|first=Elaine|first2=Juno |last2=McEnroe|date=23 March 2018|work=[[Irish Examiner]]|accessdate=23 March 2018}} [[Fine Gael]] also gave a free vote, including for ministers.{{cite news|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/ministers-to-have-freedom-on-eighth-amendment-vote-465795.html|title=Ministers to have freedom on Eighth Amendment vote|last=Ó Cionnaith|first=Fiachra|date=15 January 2018|work=[[Irish Examiner]]|accessdate=23 March 2018}} {|class="wikitable sortable" |+ TDs voting on the Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018 {{cite web |publisher=KildareStreet.ie |work=Dáil debates |date=21 March 2018 |accessdate=23 March 2018 |title=Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018: Second Stage (Resumed) |url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/debates/?id=2018-03-21a.260 }} {{cite web |publisher=KildareStreet.ie |work=Dáil debates |date=21 March 2018 |accessdate=23 March 2018 |title=Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018: Committee and Remaining Stages |url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/debates/?id=2018-03-21a.508 }} {{cite web |publisher=KildareStreet.ie |work=Dáil debates |date=21 March 2018 |accessdate=23 March 2018 |title=Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018: Fifth Stage |url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/debates/?id=2018-03-21a.463 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/latest-more-than-half-of-ff-tds-vote-against-holding-8th-amendment-referendum-833515.html |newspaper=Irish Examiner |title=Latest: Abortion Referendum Bill passes all stages in the Dáil |date=21 March 2018 |accessdate=23 March 2018}} |- ! Party / group !!data-sort-type="number"| For !!data-sort-type="number"| Against !!data-sort-type="number"| Absent !!class="unsortable" | Notes |- | [[Fine Gael]] || 42Forty-one on second stage, plus [[Simon Coveney]] on final stage || 2 || 6 || [[Seán Barrett (politician)|Seán Barrett]] and [[Peter Fitzpatrick]] voted against. |- | [[Fianna Fáil]] || 22Twenty on second stage, plus [[Seán Fleming]] and [[Charlie McConalogue]] on later stages || 21 || 1 || [[Billy Kelleher]] did not vote |- | [[Sinn Féin]] || 21Nineteen on second stage, plus [[Dessie Ellis]] and [[Kathleen Funchion]] on later stages || 1 || 1 || [[Carol Nolan]] voted against, losing the [[party whip]] for three months.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/abortion-referendum/sinn-fin-td-suspended-after-defying-party-line-on-abortion-36730217.html|title=Sinn Féin TD suspended after defying party line on abortion - Independent.ie|last=McQuinn|first=Cormac|date=21 March 2018|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=23 March 2018}} She later resigned from the party. [[Peadar Tóibín]] did not vote; [[Gerry Adams]] voted in Tóibín's seat by mistake on second stage. |- | [[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour Party]] || 7 || 0 || 0 || |- | [[Solidarity–People Before Profit]] || 6 || 0 || 0 || |- | [[Independents 4 Change|Independents 4 Change Group]]A [[technical group]] of the four [[Independents 4 Change]] party members plus three [[independent politician|independent]]s || 7 || 0 || 0 || |- | [[Social Democrats (Ireland)|Social Democrats]]–[[Green Party (Ireland)|Green Party]]A technical group of two parties || 5 || 0 || 0 || |- | [[Members of the 32nd Dáil#Rural Independents Group|Rural Independents Group]]A technical group of independents || 1 || 6 || 0 || [[Michael Harty]] voted in favour. |- | Unaligned [[independent politician|independent]]s || 4 || 2 || 2 || |- ! Total !! 115 !! 32 !! 10Excluding [[Seán Ó Fearghaíl]], who as [[Ceann Comhairle]] votes [[casting vote|only in the case of a tie]]. !! |} In the [[Members of the 25th Seanad|Seanad]], the second stage was held on 27 March, with a 35–10 vote in favour.{{cite web|url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/sendebates/?id=2018-03-27a.128|title=Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018: Second Stage|date=27 March 2018|work=Seanad debates|publisher=KildareStreet.com|accessdate=28 March 2018}} Remaining stages were the following day, with the bill passed 39–8 at committee stage and 40–10 at final stage.{{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates%20authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/seanad2018032800002#FF00800|title=Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018: Committee Stage (Resumed) and Remaining Stages|date=28 March 2018|work=Seanad debates|publisher=Oireachtas|accessdate=29 March 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/referendum-abortion-2-3928550-Mar2018/|title=Referendum on repealing the Eighth Amendment to be held on Friday 25 May|last=Finn|first=Christina|date=28 March 2018|work=[[TheJournal.ie]]|accessdate=28 March 2018}} Eight of the thirteen Fianna Fáil senators voted against, as did two of nineteen from Fine Gael, and independent [[Rónán Mullen]].{{#tag:ref| [[Jennifer Murnane O'Connor]] (FF) voted no on second stage; [[Paul Coghlan]] (FG) voted no on final stage; nine other senators voted no both times.|group="v"}} ;Notes: {{reflist|group="v"|2}} ==Campaign== On 9 March 2018, [[Minister for Housing, Planning and Local Government]] [[Eoghan Murphy]] established the statutory [[Referendum Commission]] to oversee the referendum campaign, with [[High Court (Ireland)|High Court]] judge Isobel Kennedy as Chair.{{cite web|url=http://www.housing.gov.ie/local-government/voting/referenda/minister-murphy-announces-establishment-referendum-commission|title=Minister Murphy announces establishment of Referendum Commission|date=9 March 2018|access-date=10 March 2018|publisher=[[Department of Housing, Planning and Local Government]]}} Both [[Fine Gael]] and [[Fianna Fáil]] had allowed their [[Teachta Dála|TDs]] a free vote on the issue in the [[Dáil]]. However, although Fine Gael "cannot adopt an official party position because members have been afforded a freedom of conscience vote on issues to do with the referendum",{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/taoiseach-to-launch-campaign-for-pro-repeal-fg-members-1.3464898/|title=Taoiseach to launch campaign for pro-repeal FG members|author=Sarah Bardon Political Reporter|publisher=Irish Times|date=17 April 2018 |access-date=21 April 2018 |quote=Taoiseach Leo Varadkar is to launch a campaign for Fine Gael members in favour of repealing the Eighth Amendment. Mr Varadkar and a number of senior Ministers will hold an event this weekend outlining why they believe people should vote “Yes” in the forthcoming referendum on the Amendment. ... The decision may cause some friction within the party, as there are many Fine Gael TDs and Senators who are opposed to repealing the Constitutional provision, which places the life of the unborn on an equal footing to the life of the mother. Fine Gael cannot adopt an official party position because members have been afforded a freedom of conscience vote on issues to do with the referendum. }} on 21 April [[Taoiseach]] and Fine Gael leader [[Leo Varadkar]] launched a Fine Gael 'Vote Yes' campaign for Yes-supporting party members, along with party colleagues, including Minister for Health [[Simon Harris (politician)|Simon Harris]] and Fine Gael referendum coordinator, [[Josepha Madigan]].{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/eighth-amendment/2018/0421/956174-referendum/|title=Taoiseach says Yes vote will put compassion at centre of laws|author=Dyane Connor|authorlink=Dyane Connor|publisher=RTÉ|date=21 April 2018 |access-date=21 April 2018 |quote=The Taoiseach was joined by some party colleagues to launch the Fine Gael 'Vote Yes' campaign today.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/fine-gael-vote-yes-campaign-3970947-Apr2018/|title='We still wrong women in Ireland today': Fine Gael launch referendum campaign|author=|publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]]|date=21 April 2018 |access-date=21 April 2018 |quote=Taoiseach Leo Varadkar was joined by ministers, TDs, senators, and councillors calling for a Yes vote in the referendum.}} On 8 May 2018, due to controversy over the origin, number, content and targeting of adverts on social media,{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/the-poisonous-online-campaign-to-defeat-the-abortion-referendum-1.3486236|title=The poisonous online campaign to defeat the abortion referendum|last=Mulally|first=Una|work=Irish Times|date=7 May 2018|accessdate=10 May 2018}} [[Facebook]] announced that it would block advertisements placed by foreign entities, most of whom are in the United States, and limit them to adverts placed by Irish organisations.{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/oireachtas/taoiseach-welcomes-move-by-google-facebook-on-referendum-ads-1.3489600|title=Taoiseach welcomes move by Google, Facebook on referendum ads|last=O'Halloran|first=Marie|work=Irish Times|date=9 May 2018|accessdate=10 May 2018}}{{cite news |last=Dougherty |first=Michael Brendan |date=9 May 2018 |title=Silicon Valley Deletes the Pro-Life Campaign in Ireland |url=https://www.nationalreview.com/2018/05/silicon-valley-deletes-the-pro-life-campaign-in-ireland/ |work=National Review |location=United States |access-date=9 May 2018 }}
{{cite news |last=Stanley-Becker |first=Isaac |date=9 May 2018 |title=Facebook, Google limit ads in effort to prevent interference in Irish abortion referendum |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/facebook-bans-foreign-ads-in-effort-to-limit-interference-in-irelands-abortion-referendum/2018/05/08/b1e47d7c-52c4-11e8-a6d4-ca1d035642ce_story.html?noredirect=on |work=Washington Post |location=United States |access-date=9 May 2018 }} On 9 May, [[Google]] announced that it was blocking all adverts on the referendum from its advertising platform and [[YouTube]], citing concerns around the integrity of elections.{{cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/ireland/2018/0509/961266-google-ads/|title=Google to ban ads related to referendum on Eighth Amendment|last=Goodbody|first=Will|publisher=RTÉ|date=9 May 2018|accessdate=10 May 2018}} On 9 May, the fundraising web pages of Together for Yes, Amnesty Ireland and Termination for Medical Reasons were subjected to a [[denial-of-service attack]].{{cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/eighth-amendment/2018/0510/962545-together-for-yes-campaign/|title=Yes campaign investigating incident on its fundraising webpage|last=Conneely|first=Ailbhe|publisher=RTÉ|date=10 May 2018|accessdate=11 May 2018}} On 20 May, the parents of [[Savita Halappanavar]] called for a Yes vote, her father saying "I hope the people of Ireland will vote yes for abortion, for the ladies of Ireland and the people of Ireland. My daughter, she lost her life because of this abortion law, because of the diagnosis, and she could not have an abortion. She died."{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/savita-s-father-calls-for-repeal-as-campaigns-target-undecided-1.3501906|title=Savita’s father calls for repeal as campaigns target undecided|last=Holland|first=Kitty|work=The Irish Times|date=20 May 2018|accessdate=21 May 2018}} After the landslide Yes vote, Halappanavar's father thanked the people of Ireland.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/may/26/savita-halappanavar-father-thanks-irish-voters-for-historic-abortion-vote |title=Savita Halappanavar's father thanks Irish voters for 'historic' abortion vote |newspaper=The Guardian |date=26 May 2018 |author=Harriet Sherwood |accessdate= 26 May 2018}} On 23 May, CNN reported that American-based anti-abortion groups, such as "Let Them Live", have flown to Ireland in order to sway voters to vote No to the amendment. They entered into Ireland by lying to Irish border control about their reason for coming to Ireland, claiming they were only in Ireland to document the event and nothing more, therefore breaking Irish law by their activities—they did not obtain a "Volunteer Visa", required to do voluntary work.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/05/23/europe/ireland-abortion-referendum-american-campaigners-intl/index.html|title=The Americans trying to stop Ireland from voting Yes to abortion|last=CNN|first=Kara Fox,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-05-27}} ===Endorsing a Yes vote=== [[File:Abortion Referendum Campaign Posters in Dublin, May 2018 (40281031690).jpg|thumb|upright|Referendum campaign posters in Dublin]] ;Political parties * [[Communist Party of Ireland]]{{cite web|url=http://www.communistpartyofireland.ie/r-2018-04-10.html|title=Communist Party of Ireland|website=www.communistpartyofireland.ie|language=en|access-date=23 April 2018}} * [[Green Party (Ireland)|Green Party]] * [[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour Party]]{{cite web|author=Michael O'Regan |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/majority-fine-gael-view-on-abortion-referendum-expected-1.3355364?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fnews%2Fpolitics%2Fmajority-fine-gael-view-on-abortion-referendum-expected-1.3355364 |title=Majority Fine Gael view on abortion referendum expected |publisher=Irishtimes.com |date=15 January 2018|accessdate=9 April 2018}} * [[Solidarity–People Before Profit]] * [[Social Democrats (Ireland)|Social Democrats]] * [[Sinn Féin]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/sf-unlikely-to-update-abortion-stance-before-referendum-1.3420390|title=SF unlikely to update abortion stance before referendum|work=The Irish Times|access-date=25 March 2018}} * [[Workers' Party of Ireland|The Workers' Party]]{{Cite news|url=http://workersparty.ie/policy/womens-rights/|title=Women's Rights|work=The Workers' Party of Ireland|access-date=16 April 2018}} ;Other organisations * [[Together for Yes]], an umbrella group bringing together many pro-repeal organisations, including the [[Irish Council for Civil Liberties]], the [[Irish Family Planning Association]], the [[Union of Students in Ireland]], [[SIPTU]],{{cite web|url=https://www.togetherforyes.ie/about-us/campaign-platform-members/|title=Campaign Platform Members|work=Together For Yes|accessdate=16 April 2018}} and Inclusion Ireland, the national association for people with an intellectual disability.{{cite web|url=https://www.newstalk.com/Disability-group-Inclusion-Ireland-to-join-campaign-to-repeal-Eighth-Amendment|title=Disability group Inclusion Ireland to join campaign to repeal Eighth Amendment |publisher=newstalk.com|date=13 April 2018|accessdate=28 April 2018}} * The Institute of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists: The executive committee of the Institute of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists within the [[Royal College of Physicians of Ireland]] voted 18–0, with one abstention, in favour of repeal.{{cite web|url=https://www.rcpi.ie/news/releases/statement-from-the-institute-of-obstetricians-and-gynaecologists/|title=Statement from the Institute of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists|date=10 January 2018|publisher=Royal College of Physicians of Ireland|accessdate=16 April 2018}}; {{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/abortion-referendum/obstetricians-to-agree-principles-if-eighth-amendment-repealed-1.3461242|title=Obstetricians to agree principles if Eighth Amendment repealed|last=Edwards|first=Elaine|date=13 April 2018 |work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=16 April 2018}} * The [[Irish Congress of Trade Unions]] and constituent members [[Unite the Union|Unite]], [[Mandate (trade union)|Mandate]], the [[Communication Workers Union (Ireland)|Communications Workers' Union]], and SIPTU published a newspaper with many articles calling for a Yes vote on [[International Workers' Day]].{{cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/eighth-amendment/2018/0501/959485-eighth-amendment/|title=Unions launch campaign calling for Yes vote in Eighth Amendment referendum|publisher=RTÉ|date=1 May 2018|accessdate=1 May 2018}} * ''[[The Irish Times]]'' endorsed a Yes vote in an [[editorial]], arguing "the Eighth Amendment has turned out to be more damaging than its critics in those febrile days dared imagine" and urging readers to "Repeal the Eighth".{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/editorial/the-irish-times-view-on-abortion-end-the-secrecy-and-the-shame-1.3505835|title=The Irish Times view on abortion: end the secrecy and the shame|publisher=The Irish Times|date=23 May 2018}} ===Endorsing a No vote=== [[File:Irish abortion referendum posters 2018 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Referendum campaign posters in Dublin]] ;Political parties * [[Renua Ireland]]{{cite web|author=Renua Ireland |url=https://www.facebook.com/renuairl/posts/1281920715242736 |title=Renua believes that such statements by... |publisher=Facebook |date=17 March 2018|accessdate=9 April 2018}}{{cite web|author=Renua Ireland |url=https://www.facebook.com/renuairl/photos/a.620456441389170.1073741829.614189535349194/1272525352848939/?type=3&theater |title=Rally to Save the 8th Renua Ireland urges... |publisher=Facebook |date=7 March 2018|accessdate=9 April 2018}} ;Other organisations * The [[Pro Life Campaign]], who campaigned under the slogan "Love Both".{{cite web|url=https://www.irishcentral.com/opinion/us-meddling-ireland-referendum-abortion|title=US interference in the Irish abortion referendum|last=Mulraney|first=Frances|date=3 April 2018|work=IrishCentral.com|accessdate=16 April 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/abortion-referendum-phoney-war-prevails-until-legislation-is-clear-1.3413360|title=Abortion referendum: Phoney war prevails until legislation is clear|last=Kelly|first=Fiach|date=3 March 2018|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=16 April 2018}} * Save the 8th, a campaign supported by the Life Institute and [[Youth Defence]], registered with the [[Standards in Public Office Commission]] in January 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.sipo.ie/en/Reports/Register-of-Third-Parties/|title=Register of Third Parties|publisher=Standards in Public Office Commission|accessdate=16 April 2018}} * Abortion Never, a campaign backed by the unregistered [[National Party (Ireland, 2016)|National Party]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/yes-and-no-campaigners-register-as-third-parties-with-watchdog-1.3471743|title=Yes and No campaigners register as 'third parties' with watchdog|work=The Irish Times|access-date=27 April 2018}} * Cherish All the Children Equally, a group which describes itself as "progressive, republican and of the left", and includes Sinn Féin supporters disillusioned with the party's stance.{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/cherish-all-of-the-children-equally-3976086-Apr2018/|title='Sinn Féin is an absolute disgrace' - We spoke to the republican pro-lifers at the GPO today|publisher=thejournal.ie|date=24 January 2018|accessdate=28 April 2018}} * The [[Irish Catholic Bishops' Conference]] said repealing the Eighth Amendment would be "a shocking step" and "a manifest injustice".{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/catholic-bishops-repeal-of-eighth-would-be-manifest-injustice-1.3417362|title=Catholic bishops: Repeal of Eighth would be 'manifest injustice'|last=McGarry|first=Patsy|date=6 March 2018|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=16 April 2018}}; {{cite web|url=https://www.catholicbishops.ie/2018/03/06/our-common-humanity-statement-on-the-second-day-of-the-spring-2018-general-meeting-of-the-irish-catholic-bishops-conference/|title='Our Common Humanity' – statement on the second day of the Spring 2018 General Meeting of the Irish Catholic Bishops' Conference|date=6 March 2018|publisher=Irish Catholic Bishops' Conference|accessdate=16 April 2018}} * The [[Presbyterian Church in Ireland]].{{cite web|author=Patsy McGarry |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/religion-and-beliefs/presbyterian-church-urges-no-vote-in-abortion-referendum-1.3478231 |title=Presbyterian Church urges 'No' vote in abortion referendum |publisher=Irishtimes.com |date=30 April 2018|accessdate=12 May 2018}} * The [[Islamic Cultural Centre of Ireland]].[https://islamireland.ie/news/press-release-concerning-the-forthcoming-referendum-on-abortion/ Press Release Concerning the Forthcoming Referendum on Abortion]. [[Islamic Cultural Centre of Ireland]]. 15 May 2018.[https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/religion-and-beliefs/islamic-spokesman-calls-for-no-vote-in-abortion-referendum-1.3504041 "Islamic spokesman calls for No vote in abortion referendum"]. [[The Irish Times]]. 22 May 2018. * The [[Orange Order]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/orange-order-calls-for-no-vote-in-abortion-referendum-1.3507322|title=Orange Order calls for No vote in abortion referendum|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2018-05-24|language=en-US}} ===Neutral and other positions=== * The [[Church of Ireland]] issued statements favouring giving the Oireachtas responsibility for abortion legislation, but opposing unrestricted abortion up to 12 weeks' gestation; it concluded, "We therefore ask Church members to think through the issues involved carefully and with prayer".{{cite press release |url=https://www.ireland.anglican.org/news/7872/a-statement-on-the-forthcoming |title=A statement on the forthcoming referendum on the repeal of the 8th Amendment to the Irish Constitution in relation to proposed legislation by the Archbishop of Armagh and the Archbishop of Dublin |publisher=Church of Ireland |date=28 March 2018 }}; {{cite press release |url= https://www.ireland.anglican.org/news/7763/statement-on-the-proposal-to |title=Statement on the proposal to repeal the 8th Amendment to the Irish Constitution from the Archbishop of Armagh and the Archbishop of Dublin |publisher=Church of Ireland |date=5 February 2018 }} * Down Syndrome Ireland issued a statement that "it is up to each individual to make their own decision about which way to vote" and condemning the use of a baby with [[Down Syndrome]] in a poster by "Save the 8th".{{cite press release |url=https://downsyndrome.ie/statement-on-the-topic-of-the-upcoming-referendum/ |publisher=Down Syndrome Ireland |title=Statement on the topic of the upcoming referendum |date=23 January 2018 }}; {{cite news |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/religion-and-beliefs/child-with-down-syndrome-to-feature-in-anti-abortion-billboard-campaign-1.3372867 |title=Child with Down Syndrome to feature in anti-abortion billboard campaign |date=29 January 2018 |work=The Irish Times |first=Patsy |last=McGarry }} * [[Fianna Fáil]] did not take a formal position on the referendum. However, 31 of the party's TDs and Senators posed for a photograph, showing their opposition to repealing the eighth. This means over half of the parliamentary party are supporting a No vote.{{cite news|author=Ben Kelly |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ireland-abortion-referendum-live-updates-repeal-eighth-amendment-vote-latest-poll-a8334956.html |title=Ireland abortion referendum: Google and Facebook ban ads sparking 'rigging' claims from No campaigners |publisher=The Independent |date=11 May 2018|accessdate=12 May 2018}} Nonetheless the party's leader Micheál Martin supports 'Yes',{{Cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/micheal-martin-referendum-eighth-amendment-4002913-May2018/|title=Micheál Martin says making up his mind on abortion has been a 'long and challenging process'|author=|work=thejournal.ie|date=2018-05-09|access-date=2018-05-25}} and, along with Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald, was one of the two speakers for the 'Yes' side in the final televised debate before the vote. * [[Fine Gael]] "cannot adopt an official party position because members have been afforded a freedom of conscience vote on issues to do with the referendum". However, [[Josepha Madigan]], the [[Minister for Culture, Heritage and the Gaeltacht]], co-ordinated a campaign for Yes-supporting party members, which was formally launched on 21 April 2018 by Leo Varadkar and Simon Harris. The campaign supported Together for Yes, rather than put up posters of its own.{{cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/ireland/2018/0412/954078-fine-gael-referendum/|title=Fine Gael will not put up Eighth Amendment posters|date=12 April 2018|work=[[RTÉ.ie]]|accessdate=16 April 2018}} * The [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] reiterated its policy of neutrality on political issues, in response to media reports of various players and managers publicly taking sides.{{cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2018/0422/956350-gaa-eighth-amendment-referendum/|title=GAA to write to counties over involvement in referendum|date=22 April 2018|work=[[RTÉ.ie]]|accessdate=22 April 2018}} * The head imam of the [[Al-Mustafa Islamic Cultural Centre Ireland|Al-Mustafa Islamic Centre]] supported repeal of the eighth amendment and state funded abortions in "extraordinary circumstances" but rejected "calls for abortions to be freely available until the end of the first trimester".{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/muslim-view-repeal-eighth-amendment-to-relieve-burden-on-women-1.3494798|title=Muslim view: Repeal Eighth Amendment to relieve burden on women|last=Al-Qadri|first=Umar|work=The Irish Times|date=15 May 2018|accessdate=15 May 2018}} ===Television debates during the referendum campaign=== {|class="wikitable" |+Television debates during the referendum campaign |- ! Audience members contributed to the debate. | {{cite news|title=RTÉ defends 'fair and equitable' debate|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/ireland/2018/0523/965432-eighth-amendment/|accessdate=23 May 2018|work=RTE.ie|date=23 May 2018|language=en}}; {{cite web|title=No campaigner Cora Sherlock pulls out of tonight's Prime Time referendum debate |url=https://www.her.ie/news/no-campaigner-cora-sherlock-pulls-tonights-prime-time-referendum-debate-404600|website=Her.ie|accessdate=23 May 2018|language=en}}; {{cite news|title=Latest: Peadar Toibin says unborn has 'no voice'; Simon Harris calls on people to 'trust women' in abortion debate|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/three-hours-to-final-abortion-debate-rte-and-no-side-fall-out-over-speakers-844479.html|accessdate=23 May 2018|work=Irish Examiner|date=22 May 2018}}; {{cite news|last1=Ó Cionnaith|first1=Fiachra|title='No' campaigners deny infighting over Cora Sherlock's last-minute exit from RTE debate|url=https://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/no-campaigners-deny-infighting-over-cora-sherlocks-last-minute-exit-from-rte-debate-844681.html|accessdate=24 May 2018|work=Breaking News|date=23 May 2018}}{{cite newspaper|newspaper=The Sunday Times|date=3 June 2018|title=How the ‘no’ campaign fell apart|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/acbb10dc-667d-11e8-909e-3e8bc48c88c9|first=Stephen|last=O’Brien|quote=According to one source familiar with the exchanges: “There was a consensus it should be somebody other than Cora. We felt there was a real danger of it not going well. As it turned out, it would hardly have mattered. But she took it very, very badly.” Another source said Sherlock was understandably disappointed at being taken off the show, but “there was a big surge of demand from across the pro-life organisations for Maria to go on; she was the unanimous choice because she’d done exceptionally well the week before on Claire Byrne Live”. ... She will continue as a member of the Pro Life Campaign, Love Both’s parent organisation, and insists “there is no longer-term damage” to her relationship with that group.}} |- | 23 May || ''Pat Kenny Tonight'' || [[TV3 (Ireland)|TV3]] || [[Pat Kenny]] | [[Regina Doherty]] (Fine Gael minister); [[Colm O'Gorman]] ([[Amnesty International Ireland]]) | [[Rónán Mullen]] (independent senator); [[Maria Steen]] (Iona Institute; Save The 8th) | | {{cite news|title=Maria Steen will take part in TV3 debate having previously pulled out|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/maria-steen-will-take-part-in-tv3-debate-having-previously-pulled-out-1.3505341|accessdate=23 May 2018|work=The Irish Times}} |- | 23 May || ''[[The Tonight Show (TV3)|The Tonight Show]]'' || TV3 || [[Matt Cooper (Irish journalist)|Matt Cooper]] and [[Ivan Yates]] | [[Mícheál Martin]] (Fianna Fáil leader);

color: white;" | 26% |} ==Result== [[File:Savita Halappanavar mural, Dublin.jpg|thumb|A mural outside the Bernard Shaw Pub in Portobello, Dublin depicting [[Savita Halappanavar]] and calling for a Yes vote. After the result was announced, hundreds of Yes supporters left handwritten messages and flowers at the mural.]] Polls opened at 07:00 [[Irish Standard Time|IST]] (UTC+1) and closed at 22:00 IST on 25 May 2018. Twelve [[List of islands of Ireland|offshore islands]] voted the day before, to allow for possible delays delivering ballot boxes to the count centres.{{cite news|last1=McGrath|first1=Pat|title=Islands vote in referendum on Eighth Amendment|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2018/0524/965640-island_voting/|accessdate=24 May 2018|work=RTE.ie|date=24 May 2018|language=en}} Counting began at 09:00 on 26 May. All [[Irish nationality law|Irish citizens]] entered on the [[electoral roll|electoral register]] were eligible to vote. A total of 3,229,672 people were on the annual electoral register (as of 15 February 2018) and an additional 118,389 electors were added to the supplementary register by the closing date of 8 May 2018,{{cite web|title=Register of Electors 2018/2019 |date=15 February 2018|url=http://www.housing.gov.ie/sites/default/files/publications/files/electorate_for_each_constituency.pdf|publisher=Department of Housing, Planning and Local Government|accessdate=24 May 2018|format=PDF}}{{cite web|title=Supplement to the Register of Electors 2018/2019|url=http://www.housing.gov.ie/sites/default/files/publications/files/supplement_to_register_-_may_2018.pdf|publisher=Department of Housing, Planning and Local Government|accessdate=24 May 2018|date=24 May 2018|format=PDF}}{{cite news|last1=Ó Cionnaith|first1=Fiachra|title=Today last day to register to vote ahead of referendum|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/today-last-day-to-register-to-vote-ahead-of-referendum-841501.html|work=Irish Examiner|date=8 May 2018}} an unusually high number of late registrations.{{cite news|last1=Roche|first1=Barry|last2=Kelly|first2=Olivia|last3=Gallagher|first3=Conor|title=Abortion referendum: last minute rush to register to vote|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/abortion-referendum-last-minute-rush-to-register-to-vote-1.3488501|accessdate=24 May 2018|work=The Irish Times|date=8 May 2018}}; {{cite news|last1=Russell|first1=Cliodhna|title=Council by council: An extra 118,000 people have registered to vote ahead of tomorrow's referendum|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/council-breakdown-extra-people-voting-4031180-May2018/|accessdate=24 May 2018|work=TheJournal.ie|date=24 May 2018|language=en}} [[Dáil constituencies]] were used to organise the voting, with the [[returning officer]] for each appointed by the [[Local government in the Republic of Ireland|city or county council]], and results sent to the national returning officer in Dublin. Although a close result had been expected by observers,https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/may/25/close-result-expected-in-irelands-abortion-referendumhttps://www.news.com.au/world/europe/ireland-heads-to-the-polls-in-landmark-abortion-referendum/news-story/dab73fafb76f7b5541a0350e061d4d51 an exit poll conducted by ''[[The Irish Times]]'' predicted a 68% Yes result,{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/irish-times-exit-poll-projects-ireland-has-voted-by-landslide-to-repeal-eighth-1.3508861|title=Irish Times exit poll projects Ireland has voted by landslide to repeal Eighth|date=25 May 2018|work=The Irish Times}} while one conducted by [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]] predicted a similar Yes result of 69.4%.{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/politics/2018/0526/966120-eighth-amendment-referendum/|title=Exit poll indicates large majority vote to change abortion laws|work=RTE News|date=25 May 2018}} The day after the vote, Save the 8th campaign conceded defeat.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/anti-abortion-rights-campaign-concedes-defeat-irish-referendum-after-polls-945751|title=Anti-abortion campaign concedes defeat in Irish referendum|date=26 May 2018|website=newsweek.com|accessdate=26 May 2018}} {{Referendum |title = Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018{{cite web|url=http://www.referendum.ie/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/Referendum-Results-1937-2018.pdf|work=[[Department of Housing, Planning and Local Government]]|title=Referendum Results 1937–2018|page=96|date=September 2018|access-date=28 September 2018}} |yes = 1,429,981 |yespct = 66.40 |no = 723,632 |nopct = 33.60 |valid = 2,153,613 |validpct = 99.72 |invalid = 6,042 |invalidpct = 0.28 |total = 2,159,655 |turnoutpct = 64.13 |electorate = 3,367,556 }} {|class="wikitable sortable" |+Results by constituency |- ! rowspan=2 | Constituency ! rowspan=2 | Electorate ! rowspan=2 | {{nowrap|Turnout (%)}} ! colspan=2 | Votes ! colspan=2 | Proportion of votes |- ! background:#c8ffc8;"| '''74.26%''' | style="text-align: right;" | 25.74% |- class="sortbottom" style="font-weight:bold; background:rgb(232,232,232);" | Total | style="text-align: right;" | 3,367,556 | style="text-align: right;" | 64.13% | style="text-align: right;" | '''1,429,981''' | style="text-align: right;" | 723,632 | style="text-align: right;" | 66.40% | style="text-align: right;" | 33.60% |} ===Analysis of results=== The turnout of voters, at 2,159,655, was the highest thus far in any [[Amendments to the Constitution of Ireland#List of amendments and referendums|Irish constitutional referendum]]. This beat the previous record, which had been held by the [[Thirty-fourth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|2015 marriage equality referendum]], by 209,930 votes. ;{{anchor|regions}}Results by Region All four regions voted Yes, ranging from 57.5% Yes for Connacht-Ulster to 75.5% for Dublin. {|class="wikitable sortable collapsible" |+Regional Results{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/eighth-amendment/results/|title=Referendum 2018|date=May 2018 |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |accessdate=31 May 2018}} |- ! rowspan=2 | Region ! rowspan=2 | {{nowrap|Turnout (%)}} ! colspan=2 | Votes ! colspan=2 | Proportion of votes |- ! Sampling began at 7am and was conducted at 160 locations across every constituency throughout the day. The margin of error is estimated at +/- 1.5 per cent.}} and by [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2018/0525/965899-eighth-amendment/|title=RTÉ exit poll on the Eighth Amendment projects: Yes 69.4% No 30.6%|author=|work=RTÉ|date=25 May 2018|access-date=26 May 2018|quote= The sample size was 3,800 with a margin of error of +/- 1.6%. The exit poll was conducted by RTÉ in conjunction with a number of Irish universities and was carried out by Behaviour & Attitudes.}} every age group voted Yes except those aged 65 and over, with the highest Yes vote being from the youngest age groups. The details were: {|class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan=2 | Age group ! colspan=2 | Yes ! colspan=2 | No |- ! Irish Times ! RTÉ ! Irish Times !
