The detail were: {|class="wikitable" |- ! rowspan=2 | Urban-Rural ! colspan=2 | Yes ! colspan=2 | No |- ! Irish Times ! RTÉ ! Irish Times ! RTÉ |- | style="background:#c8ffc8;"| Urban | style="text-align: right;" | 71% | style="text-align: right;" | 72.3% | style="text-align: right;" | 29% | style="text-align: right;" | 27.7% |- | style="background:#c8ffc8;"| Rural | style="text-align: right;" | 60% | style="text-align: right;" | 63.3% | style="text-align: right;" | 40% | style="text-align: right;" | 36.7% |} ==Reactions to the result== ===Ireland=== ;Yes supporters [[File:REPEAL YES05.jpg|thumb|"Yes" supporters at [[Dublin Castle]] after the Referendum results were declared]] Taoiseach [[Leo Varadkar]] said: "I think what we've seen today really is the culmination of a quiet revolution that’s taken place in Ireland for the past 10 or 20 years. This has been a great exercise in democracy and the people have spoken. The people have said we want a modern constitution for a modern country, that we trust women and we respect them to make the right decision, the right choices about their own healthcare."{{cite news|title=Reaction: 'The country has listened. Women have spoken'|work=The Irish Times|date=26 May 2018}} Tánaiste [[Simon Coveney]] said: "For me, the margin of victory is important but equally important is that there is no Dublin versus the rest or no urban/rural divide – in virtually every part of the country, people have voted in big numbers to allow the government and the Oireachtas to change Ireland for the better." Orla O'Connor, director of the National Women's Council and co-director of Together for Yes thanked Yes voters, saying: "This is phenomenal. This was a grassroots, people campaign and I think what today will show is that this is a people's referendum. Presuming that these exit polls are correct, the public haven’t just spoken, this is a resounding roar from Irish people about the horrors of the Eighth and how women should no longer be treated as second class citizens in our society." ;No supporters [[Cora Sherlock]], of the LoveBoth campaign, said: "This is a very sad day for Ireland, that people have voted for abortion. We need to remember what they have won. All that is being offered is abortion. There has been no talking about why Irish woman travel, what options could have been put on the table."{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/ireland-s-abortion-referendum-result-in-five-charts-1.3509845|title=Ireland's abortion referendum result in five charts|work=The Irish Times|date=27 May 2018|accessdate=30 May 2018}} [[Declan Ganley]] tweeted: "I've been thinking about conscientious objection. I will not pay for the killing of Ireland's unborn children, I cannot be a party to it. So there will need to be a way to exempt conscientious objectors taxes from paying for them in any way, shape or form."{{cite web |url= https://twitter.com/declanganley/status/1000484710630477824 |title=Declan Ganley on Twitter|date= 26 May 2018 |accessdate= 30 May 2018}} Catholic Bishop [[Kevin Doran]] said: "While the Catholic Church is a family and nobody ever gets struck off what I'd say to a Catholic who voted Yes is this, if you voted Yes knowing and intending that abortion would be the outcome then you should consider coming to confession."{{cite news|url=https://www.irishcentral.com/news/catholics-yes-sin-confession-ireland|title=Bishop says Ireland's Catholics who voted Yes in abortion referendum sinned and should confess|work=Irish Central|date=28 May 2018|accessdate=29 May 2018}} ===United Kingdom=== UK Prime Minister [[Theresa May]] contacted Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, and posted to [[Twitter]], saying "The Irish Referendum yesterday was an impressive show of democracy which delivered a clear and unambiguous result. I congratulate the Irish people on their decision and all of #Together4Yes on their successful campaign."{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/abortion-referendum/theresa-may-congratulates-irish-people-as-pressure-grows-to-liberalise-abortion-laws-in-northern-ireland-36951264.html|title=Theresa May congratulates Irish people as pressure grows to liberalise abortion laws in Northern Ireland|last=Hughes|first=David|work=Irish Independent|date=27 May 2018|accessdate=30 May 2018}} However, she later reiterated her position that abortion is considered a devolved matter in Northern Ireland, and accordingly that the UK government would not intervene.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/northern-ireland-abortion-ban-irish-referendum-theresa-may-uk-laws-a8374741.html|title=Theresa May will not intervene to help legalise abortion in Northern Ireland, Downing Street says|author=Benjamin Kentish, Political Correspondent|work=[[The Independent]] (UK)|date=2018-05-30|access-date=2018-05-31|quote=Prime minister believes issue ‘is a devolved matter', despite mounting calls for her to back reform}} This followed a statement from [[Arlene Foster]], leader of the Northern Ireland's anti-abortion [[Democratic Unionist Party|DUP]], whose votes are needed to give May's [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Second May ministry|Government]] its [[Parliamentary majority]], that the issue should be decided by the [[Northern Ireland Assembly]]. But senior Conservatives, such as Commons Health Committee chairperson [[Sarah Wollaston]] and education minister [[Anne Milton]], backed calls for a free vote on the issue, while [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] [[Member of parliament|MP]] [[Stella Creasy]] said she would table an amendment on the matter to the Domestic Violence Bill and said that over 150 parliamentarians had expressed support for the change, and Labour's [[Shadow Attorney General for England and Wales|shadow Attorney General]] [[Shami Chakrabarti]] called the issue a test for May's [[feminism]]. May's spokesperson refused to say whether Conservative MPs would be given a free vote in such a "hypothetical" situation, but said that there had been free votes on the abortion issue in the past. ;Northern Ireland The result re-opened the debate about the legality of abortion in [[Northern Ireland]]. In all constituent countries of the United Kingdom but Northern Ireland, abortion is legal in many circumstances under the [[Abortion Act 1967]]. Abortion in Northern Ireland has historically been considered a devolved matter to be decided by the [[Northern Ireland Assembly]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/44275372|title=NI women 'in limbo' over abortion law|date=28 May 2018|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} In Belfast a rally took place advocating for the liberalisation of abortion laws in Northern Ireland,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-44281878|title=Hundreds rally for NI abortion rights|date=28 May 2018|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} where there were calls for the UK government to step in.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-44286055|title=May told abortion reform 'is feminist test'|date=29 May 2018|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} UK intervention to liberalise abortion laws in Northern Ireland is opposed by the [[Democratic Unionist Party]], the largest party in Northern Ireland and which currently supports the minority Conservative government in the UK.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-44272326|title=Foster says abortion vote no impact on NI|date=28 May 2018|publisher=|accessdate=31 May 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} ===Elsewhere=== *Speaking from his home in [[Karnataka]], south-west [[India]], Andanappa Yalagi, the father of [[Savita Halappanavar]] (who died from sepsis in 2012 after being refused an abortion in Galway), thanked the Irish people for their "historic vote". * [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Justin Trudeau]], who, when visiting Dublin in 2017, had urged Taoiseach Leo Varadkar to liberalise Ireland's abortion laws as a fundamental [[human rights]] issue, phoned to congratulate him, and also tweeted "What a moment for democracy and women’s rights. Tonight, I spoke with Taoiseach @campaignforLeo and his team and congratulated them on the Yes side’s referendum victory legalising abortion in Ireland." *Varadkar also received messages from [[Xavier Bettel]], [[Prime Minister of Luxembourg|Prime Minister]] of [[Luxembourg]], and from [[Jüri Ratas]], [[Prime Minister of Estonia|Prime Minister]] of [[Estonia]]. * [[Finland]]'s [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Finland)|Foreign Minister]] [[Timo Soini]], a [[Blue Reform]] MP and 'a self-described [[Roman Catholic]]', criticised the Irish abortion vote, writing that 'the world had become odd if it was necessary to find reasons to defend life'.{{cite news|url=https://yle.fi/uutiset/osasto/news/ncp_mps_chide_foreign_ministers_criticism_of_irish_abortion_vote/10226523|title=NCP MPs chide foreign minister's criticism of Irish abortion vote|publisher=[[YLE]] TV News|date=28 May 2018|accessdate=1 June 2018|quote=Contrary to Soini, his Swedish counterpart, Foreign Minister Margot Wallström applauded the result of the Irish referendum.}} Following a query by [[Green League|Green Party]] MP [[Ville Niinistö]], [[Minister of the Interior (Finland)|Interior Minister]] [[Kai Mykkänen]] and [[Minister for Foreign Trade and Development (Finland)|Foreign Trade and Development Minister]] [[Anne-Mari Virolainen]], both [[National Coalition Party]] MPs, insisted that Soini's position was not the official position of the [[Finnish Government]], and that the right to abortion was a matter of human rights. *[[Sweden]]'s [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Sweden)|Foreign Minister]] [[Margot Wallström]] applauded the result of the referendum. *[[France]]'s [[President of France|President]] [[Emmanuel Macron]] tweeted that he welcomed the result.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/the-latest-uk-leader-hails-ireland-abortion-vote-result/2018/05/27/6bf6a56a-61ab-11e8-81ca-bb14593acaa6_story.html?noredirect=on |title=The Latest: Macron: Ireland makes history with abortion vote|author=Associated Press|authorlink=Associated Press|work=[[Washington Post]]|date=2018-05-27|access-date=2018-06-01|language=|quote=1:45 p.m. French President Emmanuel Macron says that Ireland has made history with its abortion referendum in which voters chose to abolish a ban on terminations. Macron tweeted that “this vote will stand as an essential symbol for women’s freedom.” }} ==Challenge to referendum result== The Provisional Referendum Certificate was signed by Barry Ryan, the Referendum Returning Officer, on 28 May 2018, and published in ''[[Iris Oifigiúil]]'' on 29 May.{{cite journal |url=http://www.irisoifigiuil.ie/currentissues/Ir290518.pdf#page=18 |format=PDF |number=43 |journal=Iris Oifigiúil |date=29 May 2018|access-date=2 June 2018 |pages=768–770 |first=Barry |last=Ryan |title=Referendum Act 1994 — Constitutional Referendum}}{{cite web |url=http://whatsnew.citizensinformation.ie/2018/05/30/referendum-what-happens-next/|title=Referendum – what happens next?|access-date=2 June 2018|date=30 May 2018}} Challenges against the validity of the referendum must be brought within seven days of publication.{{cite web |url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1994/act/12/section/42/enacted/en/html#sec42|title=Referendum Act, 1994, Section 42|publisher=[[Irish Statute Book]]|access-date=2 June 2018|quote=PART IV - Referendum Petitions - Section 42-(2) A referendum petition in relation to a provisional referendum certificate shall not be presented to the High Court unless that court, on application made to it in that behalf by or on behalf of the person proposing to present it not later than seven days after the publication in Iris Oifigiúil of the certificate, by order grants leave to the person to do so.}} Three petitions challenging the result were made within the deadline, by [[Joanna Jordan (Irish campaigner)|Joanna Jordan]], Charles Byrne, and Ciarán Tracey. These alleged variously that the Referendum Commission information booklet was biased and that the electoral register was unreliable, with unexplained deletion of older voters' details and failure to delete those of emigrants who were thus able to travel back to vote despite [[Right of Irish expatriates to vote|being ineligible]].{{cite news |title=Three court applications to challenge referendum result |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2018/0605/968418-referendum-challenge-high-court/ |access-date=5 June 2018 |work=RTE.ie |date=5 June 2018 |language=en}} Jordan's [[Thirty-first Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland#Court challenge|unsuccessful petition]] against the [[Thirty-first Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|children's rights amendment]] delayed its enactment from 2012 until 2015. Enactment of the 2015 [[Thirty-fourth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|marriage equality amendment]] was similarly delayed for three months.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/president-signs-same-sex-marriage-into-constitution-1.2333882|title=President signs same-sex marriage into Constitution|date=29 August 2015|work=[[The Irish Times]]|access-date=31 August 2015}} The applications seeking leave to bring [[judicial review]] proceedings were heard in the High Court from 26 to 29 June.{{cite news |last1=Traynor |first1=Vivienne |title=Applications sought to challenge referendum result |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/courts/2018/0611/969737-high-court-referendum-challenge/ |access-date=11 June 2018 |work=RTE.ie |date=11 June 2018 |language=en}}{{cite news |last1=O'Loughlin |first1=Ann |title=Man makes claim of 'electoral fraud' in High Court case against abortion referendum result |url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/man-makes-claim-of-electoral-fraud-in-high-court-case-against-abortion-referendum-result-851297.html |access-date=27 June 2018 |work=Irish Examiner |date=26 June 2018}}{{cite news |last1=O'Loughlin |first1=Ann |title=Judge to rule later on bids to challenge result of abortion referendum |url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/judge-to-rule-later-on-bids-to-challenge-result-of-abortion-referendum-852018.html |access-date=2 July 2018 |work=Irish Examiner |date=29 June 2018}} Tracey withdrew and leave was refused for another man, Diarmaid McConville, to take over his application. On 20 July Justice [[Peter Kelly (judge)|Peter Kelly]] ruled against the other two applicants, saying they had failed to provide ''[[prima facie]]'' evidence of anything likely to have changed the result of the vote,{{cite news |title=High Court refuses challenge to referendum result|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/courts/2018/0720/980073-high-court-referendum-result/|author=Sandra Hurley|date=20 July 2018|access-date=21 July 2018 |publisher=RTÉ News|quote=President of the High Court, Mr Justice Peter Kelly said the applicants did not demonstrate prima facie evidence of matters likely to have a material effect on the referendum result as a whole.}}; {{cite web |last1=Kelly |first1=Peter |title=[2018] IEHC 437 : Byrne -v- Ireland & ors |url=http://courts.ie/Judgments.nsf/bce24a8184816f1580256ef30048ca50/8bc050276b4937c4802582d00057ab8f?OpenDocument |website=courts.ie |publisher=Courts Service of Ireland |access-date=27 July 2018 |date=20 July 2018}}; {{cite web |last1=Kelly |first1=Peter |title=[2018] IEHC 438 : Jordan -v- Ireland & ors |url=http://courts.ie/Judgments.nsf/bce24a8184816f1580256ef30048ca50/8a4ad6e7361dd494802582d00057d8fc?OpenDocument |website=courts.ie |publisher=Courts Service of Ireland |access-date=27 July 2018 |date=20 July 2018}} but left them a week to challenge this in the [[Court of Appeal (Ireland)|Court of Appeal]].{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/eighth-referendum-challenges-4138424-Jul2018/|title='It is not a tool for a disappointed voter': Court dismisses bid to challenge abortion referendum|publisher=The Journal|date=20 July 2018|access-date=20 July 2018}}; {{cite news |last1=Carolan |first1=Mary |title=Applications to challenge abortion referendum result rejected |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/courts/high-court/applications-to-challenge-abortion-referendum-result-rejected-1.3571476 |access-date=20 July 2018 |work=The Irish Times}} [[Court costs|Costs]] were awarded against both applicants.{{cite news |last1=Carolan |first1=Mary |title=State entitled to more than €200k costs from failed abortion referendum challenges, High Court rule |url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/courts/state-entitled-to-more-than-200k-costs-from-failed-abortion-referendum-challenges-high-court-rules-37150289.html |access-date=24 July 2018 |work=Irish Independent |date=24 July 2018 |language=en}} Byrne did not appeal,{{cite news |last1=O'Loughlin |first1=Ann |title=Failed abortion referendum challenger says she will appeal High Court refusal |url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/failed-abortion-referendum-challenger-says-she-will-appeal-high-court-refusal-857358.html |access-date=24 July 2018 |work=The Irish Examiner |date=24 July 2018}} while Jordan's appeal was heard on 17 August.{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/courts/high-court/abortion-referendum-appeal-to-be-heard-in-august-1.3578370|last1=Carolan|first1=Mary|title=Abortion referendum appeal to be heard in August|access-date=28 July 2018|work=The Irish Times|date=27 July 2018}} Separately, on 31 July the Court of Appeal rejected McConville's appeal against the refusal to allow him to take over Tracey's petition application, but gave him time to apply to the [[Supreme Court of Ireland|Supreme Court]],{{cite news |last1=O'Loughlin |first1=Ann |title=Leitrim man loses appeal over abortion referendum |url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/leitrim-man-loses-appeal-over-abortion-referendum-859124.html |access-date=1 August 2018 |work=Irish Examiner |date=31 July 2018}}; {{cite web |last=Irvine |first=Mary |title=[2018] IECA 266 : Tracey -v- Ireland & Ors |url=http://courts.ie/Judgments.nsf/597645521f07ac9a80256ef30048ca52/777cc9961ed71668802582e4003c75a4?OpenDocument |website=Judgments & Determinations |publisher=Courts Service of Ireland |accessdate=9 September 2018 |date=31 July 2018}} which on 16 August denied him leave to appeal.{{cite web |last1=Dunne |first1=Elizabeth |last2=Charleton |first2=Peter |last3=O'Malley |first3=Iseult |title=[2018] IESCDET 123 : Tracey -v- Ireland and Ors |url=http://courts.ie/Judgments.nsf/5c975dd22ad51b5580257db0003d88a2/f5923b15d58e5662802582eb004c0a68?OpenDocument |website=Judgments & Determinations |publisher=Courts Service of Ireland |accessdate=9 September 2018 |date=16 August 2018}} On 27 August, the Court of Appeal dismissed Jordan's challenge, with Justice [[George Birmingham]] stating that "Jordan's assertions were so entirely devoid of substance that we can only conclude they were made with reckless and irresponsible abandon".{{cite news|last1=Ó Faoláin|first1=Aodhán|last2=Managh|first2=Ray|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/courts/reckless-attempt-to-appeal-abortion-referendum-result-dismissed-1.3608991|title='Reckless' attempt to appeal abortion referendum result dismissed|work=The Irish Times|date=27 August 2018|access-date=27 August 2018}}; {{cite web |last1=Birmingham |first1=Peter |title=[2018] IECA 291 : Jordan -v- Ireland & Ors |url=http://courts.ie/Judgments.nsf/09859e7a3f34669680256ef3004a27de/f750d00ce4a6d807802582f6004172f9?OpenDocument |website=Judgments & Determinations |publisher=Courts Service of Ireland |accessdate=9 September 2018}} Before the 31 August deadline, Jordan applied to the Supreme Court for [[Appeal#Ability to appeal|leave to appeal]]; the court decided on 7 September to refuse to hear the appeal,{{cite news |last1=Carolan |first1=Mary |title=Supreme Court clears way for abortion law |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/courts/supreme-court/supreme-court-clears-way-for-abortion-law-1.3621863 |access-date=7 September 2018 |work=The Irish Times |date=7 September 2018}}{{cite web |last1=Clarke |first1=Frank |last2=O'Donnell |first2=Donal |last3=Charleton |first3=Peter |title=[2018] IESCDET 124 : Jordan -v- Ireland, The Attorney General and The Referendum Returning Officer |url=http://courts.ie/Judgments.nsf/5c975dd22ad51b5580257db0003d88a2/01133f26cd91b6f0802583010038a8f8?OpenDocument |website=Judgments & Determinations |publisher=Courts Service of Ireland |accessdate=9 September 2018 |date=7 September 2018}} thus allowing the amendment to be signed into law by [[Michael D. Higgins|President Higgins]] on 18 September 2018. ==Implementing legislation== {{main|Health (Regulation of Termination of Pregnancy) Bill 2018}} Even though the referendum has been carried, "Abortion will remain illegal in almost all circumstances until the Oireachtas passes legislation providing otherwise", which the Government originally hoped to introduce into the Dáil in the autumn, and to have passed by the end of 2018, according to Health Minister Simon Harris, speaking a few days before the referendum. However, after the referendum there were calls for the process to be speeded up,{{cite web|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/simon-harris-abortion-2-4039539-May2018/|title=Harris to bring abortion legislation to Dáil before summer recess|date=28 May 2018|accessdate=2 June 2018|work=thejournal.ie|quote=Taoiseach Leo Varadkar said over the weekend that laws giving effect to Friday’s referendum could be enacted before the end of the year, but campaigners had called for a shorter timeline. The Together for Yes campaign has called on the government to pass legislation allowing for the terminations of pregnancies before the summer break.}} and Harris said that the bill would be introduced before the summer recess and would be sent to the President for signature by the autumn.{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/abortion-law-reform-to-be-much-sooner-than-expected-1.3511855|title=Abortion law reform to be much sooner than expected|date=29 May 2018|accessdate=2 June 2018|work=The Irish Times |author=Fiach Kelly, Deputy Political Editor|quote=Simon Harris says Bill will be tabled before summer and sent to President by autumn}} ''The Irish Times'' reported on 6 June that the Dáil second stage would begin on 11 July, possibly extending the Dáil term, and that remaining Oireachtas stages would be in September and October.{{cite news |last1=Kelly |first1=Fiach |last2=Carolan |first2=Mary |title=Eighth Amendment challenges ‘will not delay legislation’ |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/eighth-amendment-challenges-will-not-delay-legislation-1.3520537 |accessdate=6 June 2018 |work=The Irish Times |date=6 June 2018}} The introduction of legislation was held up until after the processing of the petitions against the referendum result. Media had speculated before the vote that a narrow Yes majority would encourage No-supporting legislators to obstruct or weaken the legislative provisions compared to the draft published in March.{{cite news |last1=Ó Cionnaith |first1=Fiachra |last2=McConnell |first2=Daniel |last3=McEnroe |first3=Juno |title=Half of FF TDs vote against Eighth referendum |url=https://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/half-of-ff-tds-vote-against-eighth-referendum-833700.html |accessdate=6 June 2018 |work=Breaking News |date=22 March 2018}} Conversely, media said afterwards that the large majority made such moves unlikely;{{cite news |last1=Leahy |first1=Pat |title=A landslide victory for Yes, far beyond any expectation |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/a-landslide-victory-for-yes-far-beyond-any-expectation-1.3509827?mode=sample&auth-failed=1&pw-origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.irishtimes.com%2Fnews%2Fpolitics%2Fa-landslide-victory-for-yes-far-beyond-any-expectation-1.3509827 |accessdate=6 June 2018 |work=The Irish Times |date=26 May 2018}} in particular, Fianna Fáil opponents would not "stand in the way" of the "will of the people".{{cite news |last1=Ryan |first1=Philip |title=Fianna Fail TDs on No side will allow abortion legislation through Dail — Martin |url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/abortion-referendum/fianna-fail-tds-on-no-side-will-allow-abortion-legislation-through-dail-martin-36948627.html |accessdate=6 June 2018 |work=Irish Independent |date=26 May 2018 |language=en}}; {{cite news |last1=Leahy |first1=Pat |title=Many anti-repeal TDs now set to back abortion legislation |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/many-anti-repeal-tds-now-set-to-back-abortion-legislation-1.3510570 |accessdate=6 June 2018 |work=The Irish Times |date=28 May 2018}} An updated general scheme of the [[Health (Regulation of Termination of Pregnancy) Bill 2018]] was published by the Department of Health on 10 July.{{cite web |title=Updated General Scheme of the Health (Regulation of Termination of Pregnancy Bill) 2018 |url=https://health.gov.ie/blog/publications/updated-general-scheme-of-the-health-regulation-of-termination-of-pregnancy-bill-2018/ |publisher=Department of Health |accessdate=9 October 2018 |language=en |date=10 July 2018}} The final text was agreed by the cabinet at a meeting on 27 September and published the same day.{{cite news |last1=Lehane |first1=Mícheál |title=Legislation providing for abortion approved by Cabinet |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/ireland/2018/0927/998329-eighth-amendment/ |accessdate=9 October 2018 |work=RTE.ie |date=27 September 2018 |language=en}}; {{cite web |title=Health (Regulation of Termination of Pregnancy) Bill 2018 |url=https://www.oireachtas.ie/en/bills/bill/2018/105/ |website=Bills |publisher=Oireachtas |accessdate=9 October 2018 |language=en-ie |date=27 September 2018}} Its [[second reading]] in the Dáil was introduced by minister Simon Harris on 4 October.{{cite web |title=Health (Regulation of Termination of Pregnancy) Bill 2018: Second Stage |url=https://www.oireachtas.ie/en/debates/debate/dail/2018-10-04/37/ |website=Dáil Éireann debate |publisher=Oireachtas |language=en-ie |date=4 October 2018}} [[Image:Gray1001.png|thumb|The removed bone reveals permanent teeth below the roots of primary teeth.]]
'''Tooth eruption''' is a process in [[tooth development]] in which the [[tooth|teeth]] enter the [[mouth]] and become visible. It is currently believed that the [[periodontal ligament]] plays an important role in tooth eruption. The first [[Tooth (human)|human teeth]] to appear, the [[Deciduous teeth|deciduous (primary) teeth]] (also known as baby or milk teeth), erupt into the mouth from around 6 months until 2 years of age, in a process known as "[[teething]]". These teeth are the only ones in the mouth until a person is about 6 years old creating the primary dentition stage. At that time, the first [[permanent teeth|permanent tooth]] erupts and begins a time in which there is a combination of primary and permanent teeth, known as the mixed dentition stage, which lasts until the last primary tooth is lost. Then, the remaining permanent teeth erupt into the mouth during the permanent dentition stage.
==Theories==
Although researchers agree that tooth eruption is a complex process, there is little agreement on the identity of the mechanism that controls eruption.<ref>Riolo, Michael L. and James K. Avery. ''Essentials for Orthodontic Practice''. 1st edition. 2003. p. 142. {{ISBN|0-9720546-0-X}}.</ref> There have been many [[theory|theories]] over time that have been eventually disproven.<ref>Harris, Edward F. ''Craniofacial Growth and Development.'' In the section titled "Tooth Eruption." 2002. pp. 1–3.</ref> According to [http://www.identalhub.com/dental-tooth-development-and-eruption-933.aspx Growth Displacement Theory], tooth is pushed upward into the mouth by the growth of the tooth's root in opposite direction. Continued Bone Formation Theory advocated that a tooth is pushed upward by the growth of the bone around the tooth. In addition, some believed teeth were pushed upward by vascular pressure or by an anatomic feature called the cushioned hammock. The cushioned hammock theory, first proposed by Harry Sicher, was taught widely from the 1930s to the 1950s. This theory postulated that a [[ligament]] below a tooth, which Sicher observed under a microscope on a histologic slide, was responsible for eruption. Later, the "ligament" Sicher observed was determined to be merely an [[Artifact (microscopy)|artifact]] created in the process of preparing the slide.<ref>Harris, Edward F. ''Craniofacial Growth and Development.'' In the section titled "Tooth Eruption." 2002. p. 3.</ref>
The most widely held current theory is that while several forces might be involved in eruption, the periodontal ligament provides the main impetus for the process. Theorists hypothesize that the periodontal ligament promotes eruption through the shrinking and cross-linking of their collagen fibers and the contraction of their fibroblasts.<ref>Harris, Edward F. ''Craniofacial Growth and Development.'' In the section titled "Tooth Eruption." 2002. p. 5.</ref>
There is good evidence from experimental animals that a traction force is unlikely to be involved in tooth eruption: Animals treated with lathyrogens that interfere with [[collagen]] cross-link formation showed similar eruption rates to control animals, provided occlusal forces were removed.
Inherent in most of the theories outlined above, is the idea that a force is generated in the periodontal ligament beneath unerupted teeth, and that this force physically drives teeth out through the bone. This idea may have been superseded by a further recent theory. This new theory proposes firstly that areas of tension and compression are generated in the soft tissues surrounding unerupted teeth by the distribution of bite forces through the jaws. These patterns of tension and compression, are further proposed to result in patterns of bone resorption and deposition that lift the tooth into the mouth.<ref name="Sarrafpour e58803">{{Cite journal|last=Sarrafpour|first=Babak|last2=Swain|first2=Michael|last3=Li|first3=Qing|last4=Zoellner|first4=Hans|date=2013-03-15|title=Tooth Eruption Results from Bone Remodelling Driven by Bite Forces Sensed by Soft Tissue Dental Follicles: A Finite Element Analysis|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0058803|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=8|issue=3|pages=e58803|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0058803|issn=1932-6203|pmc=3598949|pmid=23554928}}</ref> This theory is based on Wolff's Law, which is the long established idea that bone changes shape in accordance with the forces applied.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=PubMed&dopt=Citation&list_uids=15038485|title=A 2003 update of bone physiology and Wolff's Law for clinicians|last=Frost|first=H.M.|date=Feb 2004|website=|publisher=Angle Orthodontics|access-date=}}</ref> Significantly, a recent finite element analysis study, analysing the distribution of force through the jaw of an 8 year old child, observed overall compression in the soft tissues above, and tension in the soft tissues below, unerupted teeth.<ref name="Sarrafpour e58803"/> Because bone resorbs when compressed, and forms under tension, this finite element analysis strongly supports the new theory.<ref name="Sarrafpour e58803"/> Further work is required, however, to confirm this new theory experimentally.
==Timeline==
[[File:Baby teeth in human infant.jpg|thumb|right|The deciduous [[mandibular central incisor]]s, shown here in the mouth of a seven-month-old female infant, are the first teeth to erupt]]
[[File:ToothLost-2917.jpg|thumb|right|Bottom teeth of a seven-year-old, showing primary teeth ''(left)'', a lost primary tooth ''(middle)'', and a fully erupted permanent tooth ''(right)'']] Although tooth eruption occurs at different times for different people, a general eruption timeline exists. Typically, humans have 20 primary teeth and 32 permanent teeth.<ref>The American Dental Association, ''Tooth Eruption Charts'' at http://www.mouthhealthy.org/en/az-topics/e/eruption-charts.aspx</ref> The dentition goes through three stages.<ref name=":0">Illustrated Dental Embryology, Histology, and Anatomy, Bath-Balogh and Fehrenbach, Elsevier, 2011, page 191-192</ref> The first, known as primary [[dentition]] stage, occurs when only primary teeth are visible. Once the first permanent tooth erupts into the mouth, the teeth that are visible are in the mixed (or transitional) dentition stage. After the last primary tooth is shed or exfoliates out of the mouth, the teeth are in the permanent dentition stage. Each patient should be assigned a dentition period to allow for effective dental treatment.<ref name=":0" />
===Primary dentition stage===
Primary dentition stage starts on the arrival of the [[mandibular central incisor]]s, typically from around six months, and lasts until the first permanent molars appear in the mouth, usually at six years.<ref>Ash, Major M. and Stanley J. Nelson. ''Wheeler’s Dental Anatomy, Physiology, and Occlusion.'' 8th edition. 2003. P. 38, 41. {{ISBN|0-7216-9382-2}}.</ref> There are 20 primary teeth and they typically erupt in the following order: (1) central [[incisor]], (2) lateral incisor, (3) first molar, (4) [[Canine tooth|canine]], and (5) second molar.<ref>Ash, Major M. and Stanley J. Nelson. ''Wheeler’s Dental Anatomy, Physiology, and Occlusion.'' 8th edition. 2003. P. 38. {{ISBN|0-7216-9382-2}}.</ref> As a general rule, four teeth erupt for every six months of life, mandibular teeth erupt before maxillary teeth, and teeth erupt sooner in females than males.<ref>[http://www.webmd.com WebMd]. [http://www.webmd.com/content/article/66/79639.htm?z=4208_00000_9003_to_02 "Dental Health: Your Child's Teeth"]. Retrieved December 12, 2005.</ref> During primary dentition, the tooth buds of permanent teeth develop inferior to the primary teeth, close to the palate or tongue.
===Mixed dentition stage===
Mixed dentition stage starts when the first permanent tooth appears in the mouth, usually at five or six years with the first permanent molar, and lasts until the last primary tooth is lost, usually at ten, eleven, or twelve years.<ref>Ash, Major M. and Stanley J. Nelson. ''Wheeler’s Dental Anatomy, Physiology, and Occlusion.'' 8th edition. 2003. P. 41. {{ISBN|0-7216-9382-2}}.</ref> There are 32 permanent teeth and those of the maxillae erupt in a different order from permanent mandibular teeth. Maxillary teeth typically erupt in the following order: (1) [[Maxillary first molar|first molar]] (2) [[Maxillary central incisor|central incisor]], (3) [[Maxillary lateral incisor|lateral incisor]], (4) [[Maxillary first premolar|first premolar]], (5) [[Maxillary second premolar|second premolar]], (6) [[Maxillary canine|canine]], (7) [[Maxillary second molar|second molar]], and (8) [[Maxillary third molar|third molar]]. Mandibular teeth typically erupt in the following order: (1) [[Mandibular first molar|first molar]] (2) [[Mandibular central incisor|central incisor]], (3) [[Mandibular lateral incisor|lateral incisor]], (4) [[Mandibular canine|canine]], (5) [[Mandibular first premolar|first premolar]], (6) [[Mandibular second premolar|second premolar]], (7) [[Mandibular second molar|second molar]], and (8) [[Mandibular third molar|third molar]].<ref>American Dental Association, Permanent teeth at http://www.ada.org/~/media/ADA/Publications/Files/patient_56.ashx</ref> While this is the most common eruption order, variation is not uncommon.
Since there are no premolars in the primary dentition, the primary molars are replaced by permanent premolars.<ref>[http://www.charfac.umn.edu/MMS/ProjectMicro/Explorations/Contents.html Monthly Microscopy Explorations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051201181929/http://www.charfac.umn.edu/MMS/ProjectMicro/Explorations/Contents.html |date=2005-12-01 }}. [http://www.charfac.umn.edu/MMS/ProjectMicro/Explorations/Jan1998.html "Exploration of the Month: January 1998"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060518035644/http://www.charfac.umn.edu/MMS/ProjectMicro/Explorations/Jan1998.html |date=2006-05-18 }}. Retrieved December 12, 2005.</ref> If any primary teeth are shed or lost before permanent teeth are ready to replace them, some posterior teeth may drift forward and cause space to be lost in the mouth.<ref>[http://www.healthhawaii.org/ Health Hawaii]. [http://www.healthhawaii.org/dental/primary.html "Primary Teeth: Importance and Care"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060517115628/http://www.healthhawaii.org/dental/primary.html |date=2006-05-17 }}. Retrieved December 12, 2005.</ref> This may cause crowding and/or misplacement once the permanent teeth erupt, which is usually referred to as [[malocclusion]]. [[Orthodontics]] may be required in such circumstances for an individual to achieve a functioning and aesthetic dentition.
===Permanent dentition stage===
The permanent dentition begins when the last primary tooth is lost, usually at 11 to 12 years, and lasts for the rest of a person's life or until all of the teeth are lost ([[edentulism]]). During this stage, permanent third molars (also called "[[Wisdom tooth|wisdom teeth]]") are frequently [[Extraction (dental)|extracted]] because of decay, pain or impactions. The main reasons for [[tooth loss]] are decay or [[periodontal disease]].<ref>[http://www.perio.org/index.html The American Academy of Periodontology] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051214140958/http://www.perio.org/index.html |date=2005-12-14 }}. [http://www.perio.org/consumer/media/media-faq.htm "Oral Health Information for the Public"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061209195310/http://www.perio.org/consumer/media/media-faq.htm |date=2006-12-09 }}. Retrieved December 12, 2005.</ref>
== Active vs. Passive Eruption ==
===Active Eruption=== Active eruption is known as eruption of teeth into the mouth towards the occlusal plane. This is a natural path of eruption of all the teeth as they emerge from gingiva and continue erupting until they make contact with the opposing tooth.
=== Passive Eruption === Passive eruption is known as movement of the gingiva apically or away from the crown of the tooth to the level of [[Cementoenamel junction]] (CEJ) after the tooth has erupted completely. Problems in gingival tissue migrating apically can give rise to what is known as Altered or [[Delayed passive eruption]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alpiste-Illueca|first=Francisco|date=2011-01-01|title=Altered passive eruption (APE): a little-known clinical situation|journal=Medicina Oral, Patologia Oral Y Cirugia Bucal|volume=16|issue=1|pages=e100–104|issn=1698-6946|pmid=20711147}}</ref> In this phenomenon, the gingival tissues fail to move apically and thus lead to shorter clinical crowns with more square-shaped teeth and appearance of what is known as [[Gummy smile]].
==== Coslet Classification ==== Coslet et al.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Coslet|first=J. G.|last2=Vanarsdall|first2=R.|last3=Weisgold|first3=A.|date=1977-12-01|title=Diagnosis and classification of delayed passive eruption of the dentogingival junction in the adult|journal=The Alpha Omegan|volume=70|issue=3|pages=24–28|issn=0002-6417|pmid=276255}}</ref> classified delayed passive eruption into two types which related the bone crest of a tooth to the [[Mucogingival junction]] (MGJ) of that tooth. These two groups were further divided based on the position of the [[Alveolar bone|alveolar bone crest]] to the cementoenamel junction. {| class="wikitable" !Type !Osseous crest level !Attached gingival level !Gingival margin level !Treatment |- |Type 1a |Apical to CEJ |Adequate |Incisal to CEJ |Gingivectomy |- |Type 1b |At CEJ |Adequate |Incisal to CEJ |Gingivectomy and osseous surgery |- |Type 2a |Apical to CEJ |Inadequate |Incisal to CEJ |Apically positioned flap |- |Type 2b |At CEJ |Inadequate |Incisal to CEJ |Apically positioned flap and osseous surgery |}
== Abnormalities == Abnormalities in tooth eruption (timing and sequence) is often caused by genetics and may result in [[malocclusion]]. In severe cases, such as in [[Down syndrome#Dental|Down syndrome]], the eruption may be delayed by several years and some teeth may never erupt.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wysocki|first1=J. Philip Sapp; Lewis R. Eversole; George P.|title=Contemporary oral and maxillofacial pathology|date=2002|publisher=Mosby|location=St. Louis|isbn=0-323-01723-1|pages=39–40|edition=2nd }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Cawson|first1=R.A.|last2=Odell|first2=E.W.|title=Cawson's essentials of oral pathology and oral medicine|date=2012|publisher=Churchill Livingstone|location=Edinburgh|isbn=978-0443-10125-0|pages=419–421|edition=8th }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Dean|first1=Ralph E. McDonald ; David R. Avery ; Jeffrey A.|title=Dentistry for the child and adolescent|date=2004|publisher=Mosby|location=St. Louis, Mo|isbn=0-323-02450-5|pages=164–168, 190–194, 474|edition=8. }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Regezi|first1=Joseph A|last2=Sciubba|first2=James J|last3=Jordan|first3=Richard C K|title=Oral Pathology: Clinical Pathologic Correlations|date=2008|publisher=Saunders Elsevier|location=St Louis, Missouri|pages=353–354|edition=5th}}</ref>

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Treponema pallidum'' particle agglutination assay}} [[File:TPHA test on microplate wells.jpg|thumb|Caption]]
The '''''Treponema pallidum'' particle agglutination assay''' (also called '''TPPA''' test) is an indirect agglutination assay used for detection and titration of antibodies against the causative agent of [[syphilis]], ''[[Treponema pallidum]]'' subspecies ''pallidum''.
In the test, gelatin particles are sensitized with ''T. pallidum'' antigen. Patient serum is mixed with the reagent containing the sensitized gelatin particles. The particles aggregate to form clumps when the patient serum is positive for syphilis. In other words, the patient's serum contains antibodies to ''T. pallidum''. A negative test shows no clumping of gelatin particles. This is a type of specific treponemal test for syphilis.
A similar specific treponemal test for syphilis is the '''''Treponema pallidum'' hemagglutination assay''' or '''TPHA'''. TPHA is an indirect hemagglutination assay used for the detection and titration of antibodies against the causative agent of [[syphilis]], ''Treponema pallidum'' subspecies ''pallidum''.
In the test, red blood cells ([[erythrocytes]]) are sensitized with antigens from ''T. pallidum pallidum''. The cells then aggregate on the surface of a test dish if exposed to the serum of a patient with syphilis. It is used as a confirmatory test for syphilis infection. A negative test result shows a tight button or spot of red blood cells on the surface of the test dish. Often a plastic test plate containing many small "wells" is used as the test dish so that many patients may be tested at the same time but their results can be kept separate from each other. Please note the image of the wells on the test plate and the positive and negative test results look different.<ref>Cheesbrough, M. District Laboratory Practice in Tropical Countries, Part 2, Cambridge University Press, South Africa, second edition, 2006. </ref>
For [[primary syphilis]], TPPA has a [[sensitivity and specificity|sensitivity]] of 85% to 100%, and a [[sensitivity and specificity|specificity]] of 98% to 100%.<ref name=bmj>[http://bestpractice.bmj.com/best-practice/monograph/50/diagnosis/tests.html British Medical Journal (bestpractice.bmj.com) > Syphilis infection > Diagnostic tests] Last updated: Mar 22, 2012. In turn citing: *Creegan L, Bauer HM, Samuel MC, et al. An evaluation of the relative sensitivities of the venereal disease research laboratory test and the Treponema Pallidum particle agglutination test among patients diagnosed with primary syphilis. Sex Transm Dis. 2007;34:1016-1108. *Manavi K, Young H, McMillan A. The sensitivity of syphilis assays in detecting different stages of early syphilis. Int J STD AIDS. 2006;17:768–771. </ref> In secondary and late-latent syphilis, TPPA has a sensitivity of 98% to 100%.<ref name=bmj/>
Antibodies against other treponemal organisms, such as the ''T. pallidum'' subspecies ''endemicum'', ''pertenue'', or ''carateum'', can cause false positive results. A variety of methods exist to adsorb these antibodies from the test sample before hemagglutination.
==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Syphilis Tpha Test}} [[Category:Sexually transmitted diseases and infections]] [[Category:Syphilis]]

In [[statistics]], '''verification bias''' is a type of measurement [[bias]] in which the results of a diagnostic test affect whether the [[gold standard (test)|gold standard]] procedure is used to verify the test result. This type of bias is also known as "work-up bias" or "referral bias".<ref>{{cite journal|last1=O'Sullivan|first1=JW|last2=Banerjee|first2=A|last3=Heneghan|first3=C|last4=Pluddemann|first4=A|title=Verification bias.|journal=BMJ evidence-based medicine|date=April 2018|volume=23|issue=2|pages=54-55|doi=10.1136/bmjebm-2018-110919|pmid=29595130}}</ref><ref name=begg>{{cite journal |author=Begg CB, Greenes RA |title=Assessment of diagnostic tests when disease verification is subject to selection bias |journal=Biometrics |volume=39 |pages=207–215 |year=1983 |doi=10.2307/2530820 |pmid=6871349 |issue=1}}</ref>
In clinical practice, verification bias is more likely to occur when a preliminary diagnostic test is negative. Because many gold standard tests can be invasive, expensive, and carry a higher risk (e.g. angiography, biopsy, surgery), patients and physicians may be more reluctant to undergo further work-up if a preliminary test is negative.
In [[cohort study|cohort studies]], obtaining a gold standard test on every patient may not always be ethical, practical, or cost effective. These studies can thus be subjected to verification bias. One method to limit verification bias in clinical studies is to perform gold standard testing in a random sample of study participants.
In most situations, verification bias introduces a sensitivity estimate that is too high and a specificity that is too low.<ref name=zhou>{{cite journal |author=Zhou XH |title=Correcting for verification bias in studies of a diagnostic test's accuracy |journal=Statistical Methods in Medical Research |volume=7 |pages=337‐353 |year=1998 |doi=10.1191/096228098676485370 |issue=4}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Biases}}
[[Category:Epidemiology]] [[Category:Medical statistics]] [[Category:Bias]]
<!-- This will add a notice to the bottom of the page and won't blank it! The new template which says that your draft is waiting for a review will appear at the bottom; simply ignore the old (grey) drafted templates and the old (red) decline templates. A bot will update your article submission. Until then, please don't change anything in this text box and press "Save page". -->

{{Orphan|date=November 2014}}
{{Infobox university |name = Vienna School of Osteopathy |established = 1991 |location = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] |director = Raimund Engel |students = 350 <small>''(as of 2014)''</small> |administrative_staff = 120 <small>''(as of 2014)''</small> |academic_staff = 16 <small>''(as of 2014)''</small> |website = [http://www.wso.at/ www.wso.at] }}
The '''Vienna School of Osteopathy (WSO)''' is a private educational institution in Austria specialising in [[osteopathy]]. Extra occupational and postgradual trainings are offered for [[physical therapy|physiotherapists]] and [[doctors of medicine]]. University programmes are also open for graduates from other osteopathy schools. Up to now 550 students finished their training and currently 350 students are enrolled in training groups. Established in 1991, the WSO was the first provider of osteopathic training at academic level in Austria. It is located in [[Vienna]], [[Hietzing]] at Frimbergergasse 6.
== History == [[File:WSO Logo Transparent.png|thumb|Vienna School of Osteopathy (WSO)]] [[File:WSO building.jpg|right|320px|thumb|Building of the Vienna School of Osteopathy (WSO) in Vienna, Hietzing.]] The ''Vienna School of Osteopathy (WSO)'' was established through its funding body ''International School of Osteopathy'' by Raphael van Assche, Margot Seitschek and Raimund Engel in cooperation with Bernard Ligner and the ''Centre International d’Osteopathie'' in [[St. Etienne]], [[France]]. In 1998 this cooperation model was expanded to the ''European School of Osteopathy (ESO)'' in [[Maidstone]], [[Great Britain]].
The first courses were held in the facilities of the ''Kaiser Franz Josef Hotel'' and in the ''Kolpinghaus Währing'' in [[Vienna]]. In 1997 the WSO was relocated to Frimbergergasse 6 in the 13th district of [[Vienna]]. From the very start courses were held by mostly international lecturers.
Since 2005 the university programme ''Master of Science (Osteopathy)'' is offered in cooperation with the [[Danube University Krems]].<ref name="Newsletter 18/2005 der DUK">[http://www.donau-uni.ac.at/imperia/md/content/donau-uni/mitteilungsblaetter/2005/duk_mb_1805.pdf ''Newsletter 18/2005''] of the [[Danube University Krems]]. Website of the [[Danube University Krems]]. 1 September 2014.</ref> In this context scientific work at the WSO was enhanced and further developed. Diploma thesis and master thesis of a series of European osteopathy schools are published in the ''Osteopathic Research Web'', which was initiated and is managed by the WSO. Since September 2009 the ''Teaching Hospital'' plays a vital role in WSO's osteopatic education. It is located in the facilities of the ''Wiener Privatklinik'' in Pelikangasse 15 in the 9th district of [[Vienna]].
== Training == [[File:WSO course rooms.jpg|right|320px|thumb|WSO's course rooms.]] The training at the WSO is separated into two parts, the basic education and the university programme.<ref name="training">[http://wso.at/index.php/lehrgaenge-kurse/basislehrgang ''Training.''] Website of the Vienna School of Osteopathy (WSO). 1 September 2014.</ref> The ''basis education'' comprises 1.200 course units and is a profound and overall osteopathic training, taught by an international team. The university programmes ''Master of Science (Osteopathy)'' and ''Academic Expert (Osteopathy)'' are offered in cooperation with the [[Danube University Krems]] and encompass 1090 and 535 course units, respectively.<ref name="University programme Master of Science (Osteopathy)">[http://www.donau-uni.ac.at/de/studium/osteopathie ''Osteopathy - Danube University Krems.''] In cooperation with the WSO. Website of the [[Danube University Krems]]. 10 September 2014.</ref> Furthermore the WSO is provider of a broad range of postgraduate seminars.
== Cooperations ==
The WSO is politically tightly linked. It participated significantly in the founding of the ''Austrian Society for Osteopathy (ÖGO)''. Together with the ''Osteopathic Centre for Children (OCC)'' in [[London]], [[Great Britain]] the WSO established the ''Osteopathisches Zentrum für Kinder (OZK)'' as a training centre for paediatric osteopathy, which subsequently became an autonomous institution.<ref name="History and training at Osteopathisches Zentrum für Kinder">[http://www.ozk.at ''Osteopathischen Zentrums für Kinder.''] History and training. 10 September 2014.</ref> Since 2000 the WSO is involved in the ''Osteopathic European Academic Network (OsEAN')'', which was founded in [[Great Britain]]. The WSO is a member school of OsEAN<ref name="OsEAN Member Schools">[http://www.osean.com/index.php/component/civicrm/?task=civicrm/profile&reset=1&gid=8&force=1&crmSID=4_u&Itemid=64 ''OsEAN-Member Schools.''] Website of OsEAN. 1 September 2014.</ref> with Raimund Engel as president since 2006.<ref name="OsEAN Board Members">[http://www.osean.com/index.php/osean/board-members ''OsEAN Board Members.''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910200915/http://www.osean.com/index.php/osean/board-members |date=2014-09-10 }} Website of OsEAN. 1 September 2014.</ref> The WSO also worked actively in the establishment of the ''Forum for Osteopathic Regulation in Europe (FORE)''. Through its cooperation with ''Fortbildungszentrum Klagenfurt (FBZ)'' the educational institution can offer another course location in [[Graz]], [[Austria]].<ref name="Training of the WSO in [[Graz]] in cooperation with the Fortbildungszentrum Klagenfurt (FBZ)">[http://www.fbz-klagenfurt.at/index.php?id=166 ''FBZ.''] Training of the WSO in [[Graz]] in cooperation with the Fortbildungszentrum Klagenfurt (FBZ). Website of the Fortbilundszentrum Klagenfurt. 29 August 2014.</ref> In 2010, Raimund Engel took part in writing the ''Benchmarks for Training in Osteopathy'' of the [[World Health Organization]].<ref name="Benchmarks for Training in Osteopathy">[http://apps.who.int/medicinedocs/en/d/Js17555en/ ''Benchmarks for Training in Osteopathy''.] Page with link to the original document. Website of the [[World Health Organization]]. 5 September 2014.</ref>
== Clinical practice == [[File:WSO training hospital.jpg|right|320px|thumb|WSO's Teaching Hospital at Wiener Privatklinik.]] In the ''Teaching Hospital'' the WSO offers mandatory clinic days in collaboration with the ''Wiener Privatklinik''. Practicing in the ''Teaching Hospital'' together with supervised treatments form the practical part of WSO’s education. In addition, in the university programmes, practical work is documented in a portfolio.
== Certifications and standards ==
The WSO is certified by ''Ö-Cert''<ref name="Directory of Ö-Cert quality suppliers">[http://oe-cert.at/qualitaetsanbieter ''Directory of Ö-Cert quality suppliers.''] Website of Ö-Cert. 10 September 2014.</ref> and ''CERT NÖ'' and is involved in a certification at European level from the [[European Committee for Standardization]], conducted by the [[Austrian Standards Institute]] in May, 2014. Training at the WSO also correspond with the Standards of the ''Benchmarks for Training in Osteopathy'' of the [[World Health Organization]].
== Management ==
Raimund Engel, co-founder of the WSO, is Managing Director and Erich Mayer-Fally is Medical Director.
==References== {{reflist|34em}}
== External links == * [http://www.wso.at/ Official Website of the Vienna School of Osteopathy (WSO)] * [http://wiener-privatklinik.com/ Wiener Privatklinik] * [http://www.oego.org/ Austrian Society for Osteopathy (ÖGO)] * [http://www.osean.com/ Osteopathic European Academic Network (OsEAN)]

page.title: Water supply and sanitation in New Zealand

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=February 2017}} {| style="width: 25em; font-size: 90%; text-align: left;" class="infobox" |- |valign="top"| n/a |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Share of household metering |valign="top"| n/a |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Annual investment in WSS |valign="top"| n/a |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Share of self-financing by utilities |valign="top"| n/a |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Share of tax-financing |valign="top"| n/a |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Share of external financing |valign="top"| n/a |- ! style="text-align:center; background:lightblue;" colspan="3"|Institutions |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Decentralisation to Regional Government |valign="top"| |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"| |valign="top"| |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Water and sanitation regulator |valign="top"| No |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Responsibility for policy setting |valign="top"| |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Sector law |valign="top"| |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Number of urban service providers |valign="top"| |- ! style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"|Number of rural service providers |valign="top"| n/a |}
The provision of '''water supply and sanitation in New Zealand''' is generally of good quality in urban areas. It is provided by local government called [[Territorial authorities of New Zealand|Territorial Authorities ]] which include 15 city councils in urban areas and 53 district councils in rural areas. The legal framework includes the Health Act 1956 amended in 2007, the [[Local Government Act 2002 (New Zealand)|Local Government Act 2002]] and the [[Resource Management Act 1991]].
Much of rural New Zealand relies on [[Rainwater harvesting|collection of rainwater]] for water supply and [[septic tank]]s for sewage disposal.
==Resources== New Zealand enjoys high rainfall, especially along its west coast and the country is notable for its many large, and sometimes [[Braided river|braided rivers]]. However, although the population is relatively small, the population density in North Island is much greater than in South Island where most of the rain falls.
In rural communities, it remains common-place for houses to be served by their own private supply - usually by the collection of rain-water from roofs. This practice is not constrained by any regulations.
==Sanitation== All significant sized urban developments are served by municipal [[Effluent sewer|sewer]]s which drain to modern [[sewage treatment works|treatment works]] with final discharges to [[river]] or the [[sea]]. Rural communities and isolated housing is served by septic tanks or by chemical toilets or earth closets depending on location and usage. The 135 wastewater treatment plants discharge into the following type of environment:<ref>Ministry for the Environment:[http://www.mfe.govt.nz/issues/waste/wastewater/ How many municipal wastewater treatment plants discharge to land, sea, lake, river?]</ref> :[[Estuary]] 5 :[[Groundwater]] 8 :[[Lake]] 1 :[[Earth|Land]] 26 :[[Long Sea Outfall]] 22 :[[Near Shore Outfall]] 7 :[[River|River/stream/drain]] 62 :[[Wetland]] 4
==Water supply== The low level of [[water pollution]] and the relative abundance of rain-fall ensures that water shortages are relatively uncommon. Regional authorities provide abstraction, treatment and distribution infrastructure to most developed areas. Many municipal systems draw water from deep aquifers thus avoiding the cost of long pipelines. Some of these aquifer fed systems such as that serving [[Christchurch]] was of sufficiently good quality that no disinfection of final water was practised until the recent earthquake events. Following restoration of the network the water is no longer chlorinated. Water taken from shallower or less secure aquifers are at risk of contamination. An outbreak of [[Cryptosporidiosis]] in [[Hawkes Bay]] area affecting [[Hastings, New Zealand|Hastings]] and [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]] has been attributed to the consequences of intensive agricultural in the area overlying the aquifer. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.centralfm.co.nz/local_news/cryptosporidiosis-outbreak-napier-and-hastings|title=Cryptosporidiosis outbreak in Napier and Hastings|access-date=31 August 2016|publisher=Central FM}}</ref>
About 87% of the population receives drinking water from local authorities,<ref name=OAG>{{cite web|last=Controller and Auditor-General|title=Local authorities: Planning to meet the forecast demand for drinking water|url=http://www.oag.govt.nz/2010/water/part1.htm|accessdate=8 February 2012|year=2010}}</ref> including 53 District Councils and 5 Unitary Authorities.
Domestic water usage demand is relatively poorly documented with few authorities collecting relevant or reliable information and several relying exclusively on abstraction volumes as a surrogate for use.<ref>Controller and Auditor-General:[http://www.oag.govt.nz/2010/water/part4.htm#information Measuring how much drinking water is used]</ref> For example, in [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]] residential water use was estimated at 180 liters/person/day while total water use including commercial use and public buildings was estimated at 500 litre/person/day.<ref>{{cite web|last=Controller and Auditor-General|title=Local authorities: Planning to meet the forecast demand for drinking water, Appendix 1: Technical information about drinking water supply in the eight local authorities|url=http://www.oag.govt.nz/2010/water/appendix1.htm|accessdate=8 February 2012|year=2010}}</ref>
==Economic and financial aspects== In 2009, the country's infrastructure for drinking water was valued at about NZ$11 billion. For the years 2009 to 2019, local authorities' operational expenditure for supplying drinking water was projected at an average of NZ$605 million each year, and the average annual capital expenditure at NZ$390 million.<ref name=OAG/>
In most of New Zealand, the cost of water supply and sewage disposal is recovered from house holders through property tax as a percentage of the rateable value of the property. In urban Auckland, water use is metered and charged separately from rates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.watercare.co.nz/common-content/water-meters/Pages/default.aspx|title=Water meters|publisher=Watercare|accessdate=1 September 2016}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of water supply and sanitation by country]]
==References== <References/>
==External links== *[http://www.waternz.org.nz/ Water New Zealand]
[[Category:Water supply and sanitation in New Zealand]]

page.title: Without Pity: A Film About Abilities

revision.text:
The '''Women's Memorial March''' is an annual event held on [[Valentine's Day]] that originated in [[Vancouver]]'s [[Downtown Eastside]], to call attention to missing and murdered women in the district. As of 2009, the Missing Women's Task Force, a joint program of the [[Vancouver Police]] and the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]], lists 39 women as missing from the Downtown Eastside.<ref name="Elien">{{cite news|url=https://www.straight.com/article-201566/womens-memorial-march-take-place-valentines-day|title=Women's Memorial March to take place on Valentine's Day|last=Elien|first=Shadi |work=[[Georgia Straight]]|date=February 13, 2009|accessdate=27 November 2009}}</ref><ref>[https://www.jstor.org/stable/4138965 ''Their Spirits Live within Us: Aboriginal Women in Downtown Eastside Vancouver Emerging into Visibility''] Dara Culhane, [[American Indian Quarterly]], Vol. 27, No. 3/4, Special Issue: Urban American Indian Women's Activism (Summer - Autumn, 2003), pp. 593-606, University of Nebraska Press.</ref>
The event was initiated by [[First Nations]] women in 1992, when the body of Cheryl Anne Joe was found dismembered at the corner of Powell and Salsbury streets. The march became an annual event to protest the high numbers of women missing and murdered in the community.<ref name="CWHN">{{cite web|url=http://www.cwhn.ca/node/39432|title=The Global Women's Memorial Website : Creating a circle from which to speak in unison|last=McDowell|first=Christine|author2=Lisa Schincariol |work=Canadian Women's Health Network|accessdate=27 November 2009}}</ref>
The event has since spread to other [[Western Canadian]] cities, including [[Edmonton]] and more recently, [[Calgary]].<ref name="Wilton">{{cite news|url=https://calgaryherald.com/health/Hundreds+Calgary+march+memorial+missing+murdered+women/2565359/story.html|title=Hundreds in Calgary march in memorial for missing, murdered women|last=Wilton|first=Suzanne |date=February 15, 2010|work=[[Calgary Herald]]|publisher=[[Canwest]]|accessdate=16 February 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> A 2014 study by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police found that nearly 1,200 aboriginal women were murdered or went missing between 1980 and 2012 although some investigators believe the numbers are actually far higher.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kennedy|first1=Merrit|title=Canada To Launch Nationwide Investigation Into Murdered, Missing Aboriginal Women|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/02/17/467055203/canada-to-launch-nationwide-investigation-into-murdered-missing-aboriginal-women|accessdate=19 February 2016|agency=National Public Radio|date=17 February 2016}}</ref>
==Violence against Aboriginal women in Canada== By the year 2009, close to 67,000 [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|Aboriginal]] women who were aged 15 and above reported being subjected to violence within the previous 12 months.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Brennan|first=Shannon|title=Violent Victimization of Aboriginal Women in Canadian Provinces, 2009|journal=Statistics Canada|date=17 May 2011|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/85-002-x/2011001/article/11439-eng.pdf}}</ref> About 63% of these were aged 15 to 34 years old. 76% of the incidents reported were non-spousal violence and were not reported to police, as is the case with incidents of violence against [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|Aboriginal]] women.<ref name=Brennan>{{cite journal|last=Brennan|first=Shannon|title=Violent Victimization of Aboriginal Women in Canadian Provinces, 2009|journal=Statistics Canada|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/85-002-x/2011001/article/11439-eng.pdf}}</ref> Although many of these crimes against Aboriginal women were not reported to police or other service organizations, such as shelters, etc., 98% of women victimized told an informal source such as a friend or family member.<ref name=Brennan />
===Women's Memorial March in Downtown Eastside, Vancouver=== According to Dara Culhane, "''the annual [[Valentine's Day]] Women's Memorial March gives political expression to a complex process through which Aboriginal women here are struggling to change the language, metaphors, and image through which they come to be (re)known as they emerge into public visibility"''.<ref name=Culhane>{{cite journal|last=Culhane|first=Dara|title=Their Spirits Live Within Us: Aboriginal Women in Downtown Eastside Vancouver Emerging into Visibility|journal=American Indian Quarterly|year=2003|volume=27|series=3/4|issue=Urban American Indian Women's Activism}}</ref> The Women's Memorial March originated in 1991 in inner city [[Vancouver]] on February 14 as a day of remembrance to honor those women who have been murdered or missing.<ref name=Culhane/>
Since 1983, there has been a reported 61 cases of mostly Aboriginal women who are missing in Vancouver's Downtown Eastside.<ref name=Culhane/> Marches such as the Women's Memorial bring to light what Culhane terms the visibility of Aboriginal women. Women's Memorial Marches are not just held in Vancouver, but also [[Calgary]], [[Edmonton]], [[Montreal]], [[Toronto]] and [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]],BC.<ref name=Cooper>{{cite journal|last=Cooper|first=Jamie|title=Addressing Violence Against Aboriginal Women: FNSP Practicum 2009/10 for Battered Women's Support Services|date=October 2009 – February 2010 |display-authors=etal}}</ref>
===Case studies=== Some specific cases which illustrate the depth of the problem of violence against aboriginal women in Canada were highlighted in a report by [[Amnesty International]] in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stolen Sisters: A human rights response to discrimination and violence against Indigenous women in Canada|url=https://www.amnesty.ca/research/reports/stolen-sisters-a-human-rights-response-to-discrimination-and-violence-against-indig|website=Amnesty International Canada|publisher=Amnesty International Canada|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> They include the murder of 19-year-old '''Helen Betty Osborne''' who was killed November 12, 1971 after a night out with friends in [[The Pas]], [[Manitoba]], a town of 6,000 which was segregated between Indigenous and non-indigenous [[Canadians]]. She was accosted by four non-indigenous men at 2 a.m. while walking back to her house. Osborne refused to have sex with the men, and was then forced into their car where she was beaten and sexually assaulted. She was then taken to a local cabin, beaten some more and stabbed to death.
The police who were assigned to the case failed to act on specific tips that pointed to the four likely perpetrators. The car that was used during the crime was not searched until a year later (1972). By 1972, police concluded that they didn't have enough evidence for the case. Only twenty years later did the [[Manitoba]] Justice Inquiry conclude that the murder was indeed fueled by [[racism]] and [[sexism]]. Charges were eventually brought in October 1986 when new evidence was released. Dwayne Johnson was found guilty in 1987 and sentenced to life in prison. Among the other men, one was acquitted and the others never charged.
An example of the perceived indifference to the disappearance of Indigenous women is seen in the case of '''Shirley Lonethunder,''' a [[Cree]] woman from the White Bear First Nations reserve in [[Saskatchewan]] who was last seen by family in December 1991. At the time, she was a 25-year-old mother of two. She was a drug user and occasionally worked in the sex trade, according to family members. The family became aware that she was missing in March 1992, when Lonethunder's attorney contacted them to say she had missed a court date. According to Lonethunder's relatives, [[Saskatoon]] police investigators showed little interest in the case. Six months after filing a missing person report for his sister, Lonethunder's brother contacted the police to ask about progress on the case, only to be told they had no record of the report.
==See also== *[[Wendy Poole Park]] *[[Highway of Tears murders]] *''[[Finding Dawn]]''

{{update|date=December 2017}} {{infobox country at games | NPC = ZIM | NPCname = [[Zimbabwe National Paralympic Committee]] | games = Paralympics | year = | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = | competitors = | sports = | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 2 | silver = 9 | bronze = 6 | officials = | appearances = | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = {{Team appearances list|team=Zimbabwe|competition=Summer Paralympics|begin_year=|end_year= }} | winterappearances = | seealso = {{flagicon|Southern Rhodesia}} [[Rhodesia at the Paralympics|Rhodesia]] ([[Rhodesia at the 1960 Summer Paralympics|1960]], [[Rhodesia at the 1964 Summer Paralympics|1964]], [[Rhodesia at the 1968 Summer Paralympics|1968]], and [[Rhodesia at the 1972 Summer Paralympics|1972]]) }} '''[[Zimbabwe]]''' has been competing at the [[Paralympic Games]] since the country [[History of Zimbabwe|became independent]] in 1980; it had previously competed as [[Rhodesia]]. Zimbabwe was absent from the Games in 1988 and 1992, returning in 1996 with a two-man delegation, and has competed at every edition of the [[Summer Paralympics]] since then. It has never taken part in the [[Winter Paralympics]].[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=ZIM&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Zimbabwe at the Paralympics], [[International Paralympic Committee]] Zimbabweans have won a total of 2 gold medals, 9 silver, and 6 bronze. The country's most successful year, by far, was 1980, when Zimbabweans won 8 silver medals and 4 bronze - all but two won by [[Sandra James]] and [[Eileen Robertson]], across events in several sports. Zimbabwe's first gold medal was won by [[Elliot Mujaji]] in 2000, in the 100m sprint (T46 category). Mujaji won Zimbabwe's second (and most recent) Paralympic gold medal in the same event four years later.[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=ZIM&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Zimbabwe at the Paralympics], International Paralympic Committee Zimbabwe have since failed to win any medals after 2004. The [[Zimbabwe National Paralympic Committee]] was only officially launched and registered in 2010. Prior to this, "the government provided financial aid during the Paralympic Games, [but] there was no co-ordinated mechanism to maintain athletes' momentum between the Games", and athletes "had to find their own sponsor, coach and manager who would finance the training, travelling and their participation at competitions".[http://www.zimparalympic.org/about-us/history/ "About us: History"],
